The Ammonites hire Aramean mercenaries, but Joab and Abishai defeat them, and when the Arameans regroup, David personally leads Israel to a decisive victory.
2 Samuel 11: While his army besieges Rabbah, David stays in Jerusalem, sees Bathsheba bathing, commits adultery with her, and she becomes pregnant. David recalls her husband Uriah from battle and tries to get him to sleep with his wife, but when Uriah refuses out of loyalty to his fellow soldiers, David arranges for him to be killed in battle.
2 Samuel 12: Nathan confronts David with a parable about a rich man who steals a poor man's only lamb, and when David pronounces judgment, Nathan declares 'You are the man!' David repents, but God says the sword will never depart from his house, and though David pleads for his child's life, the baby dies on the seventh day, then David comforts Bathsheba and she bears Solomon.
2 Samuel 13: David's son Amnon becomes obsessed with his half-sister Tamar, rapes her, then hates her and throws her out. Absalom, Tamar's full brother, waits two years then murders Amnon in revenge and flees to Geshur for three years while David mourns for his son.
2 Samuel 14: Joab arranges for a wise woman to tell David a parable that manipulates him into allowing Absalom to return to Jerusalem. David permits Absalom's return but refuses to see him for two years, until Absalom forces a meeting by setting Joab's field on fire, and David finally reconciles with him.
2 Samuel 15: Absalom wins the hearts of Israel by positioning himself at the city gate to intercept those seeking justice, promising better treatment than they receive from David. After four years, Absalom goes to Hebron and declares himself king, forcing David to flee Jerusalem with his loyal followers, though David leaves ten concubines to care for the palace.
2 Samuel 16: As David flees, Ziba brings provisions and falsely claims Mephibosheth is staying behind hoping to regain Saul's kingdom. Shimei, a relative of Saul, curses David and throws stones at him, but David refuses to let Abishai kill him, accepting it as from the Lord, while Absalom enters Jerusalem and sleeps with David's concubines on the roof in fulfillment of Nathan's prophecy.
2 Samuel 17: Ahithophel advises Absalom to pursue David immediately while he is weary, but Hushai, David's spy, counters with advice to gather all Israel first, and Absalom follows Hushai's counsel, giving David time to escape. When Ahithophel sees his advice rejected, he goes home, sets his house in order, and hangs himself.
2 Samuel 18: David organizes his army under Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, and though he wants to go with them, they insist he stay behind. The battle occurs in the forest where David's forces defeat Absalom's army, and despite David's order to deal gently with Absalom, Joab kills him when he finds him hanging by his hair from a tree, and David weeps bitterly.
2 Samuel 19: David mourns so excessively for Absalom that Joab rebukes him for shaming his loyal soldiers. David returns to Jerusalem, pardoning Shimei and welcoming Mephibosheth despite Ziba's accusations, and tension erupts between Judah and the other tribes over who has greater claim to the king.
2 Samuel 20: Sheba son of Bikri leads Israel in rebellion against David, and Joab pursues him. When Joab encounters Amasa, David's newly appointed commander, he treacherously murders him, then besieges Abel Beth Maakah where a wise woman negotiates by having the city throw Sheba's head over the wall, ending the rebellion.
2 Samuel 21: A three-year famine prompts David to seek the Lord, who reveals it's because Saul killed the Gibeonites, and they demand seven of Saul's descendants be hanged. David spares Mephibosheth but hands over seven others, and Rizpah guards their bodies from birds and beasts until David honors her devotion by properly burying them with Saul and Jonathan's bones, and God ends the famine.
2 Samuel 22: David sings a psalm of thanksgiving to the Lord for delivering him from all his enemies and from Saul. The song celebrates God as his rock, fortress, and deliverer, describing how God rescued him from powerful enemies because He delighted in him, and declares the Lord's ways are perfect and He is a shield to all who take refuge in Him.
2 Samuel 23: David's last words declare that the Spirit of the Lord spoke through him and that the one who rules righteously in the fear of God is like the morning light at sunrise. The chapter records the exploits of David's mighty warriors, including the Three and the Thirty, with special mention of their heroic deeds and unwavering loyalty to David.
2 Samuel 24: God's anger burns against Israel, and He incites David to take a census of the fighting men, though even Joab objects. After nine months and twenty days, the census is complete, and David's conscience troubles him for having numbered the people, so God gives him a choice of three punishments, and David chooses to fall into God's hands rather than man's, and 70,000 die in a plague before God relents at the threshing floor of Araunah, where David builds an altar.
1 Kings 1: As David grows old, his son Adonijah exalts himself as king with Joab and Abiathar's support, but Nathan the prophet and Bathsheba alert David. David immediately has Solomon anointed king at Gihon, and when Adonijah hears the news, he flees to the altar for sanctuary, and Solomon spares him on condition of his good behavior.
1 Kings 2: David charges Solomon to walk in God's ways, keep His statutes, and deal wisely with Joab and Shimei. When Adonijah requests to marry Abishag, Solomon sees it as a power play and has him executed, removes Abiathar from the priesthood, kills Joab for his past murders, and executes Shimei when he violates his house arrest, and the kingdom is firmly established in Solomon's hands.
1 Kings 3: Solomon marries Pharaoh's daughter and loves the Lord, walking in David's statutes. At Gibeon, God appears to Solomon in a dream and offers him anything, and Solomon humbly asks for wisdom to govern God's people, which pleases the Lord, who grants him unparalleled wisdom along with riches and honor, demonstrated when Solomon wisely judges between two prostitutes claiming the same baby.
1 Kings 4: Solomon's officials and governors are listed, showing his organized administration over all Israel. Solomon's wisdom exceeds all the people of the East and Egypt, he speaks 3,000 proverbs and composes 1,005 songs, and people from all nations come to hear his wisdom, while Israel lives in safety and prosperity, each man under his own vine and fig tree.
1 Kings 5: King Hiram of Tyre, who loved David, sends word to Solomon, and Solomon arranges a treaty to obtain cedar and cypress from Lebanon for building the temple. Hiram provides the timber while Solomon supplies food for Hiram's household, and Solomon conscripts 30,000 laborers along with 70,000 carriers and 80,000 stonecutters to prepare for the temple construction.
1 Kings 6: In the fourth year of Solomon's reign, 480 years after the Exodus, he begins building the temple according to God's specifications. The magnificent structure takes seven years to complete, with detailed descriptions of its dimensions, cedar paneling, gold overlay, and the inner sanctuary for the Ark, and God promises to dwell among Israel if Solomon walks in His statutes.
1 Kings 7: Solomon spends thirteen years building his own palace complex, including the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon, the Hall of Justice, and residences for himself and Pharaoh's daughter. Hiram, a skilled craftsman from Tyre, creates the bronze pillars Jakin and Boaz, the massive bronze Sea, ten movable stands with basins, and all the furnishings for the temple.
1 Kings 8: Solomon brings the Ark of the Covenant into the completed temple, and the glory of the Lord fills the house so the priests cannot minister. Solomon blesses the assembly, offers a magnificent prayer of dedication acknowledging that heaven cannot contain God yet asking Him to hear prayers made toward this temple, and celebrates with sacrifices and a feast lasting fourteen days.
1 Kings 9: The Lord appears to Solomon a second time, promising to establish his throne forever if he walks faithfully, but warning that if Israel turns to other gods, He will cut them off and reject the temple. Solomon completes his building projects, establishes forced labor from non-Israelites, and Hiram gives Solomon twenty towns which displease him, and the queen of Sheba visits to test Solomon's wisdom.
1 Kings 10: The Queen of Sheba visits Solomon, tests him with hard questions, and is overwhelmed by his wisdom and prosperity. She praises the God of Israel and gives Solomon abundant gifts, and Solomon's annual gold revenue reaches 666 talents, he makes hundreds of gold shields, builds a magnificent ivory throne, and exceeds all kings in riches and wisdom as people seek his God-given insight.
1 Kings 11: Solomon loves many foreign women who turn his heart after other gods in his old age, and he builds high places for their detestable idols. God angrily declares He will tear the kingdom from Solomon, though He will leave one tribe for David's sake, and God raises up adversaries against Solomon—Hadad, Rezon, and Jeroboam—and Ahijah prophesies that Jeroboam will rule ten tribes.
1 Kings 12: Rehoboam rejects the elders' advice to lighten the people's burden and follows the young men's counsel to increase it, causing ten tribes to rebel under Jeroboam. Jeroboam establishes golden calves at Bethel and Dan to prevent people from going to Jerusalem, appoints non-Levitical priests, and institutes his own festival, leading Israel into grievous sin.
1 Kings 13: A man of God from Judah prophesies against Jeroboam's altar at Bethel, and when Jeroboam's hand withers as he points at him, the prophet prays and it's restored. An old prophet deceives the man of God into disobeying God's command not to eat in Bethel, and a lion kills him on the road as judgment, yet the old prophet buries him honorably and confirms his prophecy will come true.
1 Kings 14: Jeroboam's son falls ill, and he sends his wife in disguise to the prophet Ahijah, but God reveals her identity. Ahijah prophesies disaster on Jeroboam's house for his idolatry—all his male descendants will be destroyed and his son will die when she enters the city, which happens immediately, and meanwhile Rehoboam of Judah also does evil, provoking God with high places and Asherah poles.
1 Kings 15: Abijah reigns in Judah for three years with a divided heart, while his son Asa does what is right, removing idols and deposing his grandmother Maakah for her Asherah pole. In Israel, Nadab succeeds Jeroboam but reigns only two years before Baasha assassinates him and destroys Jeroboam's entire family, and Baasha does evil like Jeroboam.
1 Kings 16: God pronounces judgment on Baasha through the prophet Jehu for following Jeroboam's sins. After Baasha's son Elah reigns two years, Zimri assassinates him and destroys Baasha's family, but Zimri rules only seven days before Israel makes Omri king, who besieges Zimri in the palace until he burns it down with himself inside, and Omri's son Ahab does more evil than all before him, marrying Jezebel and serving Baal.
1 Kings 17: Elijah prophesies a drought to Ahab, then God sends him to a brook where ravens feed him, and when the brook dries up, God directs him to a widow at Zarephath. The widow's flour and oil miraculously never run out, but when her son dies, Elijah prays three times and God restores the boy's life.
1 Kings 18: In the third year of drought, Elijah confronts Ahab and challenges the prophets of Baal to a contest on Mount Carmel to see whose God answers by fire. Baal's prophets fail all day while Elijah mocks them, but when Elijah prays, fire falls from heaven consuming the sacrifice, stones, and water, and the people cry 'The Lord—he is God!' Elijah kills the prophets of Baal, and rain finally comes.
1 Kings 19: Jezebel threatens to kill Elijah, and he flees into the wilderness, where he sits under a broom tree and asks to die. An angel provides food, and strengthened by it, Elijah travels forty days to Mount Horeb where God speaks to him not in wind, earthquake, or fire, but in a gentle whisper, and commissions him to anoint Hazael, Jehu, and Elisha, and Elijah finds Elisha plowing and calls him to be his servant.
1 Kings 20: Ben-Hadad of Aram besieges Samaria with thirty-two kings, but a prophet assures Ahab of victory, and Israel defeats the vastly superior Aramean forces twice. When Ahab spares Ben-Hadad's life contrary to God's will and makes a treaty with him, a prophet confronts Ahab and declares that Ahab will pay with his life for letting God's condemned man go.
1 Kings 21: Ahab covets Naboth's vineyard next to his palace, but Naboth refuses to sell his ancestral inheritance. Jezebel arranges false charges against Naboth, has him stoned to death, and Ahab takes possession of the vineyard, but Elijah confronts him with God's judgment that dogs will lick his blood where they licked Naboth's, and Jezebel will be eaten by dogs, and when Ahab humbles himself, God delays the disaster until his son's days.
1 Kings 22: Ahab wants to recapture Ramoth Gilead and persuades Jehoshaphat of Judah to join him, though the prophet Micaiah warns that God has put a lying spirit in Ahab's prophets to lure him to his death. Ahab disguises himself in battle but is struck by a random arrow, dies that evening, and dogs lick up his blood while washing his chariot, and Jehoshaphat reigns in Judah doing mostly right while Ahab's son Ahaziah does evil.
2 Kings 1: After Ahab's death, Moab rebels, and Ahaziah falls through a lattice and sends messengers to consult Baal-Zebub about his recovery. Elijah intercepts them with God's message that Ahaziah will die, and when Ahaziah sends soldiers to seize Elijah, fire consumes the first two groups of fifty until the third captain pleads for mercy, and Elijah personally delivers God's death sentence to the king.
2 Kings 2: As Elijah is about to be taken up to heaven, Elisha refuses to leave his side despite Elijah's three attempts to send him away. When they cross the Jordan on dry ground, Elisha asks for a double portion of Elijah's spirit, and a chariot of fire separates them as Elijah is taken up in a whirlwind, and Elisha picks up Elijah's cloak and performs miracles including purifying Jericho's water and calling bears to maul boys who mock him.
2 Kings 3: Joram of Israel does evil but not as badly as his father Ahab, and when Moab rebels, he allies with Jehoshaphat and the king of Edom to attack. When the armies run out of water in the desert, Elisha prophesies that God will provide water without rain and give them victory, which happens, though the Moabites' king sacrifices his firstborn on the wall, causing great wrath and Israel's withdrawal.
2 Kings 4: Elisha multiplies a widow's oil to save her sons from slavery, promises a barren woman a son who is later raised from the dead, makes poisonous stew safe to eat, and feeds one hundred men with twenty loaves. These miracles demonstrate God's provision and Elisha's prophetic authority throughout Israel.
2 Kings 5: Naaman, commander of Aram's army, has leprosy, and a captured Israelite girl suggests he see Elisha. Elisha tells him to wash seven times in the Jordan, and though Naaman is initially offended, his servants persuade him to obey, and he is healed, but when Gehazi, Elisha's servant, lies to get gifts from Naaman, he is struck with leprosy.
2 Kings 6: When a borrowed ax head falls into the Jordan, Elisha makes it float. The king of Aram discovers Elisha reveals his plans to Israel's king, so he sends an army to capture Elisha, but God opens the servant's eyes to see fiery horses and chariots, strikes the Arameans with blindness, and Elisha leads them to Samaria where they're released, leading to peace, though Aram later besieges Samaria causing terrible famine.
2 Kings 7: During the siege and famine, Elisha prophesies that food will be abundant by tomorrow, which an officer doubts and is told he'll see it but not eat it. Four leprous men discover the Aramean camp abandoned because God made them hear chariots and horses, and they report it to the king, and the doubting officer is trampled to death at the gate as people rush for food.
2 Kings 8: The woman whose son Elisha raised from the dead returns from seven years in Philistia during the famine and recovers her land with the king's help. Elisha travels to Damascus where he weeps after telling Hazael he will be king and the evil he will do to Israel, and Hazael murders Ben-Hadad to seize the throne, while Jehoram and then Ahaziah reign in Judah, both doing evil.
2 Kings 9: Elisha sends a prophet to anoint Jehu as king over Israel to destroy Ahab's house and avenge the prophets' blood. Jehu immediately conspires against Joram, shoots him with an arrow in Naboth's field fulfilling Elijah's prophecy, has Ahaziah of Judah killed, and orders Jezebel thrown from a window where dogs eat her body, leaving only her skull, feet, and hands.
2 Kings 10: Jehu challenges Ahab's seventy sons' guardians in Samaria, who respond by killing them all and sending their heads in baskets. Jehu wipes out all Ahab's remaining family and followers, then deceitfully assembles all Baal worshipers under pretense of a great sacrifice, traps them in Baal's temple, and slaughters them all, demolishing the temple and making it a latrine, though he doesn't turn from Jeroboam's golden calves.
2 Kings 11: When Athaliah sees her son Ahaziah is dead, she murders the entire royal family of Judah to seize the throne, but Jehosheba hides the infant Joash for six years. In the seventh year, Jehoiada the priest reveals Joash, has him crowned king, and the people execute Athaliah, and Jehoiada makes a covenant renewing dedication to the Lord, and the people destroy Baal's temple.
2 Kings 12: Joash does right as long as Jehoiada the priest instructs him, and he orders the priests to repair the temple, but when they fail to do so, Jehoiada establishes a chest for collecting money that is used directly for repairs. Later when Hazael threatens Jerusalem, Joash sends him temple and palace treasures as tribute, and Joash's officials assassinate him for shedding innocent blood.
2 Kings 13: Jehoahaz of Israel does evil and God gives them to Hazael of Aram, but when Jehoahaz seeks God's favor, the Lord provides a deliverer. His son Jehoash also does evil, and when Elisha is dying, he prophesies that Jehoash will defeat Aram three times, and after Elisha dies, a dead man thrown in Elisha's tomb comes back to life when he touches Elisha's bones.
2 Kings 14: Amaziah of Judah does right but not wholeheartedly, defeats Edom, foolishly challenges Israel's king Jehoash, and is thoroughly defeated with Jerusalem's wall broken down and temple treasures taken. In Israel, Jeroboam II reigns forty-one years doing evil but restoring Israel's boundaries as prophesied by Jonah, and Amaziah is assassinated and succeeded by his son Azariah.
2 Kings 15: Azariah (Uzziah) reigns fifty-two years doing right but doesn't remove the high places and is struck with leprosy. Israel descends into chaos with five kings in a few decades—Zechariah, Shallum, Menahem, Pekahiah, and Pekah—all doing evil, until Hoshea conspires against Pekah, and Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria begins deporting Israelites, while in Judah, Jotham and then Ahaz reign, with Ahaz doing great evil.
2 Kings 16: Ahaz of Judah does evil, sacrificing his son in fire and worshiping at high places, and when Rezin and Pekah attack Jerusalem, Ahaz appeals to Assyria for help rather than trusting God. After meeting Tiglath-Pileser in Damascus, Ahaz has a copy of a pagan altar built in Jerusalem, replacing the bronze altar and making various ungodly changes to the temple furnishings.
2 Kings 17: Hoshea becomes Israel's last king, doing evil but not as badly as his predecessors, and when he withholds tribute from Assyria, Shalmaneser besieges Samaria for three years, conquers it, and deports the Israelites to Assyria in 722 BC. The chapter explains Israel's exile resulted from persistent idolatry and rejection of God's warnings through prophets, and Assyria settles foreigners in Israel who form a syncretistic religion mixing fear of the Lord with idol worship.
2 Kings 18: Hezekiah becomes king at age twenty-five and does what is right, removing high places, smashing sacred stones, breaking the bronze serpent Moses made, and trusting in the Lord like no king before or after. He rebels against Assyria and defeats the Philistines, but when Sennacherib invades, Hezekiah pays heavy tribute, yet the Assyrian king sends his field commander to threaten Jerusalem with blasphemous claims that God cannot deliver them.
2 Kings 19: When Hezekiah hears the Assyrian threats, he tears his clothes, seeks Isaiah's counsel, and prays earnestly for deliverance. Isaiah prophesies that God will defend Jerusalem, and that night the angel of the Lord strikes down 185,000 Assyrian soldiers, forcing Sennacherib to withdraw to Nineveh where his own sons assassinate him.
2 Kings 20: Isaiah tells the sick Hezekiah to set his house in order because he will die, but when Hezekiah weeps and prays, God adds fifteen years to his life and gives a sign by moving the shadow backward ten steps. Envoys from Babylon visit and Hezekiah foolishly shows them all his treasures, and Isaiah prophesies that everything will be carried to Babylon and Hezekiah's descendants will serve in the Babylonian king's palace.
2 Kings 21: Manasseh becomes king at age twelve and does more evil than any before him, rebuilding high places, erecting altars to Baal, worshiping the stars, practicing divination and sorcery, and even sacrificing his son and placing an Asherah pole in the temple. God declares He will bring such disaster on Jerusalem that both ears of everyone who hears it will tingle, and though Manasseh's son Amon also does evil, he reigns only two years before being assassinated.
2 Kings 22: Josiah becomes king at age eight and does right, walking in David's ways without turning aside. When repairing the temple, the Book of the Law is found and read to Josiah, who tears his robes in distress at Israel's disobedience, and when he inquires of the prophetess Huldah, she confirms judgment is coming but because Josiah humbled himself, he will die in peace before the disaster comes.
2 Kings 23: Josiah reads the Book of the Covenant to all the people and renews the covenant before the Lord. He undertakes radical reforms—removing all pagan priests, destroying high places from Geba to Beersheba, defiling Topheth, removing horses dedicated to the sun, burning Asherah poles, and slaughtering pagan priests on their altars, and he celebrates Passover like no Passover since the judges' days, yet God's anger against Judah does not turn away.
2 Kings 24: After Josiah is killed by Pharaoh Necho, Jehoiakim becomes a vassal to Babylon but rebels after three years, and God sends raiders against Judah. Jehoiachin reigns three months doing evil before Nebuchadnezzar besieges Jerusalem, and the young king surrenders, and Babylon carries away 10,000 captives including all the officials, warriors, craftsmen, and the prophet Ezekiel, leaving only the poorest people, and makes Zedekiah king.
2 Kings 25: Zedekiah rebels against Babylon after nine years, and Nebuchadnezzar besieges Jerusalem for two years until famine is severe. The Babylonians break through the wall, capture Zedekiah, kill his sons before his eyes, blind him, burn the temple and palace, break down Jerusalem's walls, and carry most remaining people to exile, leaving only the poorest to work the land, and Gedaliah the appointed governor is assassinated, but thirty-seven years later, Babylon's king releases Jehoiachin from prison and honors him.
1 Chronicles 1: This chapter traces humanity's genealogy from Adam through Noah's sons, listing the descendants of Japheth, Ham, and Shem. The line focuses particularly on Abraham's descendants through both Ishmael and Isaac, and Esau's descendants, establishing the broader family context for Israel's origins.
1 Chronicles 2: The genealogy traces Judah's line in detail, including his sons by Tamar, Perez's descendants through Hezron, and the family of Ram who leads to David. Special attention is given to Caleb's descendants and various branches of Judah's tribe, establishing the royal lineage.
1 Chronicles 3: David's sons born in Hebron and Jerusalem are listed, including Solomon through whom the royal line continues. The genealogy extends through Solomon's descendants to the Babylonian exile and beyond, including Zerubbabel who would lead the return, showing the continuation of David's line even after the kingdom's fall.
1 Chronicles 4: Additional descendants of Judah are recorded, including Jabez who cries out to God for blessing and enlarged territory, and God grants his request. The chapter also lists descendants of Simeon, their cities, and their expansion into surrounding territories.
1 Chronicles 5: The descendants of Reuben (who lost his birthright due to sin), Gad, and half-tribe of Manasseh are recorded, including their territories east of the Jordan. Despite their might and victories when they cried out to God in battle, they were unfaithful and worshiped the gods of the peoples God had destroyed, so God stirred up Assyria to take them into exile.
1 Chronicles 6: This long chapter traces the Levitical line from Levi through Aaron to the high priests who served until the exile, including Zadok and other key figures. It lists the duties of the Levitical families in music ministry at the tabernacle and temple, and details the towns given to the Levites throughout Israel's territory, emphasizing their role as Israel's spiritual servants.
1 Chronicles 7: The genealogies of Issachar, Benjamin, Naphtali, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Asher are recorded with their mighty warriors and tribal leaders. Ephraim's line includes Joshua, and special note is made of various warriors and leaders who served these tribes.
1 Chronicles 8: Benjamin's genealogy is given in detail, particularly those who lived in Jerusalem after the exile. The chapter emphasizes Saul's family line through his sons, grandsons, and the descendants who continued after the kingdom passed to David.
1 Chronicles 9: Those who resettled in Jerusalem after the exile are listed by families, including priests, Levites, gatekeepers, and other temple servants. The chapter describes their duties in caring for the temple, its furnishings, and leading worship, then concludes by repeating Saul's genealogy as a transition to his story.
1 Chronicles 10: The Philistines battle Israel on Mount Gilboa, killing Saul's three sons including Jonathan. Saul, badly wounded, falls on his own sword to avoid capture, and the Philistines fasten his body to the temple of their gods until men from Jabesh Gilead retrieve and bury him, and the narrator states Saul died for his unfaithfulness and for consulting a medium.
1 Chronicles 11: All Israel comes to David at Hebron and makes him king, and he captures Jerusalem from the Jebusites, making it his capital. The chapter celebrates David's mighty warriors—the Three who performed heroic exploits including bringing him water from Bethlehem's well past enemy lines, and the Thirty including Benaiah who killed a lion in a pit on a snowy day—men who made David's kingdom great.
1 Chronicles 12: Warriors from various tribes join David while he's still under Saul's authority—Benjamites who could shoot arrows or sling stones with either hand, Gadites who cross the flooding Jordan, and many others. The chapter lists the thousands from each tribe who come to Hebron to make David king over all Israel with great celebration and unity.
1 Chronicles 13: David consults with all Israel's leaders and decides to bring the Ark of God from Kiriath Jearim to Jerusalem with great celebration. When the oxen stumble, Uzzah reaches out to steady the ark and God strikes him dead for his irreverence, and David is angry then afraid, leaving the ark at Obed-Edom's house for three months where it brings blessing.
1 Chronicles 14: King Hiram of Tyre sends materials and craftsmen to build David a palace, and David takes more wives and has more children in Jerusalem. When the Philistines come to attack, David inquires of God who gives him specific battle strategies, and David defeats them twice, and his fame spreads throughout every land as the Lord makes all nations fear him.
1 Chronicles 15: David prepares to bring the ark to Jerusalem properly this time, assembling the Levites and instructing them to consecrate themselves since they should carry the ark as Moses commanded. With joyful celebration and music led by Levites including Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, they successfully bring the ark to Jerusalem, though Michal despises David's exuberant dancing.
1 Chronicles 16: The ark is placed in the tent David prepared, and he appoints Levites to minister before it with music and thanksgiving. David delivers a psalm of thanks celebrating God's covenant faithfulness to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, proclaiming His glory among nations and calling all creation to worship, and he establishes regular worship with Asaph and his associates before the ark in Jerusalem.
1 Chronicles 17: David desires to build God a house, but God tells Nathan that David's son will build the temple instead. God makes a covenant with David, promising that his throne will be established forever and his descendant will build the house for God's name, and David responds with a humble prayer of thanksgiving, marveling that God would make such promises to him.
1 Chronicles 18: The Lord gives David victory wherever he goes—defeating Philistines, Moabites, Hadadezer of Zobah, and the Arameans who came to help him. David dedicates the plunder from all nations to the Lord, and when Edomites come, he defeats them too, placing garrisons throughout Edom, and David reigns over all Israel, doing what is just and right for all his people.
1 Chronicles 19: David sends envoys to comfort Hanun king of the Ammonites, but Hanun humiliates them by shaving them and cutting their garments. The Ammonites hire Aramean mercenaries, but Joab and Abishai wisely divide their forces and defeat both armies, and when the Arameans regroup with reinforcements, David personally leads Israel to a crushing victory.
1 Chronicles 20: Joab besieges Rabbah while David remains in Jerusalem (the Chronicler omits the Bathsheba account), and David eventually takes Rabbah and the Ammonite crown. The chapter records victories over the Philistines, including killing giants who were descendants of Rapha, as David's mighty men continue to secure his kingdom.
1 Chronicles 21: Satan incites David to take a census of Israel, and despite Joab's protest, David insists, angering God. David chooses to fall into God's hands rather than man's, and though 70,000 die in a plague, God relents at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite where David builds an altar, and fire falls from heaven to consume the sacrifice, establishing this as the site for the future temple.
1 Chronicles 22: David makes extensive preparations for building the temple, gathering materials including 100,000 talents of gold, a million talents of silver, and bronze and iron beyond weighing. He charges Solomon to build the house for the Lord, commands Israel's leaders to help Solomon, and emphasizes that God will be with Solomon if he carefully follows all the law Moses gave.
1 Chronicles 23: When David is old, he makes Solomon king and organizes the Levites into divisions for temple service. He numbers the Levites from age thirty upward—38,000 total—assigning some to temple work, some as officials and judges, some as gatekeepers, and some as musicians praising the Lord, establishing the pattern for worship that will continue for generations.
1 Chronicles 24: David and Zadok divide Aaron's descendants into twenty-four divisions for priestly service, casting lots to determine their order so no group could claim preference. The remaining Levites are also organized by families and assigned duties, establishing an orderly system for temple ministry that ensures each family serves in turn.
1 Chronicles 25: David and the army commanders set apart the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun for the ministry of prophesying with music through harps, lyres, and cymbals. The chapter lists all 288 skilled musicians divided into twenty-four groups, assigned their duties by casting lots regardless of age or status, emphasizing that musical worship is as important as priestly service.
1 Chronicles 26: The gatekeepers are organized into divisions with specific assignments—guarding the temple's various entrances, the storehouses, and the treasuries. Additional Levites are appointed over the treasuries of dedicated things, and others serve as officials and judges throughout Israel, maintaining order and justice in both religious and civil matters.
1 Chronicles 27: This chapter lists David's military organization—twelve divisions of 24,000 men serving month by month, his mighty warriors, tribal leaders, and officers over royal property and herds. It includes overseers for various agricultural operations, royal storehouses, and counselors, demonstrating the sophisticated administration of David's kingdom.
1 Chronicles 28: David assembles all Israel's leaders and announces that though he wanted to build God's temple, God chose Solomon instead. David charges Solomon publicly to serve God with wholehearted devotion and careful obedience, gives him detailed plans for the temple that came from the Lord's hand, and encourages him to be strong and courageous because God will be with him until all the work is finished.
1 Chronicles 29: David announces his personal gift for the temple—3,000 talents of gold and 7,000 of silver—and challenges the leaders who respond with tremendous generosity, totaling over 5,000 talents of gold. David offers a magnificent prayer of praise acknowledging everything comes from God's hand, prays for Solomon to keep God's commands with wholehearted devotion, the people worship joyfully, and Solomon is anointed king, and David dies at a good old age after reigning forty years.
2 Chronicles 1: Solomon establishes himself firmly over the kingdom, goes to Gibeon with all Israel to sacrifice before the tabernacle, and God appears to him offering anything he desires. Solomon asks for wisdom and knowledge to lead God's people, which pleases God who grants him unparalleled wisdom along with wealth and honor, and Solomon accumulates horses, chariots, gold, and silver in abundance.
2 Chronicles 2: Solomon prepares to build the temple and sends to King Hiram of Tyre for skilled craftsmen and cedar timber, describing the magnificence of the house he will build. Hiram praises God and sends Huram-Abi, a highly skilled craftsman, along with timber, and Solomon conscripts 70,000 carriers, 80,000 stonecutters, and 3,600 foremen to oversee the work.
2 Chronicles 3: Solomon begins building the temple in the fourth year of his reign on Mount Moriah where the Lord appeared to David. The chapter provides detailed dimensions and descriptions—the portico, the main hall overlaid with pure gold, the Most Holy Place with carved cherubim overlaid with gold, and the two bronze pillars Jakin and Boaz.
2 Chronicles 4: Solomon makes the bronze altar, the massive bronze Sea supported by twelve bulls, ten bronze water basins on movable stands, and all the furnishings for the temple. Huram-Abi completes all the work with meticulous craftsmanship—lampstands, tables, bowls, and articles of pure gold—creating a magnificent house for the Lord.
2 Chronicles 5: Solomon brings the ark and all the sacred furnishings into the completed temple, and the Levites carry the ark into the Most Holy Place beneath the cherubim. When the priests withdraw and the musicians begin to praise God in unison, the glory of the Lord fills the temple in a cloud so thick the priests cannot perform their service.
2 Chronicles 6: Solomon addresses the assembly, blessing them and recounting how God chose Jerusalem and David's line. He kneels before all Israel with hands spread toward heaven and offers a magnificent prayer of dedication, asking God to hear prayers made toward this temple concerning justice, drought, plague, enemies, foreigners seeking God, and exile, and when he finishes, fire falls from heaven and consumes the sacrifices.
2 Chronicles 7: The glory of the Lord fills the temple and the people worship, offering 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep in celebration lasting seven days plus seven more for the Festival of Tabernacles. God appears to Solomon at night, promising to hear prayers made toward this temple, but warning that if they turn to other gods, He will uproot Israel and reject the temple, making it an object of ridicule.
2 Chronicles 8: Solomon completes his building projects including the temple, his palace, and various cities, taking twenty years total. He rebuilds cities, establishes storage facilities, organizes the priests and Levites for temple service, and conducts trade expeditions with Hiram's fleet that bring back gold from Ophir.
2 Chronicles 9: The Queen of Sheba visits Solomon, testing him with hard questions, and is overwhelmed by his wisdom, wealth, and the happiness of his officials. She praises the God of Israel and gives Solomon abundant gifts, and Solomon's annual gold revenue reaches 666 talents as kings from all over the world seek his wisdom, and he reigns forty years before dying and Rehoboam succeeds him.
2 Chronicles 10: Rehoboam goes to Shechem where all Israel gathers to make him king, and the people ask him to lighten the harsh labor Solomon imposed. Rehoboam rejects the elders' wise counsel to be kind and follows the young men's advice to increase the burden, causing ten tribes to rebel under Jeroboam and leave only Judah and Benjamin loyal to the house of David.
2 Chronicles 11: When Rehoboam prepares to fight Israel to restore his kingdom, the prophet Shemaiah delivers God's message forbidding the war. Rehoboam fortifies cities in Judah, and when Jeroboam rejects the Levites, they move to Judah along with faithful Israelites from all tribes who come to Jerusalem to sacrifice to the Lord, strengthening Rehoboam's kingdom for three years.
2 Chronicles 12: After Rehoboam establishes his kingdom, he and all Israel abandon the law, so God allows Shishak king of Egypt to invade. When Rehoboam and the leaders humble themselves, God relents from total destruction but allows them to become subject to Shishak, who plunders the temple and palace treasures, and Rehoboam makes bronze shields to replace the gold ones.
2 Chronicles 13: War breaks out between Abijah of Judah and Jeroboam of Israel, and though outnumbered two-to-one, Abijah proclaims that God is with Judah because they keep His ordinances while Israel has forsaken Him. When Israel sets an ambush, Judah cries out to the Lord, the priests blow trumpets, and God defeats Israel with 500,000 casualties, and Jeroboam never recovers his power.
2 Chronicles 14: Asa does what is good and right, removing foreign altars and high places, and the land has peace for ten years. When Zerah the Cushite comes with a vast army, Asa prays for God's help, trusting in His name, and the Lord strikes down the Cushites who flee, and Judah carries off abundant plunder.
2 Chronicles 15: The Spirit of God comes upon Azariah who encourages Asa that the Lord is with them when they seek Him. Emboldened by this prophecy, Asa removes detestable idols, repairs the altar, and assembles the people who make a covenant to seek the Lord with all their heart, and God gives them rest on every side.
2 Chronicles 16: In his thirty-sixth year, Asa faces Baasha of Israel and foolishly trusts in Aram's king rather than the Lord, bribing Ben-Hadad with temple treasures. The seer Hanani rebukes Asa, reminding him how God delivered him from the Cushites, but Asa angrily imprisons the seer and oppresses some people, and when he develops a severe foot disease, he seeks physicians rather than the Lord.
2 Chronicles 17: Jehoshaphat strengthens himself against Israel, removes the high places and Asherah poles, and sends officials and Levites throughout Judah to teach the Book of the Law. The fear of the Lord falls on surrounding kingdoms so they don't make war, and Jehoshaphat becomes powerful with great wealth, large armies, and experienced commanders.
2 Chronicles 18: Jehoshaphat allies himself with Ahab through marriage and joins him to fight for Ramoth Gilead despite the prophet Micaiah warning that God has put a lying spirit in Ahab's prophets to lure him to his death. Jehoshaphat cries out in battle and is spared, but Ahab is struck by a random arrow and dies, fulfilling Micaiah's prophecy.
2 Chronicles 19: When Jehoshaphat returns safely, the seer Jehu rebukes him for helping the wicked and loving those who hate the Lord, though God still finds some good in him. Jehoshaphat appoints judges throughout the fortified cities and in Jerusalem, charging them to judge carefully because they judge for the Lord, not man, and he instructs them to serve faithfully with reverent fear.
2 Chronicles 20: A vast army from Moab, Ammon, and Edom comes against Jehoshaphat, and he proclaims a fast and prays earnestly before all Judah, acknowledging their powerlessness. The Spirit of the Lord comes upon Jahaziel who declares the battle is God's, and when Judah goes out singing praises, God sets ambushes and the enemy armies destroy each other, and it takes three days to collect the plunder.
2 Chronicles 21: Jehoshaphat dies and Jehoram becomes king, immediately murdering all his brothers to secure his throne. Jehoram does evil, walking in the ways of Israel's kings, and though God doesn't destroy Judah for David's sake, Edom and Libnah revolt, and Elijah sends a letter prophesying a terrible plague on Jehoram's family and intestines, which comes true, and he dies unmourned after eight years.
2 Chronicles 22: Ahaziah reigns one year doing evil under his mother Athaliah's influence, and he joins Joram of Israel in battle where Jehu kills them both. Athaliah seizes Judah's throne and murders the royal family, but Jehosheba hides the infant Joash, preserving David's line.
2 Chronicles 23: In the seventh year, Jehoiada the priest makes a covenant with the commanders and reveals Joash, stationing armed guards around him. They crown Joash king, anointing him amid shouts of 'Long live the king!' Athaliah tears her robes crying 'Treason!' but they execute her outside the temple grounds, and Jehoiada makes a covenant renewing dedication to the Lord, and the people destroy Baal's temple and priest.
2 Chronicles 24: Joash does what is right as long as Jehoiada lives, repairing the temple with money collected in a chest. After Jehoiada dies at 130, officials lead Joash astray into idolatry, and when Jehoiada's son Zechariah prophesies against them, Joash has him stoned in the temple courtyard, and Zechariah's dying words are 'May the Lord see this and call you to account.' A small Aramean army defeats Judah, Joash is wounded, and his officials assassinate him.
2 Chronicles 25: Amaziah does right but not wholeheartedly, executing his father's assassins but sparing their children according to the Law. He hires 100,000 Israelite troops but a prophet warns him to send them away, and when Amaziah obeys, God gives him victory over Edom, but he foolishly brings back Edomite idols to worship, provoking God's anger, and his pride leads him to challenge Israel's king who thoroughly defeats him.
2 Chronicles 26: Uzziah becomes king at sixteen and does right, seeking God during Zechariah's lifetime, and God gives him success in battle, agriculture, and building projects. His fame spreads far, but when he becomes powerful, pride leads him to enter the temple to burn incense, and when the priests confront him, God strikes him with leprosy on his forehead, and he lives in isolation until his death.
2 Chronicles 27: Jotham becomes king and does right, growing powerful because he walks steadfastly before the Lord. He builds extensively, defeats the Ammonites who pay him tribute for three years, and reigns sixteen years, but the people continue their corrupt practices.
2 Chronicles 28: Ahaz does evil, following the detestable practices of the nations, making cast idols for the Baals and sacrificing his sons in fire. God gives him into the hands of Aram and Israel who kill 120,000 warriors in one day and take 200,000 captives, though a prophet convinces Israel to release them, and when Assyria attacks, Ahaz seeks their help by plundering the temple, but it doesn't help him.
2 Chronicles 29: Hezekiah becomes king at twenty-five and immediately begins reforms, opening and repairing the temple doors in the first month. The Levites consecrate themselves, cleanse the temple for sixteen days, reinstitute proper worship with sacrifices and music, and Hezekiah and all the people rejoice at what God has brought about, though it happened so quickly.
2 Chronicles 30: Hezekiah sends word throughout Israel and Judah inviting everyone to Jerusalem for Passover in the second month, though couriers are mocked in the north. Many humble themselves and come, celebrating with great joy for seven days, then continuing seven more days, and the celebration is unprecedented since Solomon's time, and the priests and Levites bless the people, and God hears their prayer.
2 Chronicles 31: When the festival ends, the people go throughout Judah smashing sacred stones, cutting down Asherah poles, and destroying high places. Hezekiah organizes the priests and Levites into divisions, and when he commands the people to bring their contributions, they respond so generously that heaps of produce pile up for months, requiring storage rooms to be prepared, and Hezekiah does what is good, right, and faithful before the Lord.
2 Chronicles 32: Sennacherib invades Judah, and Hezekiah prepares by blocking springs, strengthening defenses, and encouraging the people. When Assyrian officers mock God and threaten Jerusalem, Hezekiah and Isaiah pray earnestly, and the angel of the Lord annihilates the Assyrian army overnight, and Sennacherib returns home in disgrace where his own sons kill him, and Hezekiah is highly regarded, but his pride over Babylonian envoys brings a rebuke, though he humbles himself.
2 Chronicles 33: Manasseh becomes king at twelve and does more evil than the nations God destroyed, rebuilding high places, erecting altars to false gods in the temple, and sacrificing his sons in fire. God sends Assyria who captures Manasseh with hooks and bronze shackles, and in his distress, Manasseh humbles himself greatly, prays to God, and God brings him back to Jerusalem where he removes foreign gods and idols, though his son Amon reigns two years doing evil before being assassinated.
2 Chronicles 34: Josiah becomes king at eight, and at sixteen begins seeking God, and at twenty begins purging Judah of high places, Asherah poles, and idols, even going into Israel's territory. While repairing the temple, Hilkiah finds the Book of the Law, and when it's read to Josiah, he tears his robes in distress, and the prophetess Huldah confirms judgment is coming but Josiah will die in peace because he humbled himself.
2 Chronicles 35: Josiah celebrates the Passover with meticulous attention to God's commands, organizing the priests and Levites, providing abundant animals for sacrifice, and leading Israel in the greatest Passover since Samuel's time. Tragically, Josiah ignores Pharaoh Necho's warning that God sent him through Judah, disguises himself to fight at Megiddo, is struck by archers, and dies, and all Judah mourns the righteous king, and Jeremiah composes laments.
2 Chronicles 36: After Josiah, Judah has four kings in quick succession—Jehoahaz (deposed by Egypt after three months), Jehoiakim (who does evil for eleven years), Jehoiachin (who reigns three months before Babylon exiles him), and Zedekiah (who rebels against Babylon after eleven years). The people become increasingly unfaithful, the leaders mock God's prophets, and finally God's wrath can no longer be restrained, so Babylon destroys Jerusalem, burns the temple, and exiles the people for seventy years until Cyrus of Persia decrees they can return.
Ezra 1: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, fulfilling Jeremiah's prophecy, God moves Cyrus to issue a decree allowing the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple. Cyrus returns the gold and silver articles Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the temple, totaling 5,400 items, and the neighboring peoples provide resources for those returning.
Ezra 2: This chapter lists the exiles who returned to Jerusalem and Judah from Babylon, numbering 42,360 people plus 7,337 servants. The list includes family groups, priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, and temple servants, and some whose ancestry couldn't be verified, and when they arrive, many make freewill offerings for rebuilding the temple.
Ezra 3: In the seventh month, the people assemble and build the altar to sacrifice burnt offerings, celebrating the Festival of Tabernacles despite fearing the surrounding peoples. In the second year they begin laying the temple foundation, and when it's completed, the priests and Levites lead worship with thanksgiving and praise, and the people shout with joy, though many old men who remembered the first temple weep aloud.
Ezra 4: Enemies of Judah offer to help build the temple, but when Zerubbabel and the leaders refuse, they discourage and intimidate the people, bribing officials to frustrate their plans. They send letters to Persian kings accusing the Jews of rebuilding a rebellious city, and King Artaxerxes orders work to stop, and the enemies use force to halt construction for fifteen years until Darius's reign.
Ezra 5: The prophets Haggai and Zechariah urge the people to resume building, and Zerubbabel and Jeshua restart construction. When the governor Tattenai questions their authority, they explain Cyrus authorized it, and Tattenai writes to King Darius asking him to search the archives, and meanwhile the elders continue building encouraged by the prophets.
Ezra 6: Darius searches the archives and finds Cyrus's decree authorizing the temple's construction with specific dimensions and provisions. Darius orders Tattenai to stay away, supply whatever the priests need from royal revenues, and even provide animals for sacrifices, and anyone who interferes will be impaled on a beam from their own house, and the temple is completed in Darius's sixth year amid great celebration.
Ezra 7: During Artaxerxes' reign, Ezra, a teacher skilled in the Law of Moses, travels from Babylon to Jerusalem with the king's blessing and generous provisions. The king's letter grants Ezra authority to teach God's law, appoint magistrates and judges, and take silver and gold for the temple, and Ezra credits God for inclining the king's heart favorably, and he gathers leaders to return with him.
Ezra 8: Ezra lists the family heads who accompanied him from Babylon, including priests and Levites, totaling about 1,500 men plus women and children. He proclaims a fast seeking God's protection for the journey, refuses the king's soldiers trusting God instead, entrusts the temple treasures to priests, and after three months' travel, they arrive safely in Jerusalem with all the gold and silver intact.
Ezra 9: The leaders inform Ezra that the people, including priests and Levites, have intermarried with surrounding peoples who practice detestable customs. Ezra tears his tunic, pulls hair from his head and beard, sits appalled until evening, then falls on his knees in prayer, confessing Israel's sins and guilt, acknowledging God's grace in their survival and return, yet admitting they've again broken His commands.
Ezra 10: While Ezra prays and confesses, weeping and throwing himself before the temple, a large crowd gathers, also weeping bitterly, and Shekaniah proposes making a covenant to send away foreign wives and their children. Ezra makes the leaders take an oath, and within three days all the men assemble in heavy rain, agreeing to separate from foreign wives, and the chapter lists all who had married foreign women, totaling about 110 men.
Nehemiah 1: Nehemiah, cupbearer to King Artaxerxes, receives news from his brother that Jerusalem's walls are broken down and its gates burned. He weeps, mourns, fasts, and prays for days, confessing Israel's sins and asking God to grant him success when he speaks to the king about the situation.
Nehemiah 2: When the king notices Nehemiah's sadness and asks why, Nehemiah prays quickly then requests permission to go rebuild Jerusalem, and the king grants it, providing letters for safe passage and timber. Nehemiah inspects Jerusalem's walls at night, then tells the officials about God's gracious hand upon him, and they agree to rebuild, but Sanballat, Tobiah, and Geshem mock them.
Nehemiah 3: This chapter details the rebuilding of Jerusalem's walls, listing each gate and section with the families and individuals responsible for repairs. The work proceeds around the entire city wall with priests, Levites, rulers, merchants, and common people all participating, though some nobles refuse to help, and the text emphasizes everyone working together.
Nehemiah 4: When Sanballat and Tobiah hear about the rebuilding, they mock the Jews, but Nehemiah prays and the people work with determination. As the wall reaches half its height, enemies plot to attack, so Nehemiah stations armed guards while half work and half stand watch, and the people work from dawn to dusk with weapons ready, and Nehemiah and his men never take off their clothes.
Nehemiah 5: The people cry out against their fellow Jews who are charging excessive interest and seizing their children as slaves to pay debts. Nehemiah angrily rebukes the nobles and officials, and they agree to return confiscated property and stop charging interest, and Nehemiah reminds them he hasn't taken the governor's food allowance for twelve years, serving at his own expense out of fear of God.
Nehemiah 6: Sanballat and others repeatedly try to lure Nehemiah away to harm him, but he refuses, recognizing their schemes. They send false accusations and hire prophets to frighten him into hiding in the temple, but Nehemiah doesn't give in, and after fifty-two days the wall is completed, and when surrounding nations hear, they realize this work was done with God's help.
Nehemiah 7: After the wall is completed, Nehemiah appoints gatekeepers, singers, and Levites, puts his brother Hanani in charge of Jerusalem, and gives instructions about opening and closing the gates. God puts it in his heart to assemble the people and register them by families, and he finds the genealogical record of those who first returned from exile, listing the same families and numbers as Ezra 2.
Nehemiah 8: All the people assemble and ask Ezra to bring the Book of the Law, and he reads it from daybreak till noon on a wooden platform with Levites helping people understand. When the people weep upon hearing the Law, Nehemiah and Ezra tell them not to mourn but celebrate because this day is sacred, and the people discover the command about the Festival of Tabernacles and celebrate it with great joy for seven days.
Nehemiah 9: The Israelites gather with fasting and sackcloth, confess their sins, and spend a quarter of the day reading the Law and another quarter worshiping. The Levites lead an extended prayer recounting God's faithfulness throughout history—from Abraham through the Exodus, wilderness, conquest, and judges—contrasting it with Israel's repeated rebellion, yet celebrating God's compassion and mercy in not abandoning them even in exile.
Nehemiah 10: The leaders, Levites, and priests seal a binding agreement to follow God's Law, promising not to intermarry with surrounding peoples, to keep the Sabbath and sabbatical year, to care for the temple with regular contributions, and to bring firstfruits, firstborn animals, and tithes. The document includes specific names of those who seal it, showing the people's serious commitment to covenant renewal.
Nehemiah 11: The leaders settle in Jerusalem while the rest cast lots to bring one of every ten people to live in the holy city, and the people commend those who volunteer. The chapter lists the leaders, priests, Levites, and gatekeepers who settle in Jerusalem and the surrounding towns, organizing the people for worship and security.
Nehemiah 12: This chapter lists the priests and Levites who returned with Zerubbabel and traces the succession of high priests. For the dedication of the wall, the Levites gather from the surrounding area, and two large choirs process around the wall in opposite directions with thanksgiving, meeting at the temple with joyful celebration, and the sound of rejoicing can be heard far away, and officials are appointed over the storerooms.
Nehemiah 13: When they read that Ammonites and Moabites should be excluded from God's assembly, they separate all foreigners. Nehemiah learns the priest Eliashib gave Tobiah a room in the temple, so he throws out Tobiah's household goods and purifies the rooms, rebukes those neglecting the Levites and breaking the Sabbath, and confronts men who married foreign women, even chasing away a priest married to Sanballat's daughter, and prays God will remember him favorably.
Esther 1: King Xerxes displays his wealth for 180 days then holds a seven-day banquet for all his officials. When Queen Vashti refuses to come display her beauty at his drunken command, his advisors convince him to depose her and issue a decree that all women must honor their husbands, lest other wives become disobedient.
Esther 2: Xerxes' attendants propose gathering beautiful virgins and choosing a new queen. Mordecai's cousin Esther, whom he adopted after her parents died, is taken to the palace and wins favor with everyone, especially Hegai the keeper of the women, and after twelve months of beauty treatments, she is brought to the king who loves her above all women and makes her queen, and Mordecai uncovers an assassination plot and Esther reports it to the king.
Esther 3: King Xerxes honors Haman, and all officials bow to him except Mordecai the Jew. Enraged, Haman plots to destroy all Jews throughout the kingdom, casts lots (purim) to choose a date, and convinces the king to issue an edict authorizing the annihilation of all Jews in one day, plundering their goods, and couriers carry the decree to every province.
Esther 4: When Mordecai learns of the edict, he tears his clothes, puts on sackcloth, and wails loudly. He sends word to Esther to plead with the king, but she explains approaching the king uninvited means death, and Mordecai responds that perhaps she came to her royal position 'for such a time as this,' and Esther agrees to go after three days of fasting.
Esther 5: Esther puts on royal robes and stands in the inner court, and when the king sees her, he extends his golden scepter, sparing her life. He offers her up to half his kingdom, but she only requests he and Haman attend a banquet, and at the banquet she invites them to another the next day, and Haman boasts to his family but is enraged that Mordecai still won't bow, and his wife suggests building a gallows to hang Mordecai.
Esther 6: That night the king cannot sleep and has the chronicles read, discovering Mordecai saved his life but was never rewarded. When Haman arrives to request permission to hang Mordecai, the king asks how to honor someone, and Haman, thinking the king means him, suggests royal robes and a horse, so the king orders Haman to do exactly this for Mordecai, humiliating Haman who returns home in mourning.
Esther 7: At the second banquet, Esther reveals she is Jewish and pleads for her life and her people's, identifying Haman as the enemy. The king storms out in rage, and when he returns to find Haman falling on Esther's couch begging for mercy, he orders Haman hanged on the very gallows Haman built for Mordecai.
Esther 8: The king gives Mordecai Haman's position and Esther his estate, but the edict to destroy the Jews still stands. Esther begs the king to revoke it, and he allows her and Mordecai to write a new decree letting Jews defend themselves, which is sent throughout the kingdom in every language, and many people convert to Judaism out of fear of the Jews.
Esther 9: On the thirteenth day of Adar, when enemies hoped to overpower the Jews, the opposite occurs—the Jews strike down their enemies while officials help them out of fear of Mordecai. In Susa, the Jews kill 500 men plus Haman's ten sons, and the king grants one more day, and throughout the provinces 75,000 enemies die, and Mordecai establishes Purim as an annual celebration of deliverance.
Esther 10: King Xerxes imposes tribute throughout his empire, and Mordecai the Jew becomes second in rank, working for his people's welfare and speaking up for their security. His acts of power and might are recorded in the annals of the kings of Media and Persia.
Job 1: Job, a blameless and upright man in Uz, has seven sons, three daughters, and vast wealth. In heaven, Satan challenges God, claiming Job only serves God because of His protection and blessings, so God allows Satan to test Job, and in one day messengers bring news that raiders stole his oxen and donkeys, fire fell from heaven burning his sheep, Chaldeans took his camels, and a windstorm killed all his children, yet Job worships God saying, 'The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away; may the name of the Lord be praised.'
Job 2: Satan again appears before God, who points to Job's continued integrity despite losing everything. Satan argues that if Job's health is struck, he will curse God, so God allows Satan to afflict Job with painful sores from head to foot, and Job's wife tells him to curse God and die, but Job rebukes her, and three friends—Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar—come to comfort him, sitting in silence for seven days because they see his suffering is very great.
Job 3: Job finally breaks his silence and curses the day of his birth, wishing he had died in the womb rather than live to see such misery. He questions why God gives life to those in misery and longs for death that doesn't come, expressing the depth of his anguish and suffering.
Job 4: Eliphaz responds gently, reminding Job of how he has strengthened others, but questions whether innocent people ever perish. He describes a mysterious vision where a spirit declared that no mortal can be more righteous than God, and suggests that those who sow trouble reap it, implying Job must have sinned to suffer so greatly.
Job 5: Eliphaz continues, declaring that trouble doesn't come from the soil but people are born to it. He encourages Job to appeal to God who does marvelous things, and promises that if Job accepts God's discipline, God will deliver him from six troubles, even seven, and restore him to greater blessing than before.
Job 6: Job responds that his anguish is so great it outweighs the sand of the seas, and God's arrows have pierced him. He defends his complaint as justified, laments that his friends have proved undependable like seasonal streams that dry up, and asks them to teach him where he has gone wrong rather than assuming he has sinned.
Job 7: Job continues, describing life as hard service with no rest, his nights full of tossing until dawn, his skin broken and oozing. He questions why God watches him so closely if he's only going to die soon anyway, and asks what his sin is that God targets him and won't leave him alone even long enough to swallow his saliva.
Job 8: Bildad accuses Job's words of being a blustering wind, insisting God doesn't pervert justice and suggesting Job's children died for their own sins. He argues that God doesn't reject a blameless person, so if Job is pure, God will restore him, but if not, he will perish like godless hypocrites who trust in what proves fragile as a spider's web.
Job 9: Job agrees no one can be righteous before God, but questions how to contend with One who is infinitely powerful and wise. He describes God's incomprehensible greatness yet laments that God seems to destroy both the blameless and the wicked alike, and there is no mediator between them to lay a hand on both and remove God's rod from him.
Job 10: Job pours out his complaint freely, asking God why He condemns him and whether it pleases Him to oppress, to favor the wicked while crushing the work of His hands. He questions why God brought him out of the womb only to suffer, asking to be left alone for his few remaining days before he goes to the land of gloom and deep shadow.
Job 11: Zophar harshly accuses Job of being a talker full of empty words, claiming Job says his beliefs are flawless and he is pure, but insists God knows deceitful people and sees wickedness. He declares that if Job puts away sin and reaches out to God, his life will be brighter than noonday and secure, but the wicked have no escape.
Job 12: Job responds sarcastically that surely his friends are the people and wisdom will die with them, but he is not inferior and knows as much as they do. He declares that even animals could teach them that God is sovereign over everything, but his friends' proverbs are as worthless as ashes, and he wishes to argue his case directly with God.
Job 13: Job tells his friends they are worthless physicians who whitewash the truth with lies, and they should be silent because that would be their wisdom. He declares his desire to argue his case before God, knowing that even if God slays him, he will hope in Him, though he wants to know what he has done wrong, asking why God hides His face and treats him as an enemy.
Job 14: Job reflects on humanity's brief, troubled life like a flower that withers and a shadow that flees, questioning why God would bring charges against such a one. He wishes God would hide him in the grave until His anger passes, then remember him, but laments that unlike a tree that can sprout again when cut down, when a person dies, they don't return.
Job 15: Eliphaz responds more harshly, accusing Job of filling himself with hot east wind and undermining piety with his words. He argues that even the heavens are not pure in God's sight, how much less humans who drink up evil like water, and describes the fate of the wicked who live in anguish, suggesting this is Job's condition.
Job 16: Job calls his friends miserable comforters whose speeches are like a torrent of words, saying he could speak like them if positions were reversed. He describes how God has worn him out, torn him in His wrath, and allowed the wicked to strike him on the cheek, yet insists his prayer is pure and his witness is in heaven, and he weeps before God.
Job 17: Job's spirit is broken, his days cut short, and the grave awaits him, and though mockers surround him, he pleads with God to be his pledge. He laments that his friends have closed their minds to understanding, and though they claim his night will soon be day, he sees darkness approaching, making the grave his home and the worm his family.
Job 18: Bildad angrily asks when Job will stop his words, accusing him of regarding his friends as cattle. He describes in vivid detail the fate of the wicked—their light goes out, calamity pursues them, terrors startle them, disease eats their skin, they are torn from security, and their memory perishes, suggesting all this applies to Job.
Job 19: Job responds that his friends have reproached him ten times without shame, and even if he has sinned, it remains his own matter. He describes how God has wronged him, walled up his path, stripped his honor, alienated his family, and made everyone turn against him, and he pleads for pity, but declares confidently: 'I know that my redeemer lives, and that in the end he will stand on the earth. And after my skin has been destroyed, yet in my flesh I will see God.'
Job 20: Zophar responds with agitation, describing the brief triumph of the wicked who may enjoy pleasure but will perish forever. Though evil is sweet in their mouth and wealth fills their stomach, God will make them vomit it up, their prosperity will not endure, and terrors will overtake them—this is the fate God has appointed for the wicked.
Job 21: Job counters by observing that the wicked often prosper, their children thrive, their homes are safe, their cattle increase, and they spend their days in wealth without suffering. He questions why, if God judges, the wicked are not punished in their lifetime but often die in comfort and security, making his friends' arguments meaningless.
Job 22: Eliphaz directly accuses Job of great wickedness—withholding water from the weary, bread from the hungry, sending widows away empty, and crushing orphans—and claims this is why disaster has overtaken him. He urges Job to submit to God, accept instruction, return to the Almighty, and remove wickedness, promising that if he does, God will restore him.
Job 23: Job wishes he knew where to find God so he could present his case before Him, but God is not in His dwelling place. He knows Job has not departed from God's commands, treasuring His words more than daily bread, yet God does whatever He pleases with him, and understanding this terrifies Job, though God has not silenced him with darkness.
Job 24: Job questions why the Almighty doesn't set times for judgment when the wicked steal from the poor, push the needy off the path, murder the innocent, and commit adultery under cover of darkness. He observes that though evildoers briefly prosper, they will be brought low, cut off like heads of grain, yet asks who can prove him wrong.
Job 25: Bildad's brief response declares that dominion and fear belong to God who makes peace in His heights, and questions how a mortal can be righteous before God or one born of woman be pure, since even the moon is not bright and stars are not pure in His eyes, how much less man who is a maggot.
Job 26: Job mocks Bildad's unhelpful words, asking whose spirit spoke through him. He then describes God's power—He spreads the northern skies over empty space, suspends the earth over nothing, wraps waters in clouds, stirs up the sea, and by His breath the heavens become fair, yet these are merely the outer fringes of His works.
Job 27: Job vows by the living God who has denied him justice that he will maintain his innocence as long as he lives and never admit his friends are right. He describes the fate awaiting the wicked—their children will face the sword or hunger, their widows will not weep, and though they heap up silver and clothes, the righteous will wear them.
Job 28: Job describes humanity's impressive ability to mine precious metals and gems from the earth's depths, but asks where wisdom can be found, for it is hidden from living creatures and cannot be purchased with gold or jewels. Only God understands the way to wisdom, for He looks to the ends of the earth, and He said to humanity: 'The fear of the Lord—that is wisdom, and to shun evil is understanding.'
Job 29: Job longs for the months when God watched over him, when his lamp shone above his head and he walked through darkness by God's light. He recalls when he was honored in the city gate, helped the poor and needy, broke the fangs of the wicked, and lived like a king among his troops, and everyone listened to his counsel.
Job 30: Now young men whose fathers Job would have disdained mock him, and outcasts spit in his face. God has afflicted him terribly—His fury pursues him, nights of pain pierce his bones, and terrors overwhelm him. He cries to God but receives no answer, and stands up in the assembly pleading for help, yet expected good but evil came, light but darkness arrived.
Job 31: Job makes a final defense of his integrity through a series of oaths, declaring if he has lusted, lied, committed adultery, mistreated servants, ignored the poor, trusted in wealth, rejoiced at enemies' misfortune, or hidden sin like Adam, then let him be punished. He insists on his innocence and longs for the Almighty to answer him, willing to wear any accusation like a crown if someone could prove wrongdoing.
Job 32: After Job's three friends stop answering because Job is righteous in his own eyes, Elihu becomes angry—at Job for justifying himself rather than God, and at the three friends for condemning Job without proving him wrong. Elihu, younger than the others, waited to speak out of respect for age, but now declares he is full of words and must speak, and he will show no partiality.
Job 33: Elihu addresses Job directly, saying he will speak uprightly from sincere motives. He rebukes Job for claiming to be pure and without sin, saying God has no obligation to answer humans, and He speaks in various ways though people may not perceive it—through dreams, suffering, and angelic intervention—to turn them from wrongdoing and preserve them from death.
Job 34: Elihu appeals to the wise men listening, arguing that Job speaks without knowledge when he says God denies him justice. He declares it's unthinkable that God would do wrong, for He governs all people impartially, doesn't need to investigate further before judging, and has no obligation to explain His ways to humans who charge Him with injustice.
Job 35: Elihu questions Job's claim to be more righteous than God, asking what Job gains by being sinless or what God gains if Job sins. He explains that human righteousness or wickedness only affects other humans, not God, and when people cry out in affliction but don't seek God, He doesn't answer because of their pride and empty cries.
Job 36: Elihu asks Job to wait while he speaks more on God's behalf, saying God is mighty yet doesn't despise anyone. He explains that God uses suffering to speak to people, to draw them from distress, warn them about sin, and if they listen and serve Him, they will prosper, but if not, they will perish, and he describes God's power in thunder, rain, and storms.
Job 37: Elihu continues describing God's awesome power in storms—thunder, lightning, snow, and ice—that accomplish His purposes whether for judgment or to show His love. He challenges Job to consider God's wonders, questions whether Job can explain the clouds or lightning, and asks how Job can confront God when he cannot even look at the sun, concluding that God is exalted beyond our understanding.
Job 38: The Lord answers Job out of the storm, challenging him: 'Who is this that obscures my plans with words without knowledge?' God asks Job where he was when He laid the earth's foundations, set its dimensions, and made the sea, then questions whether Job has comprehended the earth's vast expanses, death's gates, light's dwelling, or snow's storehouses, overwhelming Job with questions about creation he cannot answer.
Job 39: God continues questioning Job about wild animals—do you know when mountain goats give birth, can you provide food for lions, does the hawk take flight by your wisdom, does the eagle soar at your command? He describes the ostrich's foolishness, the horse's strength in battle, and the hawk's flight, demonstrating His sovereign care and design throughout creation.
Job 40: God asks if Job who contends with Him will correct Him, and Job covers his mouth, admitting he has no answer. God continues, asking if Job has an arm like His, then describes Behemoth, a powerful creature that moves with majesty, eats grass like an ox, whose strength is in its loins, and can drink up rivers, demonstrating God's creative power over the mightiest creatures.
Job 41: God describes Leviathan, an untamable creature no one can capture with hooks or pierce its hide with harpoons, breathing fire and smoke, with scales so tight no air can pass between them, thrashing making the depths churn like a boiling pot, nothing on earth its equal, looking down on all that are haughty—it is king over all that are proud.
Job 42: Job responds in humble repentance, acknowledging he spoke of things he didn't understand, that his ears had heard of God but now his eyes have seen Him, and he despises himself and repents in dust and ashes. God rebukes Job's three friends for not speaking truth about Him like Job did, commands them to sacrifice and have Job pray for them, then restores Job's fortunes, giving him twice as much as before—14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, 1,000 donkeys, seven sons and three daughters, and 140 more years of life.
Psalm 1: This wisdom psalm contrasts two paths—the blessed person who delights in God's law and meditates on it day and night, becoming like a fruitful tree by streams of water, versus the wicked who are like chaff blown away by the wind. The righteous will prosper while the way of the wicked will perish.
Psalm 2: This royal psalm celebrates God's anointed king in Zion and warns the nations not to rebel against the Lord and His Messiah. Kings are urged to serve the Lord with fear and submit to the Son, for blessed are all who take refuge in Him.
Psalm 3: Written when David fled from his son Absalom, this psalm expresses trust in God despite being surrounded by many enemies who say God will not deliver him. David declares that the Lord is his shield and glory who answers when he calls, and he lies down and sleeps in peace because the Lord sustains him.
Psalm 4: David calls on God to answer him in his distress and rebukes those who turn his glory into shame by loving delusions. He encourages trust in the Lord, declaring that God has set apart the faithful and gives him more joy than material abundance, and he lies down in peace knowing the Lord keeps him safe.
Psalm 5: David brings his morning prayer to God, asking Him to listen to his cry for help and lead him in righteousness because of his enemies. He contrasts the wicked who speak lies with the righteous whom God blesses, and asks God to destroy the wicked while letting those who take refuge in Him rejoice forever.
Psalm 6: In this lament, David pleads with God not to rebuke him in anger or discipline him in wrath, for he is faint and his bones are in agony. He is worn out from groaning, his bed drenched with tears, but he confidently declares that the Lord has heard his weeping and will accept his prayer while his enemies flee in disgrace.
Psalm 7: David takes refuge in the Lord from those pursuing him, asking God to arise in anger against his enemies' rage and awaken to decree justice. He proclaims his innocence and calls on God the righteous judge to bring down the wicked who dig pits for others but fall into them themselves.
Psalm 8: David marvels at God's majesty displayed in creation—the heavens, moon, and stars—and wonders why God is mindful of mere humans, yet has made them rulers over creation, crowned with glory and honor. The psalm both opens and closes with 'Lord, our Lord, how majestic is your name in all the earth!'
Psalm 9: David praises God with all his heart for His marvelous deeds and just judgments against the nations and the wicked. He celebrates that the Lord reigns forever, judging the world with righteousness, and is a refuge for the oppressed in times of trouble.
Psalm 10: The psalmist asks why God seems far away when the wicked arrogantly persecute the poor and boast that God doesn't see or care. He describes the wicked who ambush the innocent like lions, yet appeals to God to arise and defend the helpless, declaring that the Lord does see trouble and grief and will call the wicked to account.
