Psalm 11: When advised to flee like a bird to the mountains because the wicked are drawing their bows, David refuses because the Lord is his refuge. He declares that the Lord is in His holy temple, examines both righteous and wicked, and will rain down judgment on the wicked while upholding the righteous who will see His face.
Psalm 12: David cries out for help because the faithful have vanished and everyone lies to their neighbor with flattering but deceptive lips. The Lord promises to protect the oppressed and needy, and though the wicked freely strut about and vileness is honored, God's words are flawless and He will keep the faithful safe.
Psalm 13: David asks 'How long, O Lord?' four times, feeling forgotten and wondering how long sorrow will fill his heart and enemies triumph. Yet he trusts in God's unfailing love, rejoices in His salvation, and sings to the Lord who has been good to him.
Psalm 14: The fool says in his heart 'There is no God,' and all have turned away doing corrupt and vile deeds with no one who does good. God looks down from heaven on humanity and finds none who seek Him, but He is present with the righteous generation, and the psalmist longs for salvation to come from Zion to restore Jacob.
Psalm 15: David asks who may dwell in God's sacred tent and live on His holy mountain. The answer describes a person of integrity who speaks truth, does no wrong to neighbors, honors those who fear the Lord, keeps oaths even when it hurts, lends money without interest, and refuses bribes—whoever does these things will never be shaken.
Psalm 16: David declares God is his refuge and Lord, and apart from God he has no good thing. He finds joy in the faithful, rejects those who run after other gods, and celebrates that the Lord is his chosen portion and inheritance who makes his lot secure and counsels him, and he will not be shaken because God is at his right hand, showing him the path of life and eternal pleasures.
Psalm 17: David appeals to God to hear his righteous plea, examine his heart, and find no evil, for he has resolved not to sin with his mouth. He asks God to show His wonderful love by saving him from the wicked who attack like lions, and prays that when he awakes he will be satisfied with seeing God's face.
Psalm 18: This lengthy psalm of thanksgiving celebrates how God rescued David from all his enemies—God came down in power with thunder and lightning, drew him out of deep waters, and delivered him because He delighted in him. David praises God as his rock, fortress, and deliverer who trains his hands for battle, and he exalts the Lord who gives him victory over the nations.
Psalm 19: The heavens declare God's glory and the skies proclaim His handiwork, speaking without words yet their voice goes out to all the earth. The law of the Lord is perfect, more precious than gold and sweeter than honey, reviving the soul and making wise the simple, and David prays that his words and meditation would be pleasing to the Lord, his Rock and Redeemer.
Psalm 20: This prayer for the king asks that the Lord answer him in trouble, send help from the sanctuary, remember his sacrifices, and grant his heart's desires. The people trust not in chariots or horses but in the name of the Lord their God, confident that the Lord gives victory to His anointed king.
Psalm 21: The king rejoices in God's strength and salvation, celebrating the blessings God has granted including life, splendor, and eternal joy in His presence. The king will find all his enemies, God's hand will destroy those who hate Him, and the people will sing praise to God's strength.
Psalm 22: Beginning with Jesus' words on the cross—'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?'—David describes intense suffering with enemies surrounding him like bulls and dogs, his bones out of joint, strength dried up, hands and feet pierced, and people dividing his clothes. Yet the psalm turns to praise, declaring God has not despised the afflicted one's cry, and all nations will worship the Lord who rules over them.
Psalm 23: This beloved shepherd psalm declares the Lord is David's shepherd who provides everything he needs—green pastures, quiet waters, restored soul, guidance in righteousness, comfort through dark valleys, protection from enemies, abundant blessing, and the assurance of dwelling in God's house forever. Because the Lord is his shepherd, David lacks nothing and fears no evil.
Psalm 24: The earth belongs to the Lord and all who dwell in it, for He founded it upon the seas. The psalm asks who may ascend God's holy hill—those with clean hands, pure hearts, who don't trust in idols or swear falsely—and calls for the ancient gates to lift up their heads for the King of glory, the Lord strong and mighty, to come in.
Psalm 25: David lifts up his soul to the Lord, trusting He will not let him be put to shame, and asks God to teach him His paths and guide him in truth. He appeals to God's great mercy and love, asking Him to remember not the sins of his youth, forgive his iniquity though it is great, and turn to him for he is lonely and afflicted.
Psalm 26: David asks the Lord to vindicate him because he has walked in integrity, trusted without wavering, and not sat with the wicked or joined hypocrites. He loves the house where God's glory dwells, declares his innocence, and pledges to walk in integrity, standing on level ground and praising the Lord in the assembly.
Psalm 27: David declares the Lord is his light, salvation, and stronghold—whom shall he fear? One thing he seeks: to dwell in the Lord's house all his days, gazing on His beauty and seeking Him in His temple, for God will hide him in trouble, set him high upon a rock, and though his father and mother forsake him, the Lord will receive him.
Psalm 28: David cries out to his Rock not to be silent, lest he become like those who go down to the pit. He pleads for mercy, asks God not to drag him away with the wicked, and then bursts into praise because the Lord has heard his cry, declaring the Lord is his strength and shield in whom his heart trusts, and asking God to be the shepherd of His people.
Psalm 29: This majestic psalm calls on the mighty to ascribe glory and strength to the Lord whose voice is over the waters, breaking cedars, shaking the desert, stripping forests bare, and making everyone in His temple cry 'Glory!' The Lord sits enthroned over the flood as King forever and gives strength and peace to His people.
Psalm 30: David exalts the Lord for lifting him up and not letting enemies rejoice over him, for God brought him up from the grave and healed him. He describes how God's anger lasts only a moment but His favor lasts a lifetime—weeping may stay for the night but rejoicing comes in the morning—and God turned his wailing into dancing, removed his sackcloth and clothed him with joy.
Psalm 31: David takes refuge in the Lord his rock and fortress, committing his spirit into God's hands (words Jesus would echo on the cross). Though surrounded by enemies spreading slander and making him the object of dread, he trusts in God's unfailing love, knowing God will deliver him from the plots against him, and he encourages others to be strong and take heart, all who hope in the Lord.
Psalm 32: David declares blessed is the one whose transgressions are forgiven and sins covered, contrasting the anguish of unconfessed sin—his bones wasting away, strength sapped—with the joy of confession when God forgave the guilt of his sin. He encourages others to pray to God while He may be found, and to rejoice in the Lord and sing, for many are the woes of the wicked but unfailing love surrounds those who trust in the Lord.
Psalm 33: This psalm calls the righteous to sing joyfully to the Lord and praise Him with instruments, for the word of the Lord is right and true, and He loves righteousness and justice. It celebrates God's creative power—by His word the heavens were made—His sovereignty over nations, and His watchful eye on those who fear Him and hope in His unfailing love to deliver them from death.
Psalm 34: David (pretending to be insane before Abimelek) blesses the Lord at all times and invites others to taste and see that the Lord is good. He teaches that those who seek the Lord lack no good thing, the righteous cry out and the Lord hears and delivers them from all troubles, the Lord is close to the brokenhearted, and rescues His servants who take refuge in Him.
Psalm 35: David calls on the Lord to contend with those contending against him, to take up shield and armor and fight his enemies who seek his life without cause. He asks God to vindicate him against false witnesses and malicious accusers, promising to rejoice in God's salvation and praise Him in the great assembly when He delivers the poor and needy from those who rob them.
Psalm 36: David describes how sin whispers to the wicked in their hearts, flattering them so they cannot detect or hate their sin, and their words are wicked and deceitful. In contrast, God's love reaches to the heavens, His faithfulness to the skies, His righteousness like mighty mountains, and with Him is the fountain of life—in His light we see light.
Psalm 37: This wisdom psalm counsels not to fret over evildoers or envy those who do wrong, for like grass they will soon wither. Instead, trust in the Lord and do good, delight in Him and He will give you your heart's desires, be still before the Lord and wait patiently, for the meek will inherit the land and the righteous will dwell there forever while the wicked will be cut off.
Psalm 38: In this lament, David pleads with God not to rebuke him in anger, for God's arrows have pierced him, his wounds fester because of his sin, he is bowed down and mourns all day, and friends and companions avoid him. He confesses his sin, acknowledges his guilt troubles him, and waits for the Lord his God to answer, for in Him alone is his hope.
Psalm 39: David resolves to watch his ways and keep his tongue from sin, but his anguish grows within him until he must speak, asking God to show him his life's end and how fleeting it is. He acknowledges human life is but a breath, a mere phantom moving about in vain, and pleads with God to hear his prayer and spare him before he departs and is no more.
Psalm 40: David testifies that he waited patiently for the Lord who lifted him from the slimy pit, set his feet on a rock, and put a new song in his mouth. He declares that God doesn't desire sacrifice and offerings but wants obedience—'I desire to do your will, my God'—and though troubles surround him and his sins overtake him, he pleads for God's rescue, declaring 'Yet I am poor and needy; may the Lord think of me.'
Psalm 41: David pronounces a blessing on those who consider the poor, promising the Lord will deliver, protect, and sustain them on their sickbed. He describes how enemies wish him dead and spread malicious gossip, even his close friend has betrayed him, but he appeals to God's mercy to raise him up so he can repay his enemies, confident that God delights in him and will sustain his integrity.
Psalm 42: The psalmist's soul thirsts for God like a deer panting for water, and he weeps day and night while people mock 'Where is your God?' He remembers leading processions to the house of God with shouts of joy, asks why his soul is downcast, and puts his hope in God whom he will yet praise. Deep calls to deep in the roar of waterfalls, and all God's waves sweep over him, yet by day the Lord directs His love and at night His song is with him.
Psalm 43: Continuing the theme of Psalm 42, the psalmist asks God to vindicate him against ungodly people and rescue him from deceitful men. He longs for God to send His light and truth to lead him to the holy mountain and dwelling place where he will worship at God's altar, and again asks why his soul is downcast, resolving to put his hope in God whom he will yet praise.
Psalm 44: This corporate lament recalls how God gave the fathers victory not by their sword but by His right hand and love, yet now God has rejected and humbled them, allowing them to be devoured and scattered among nations. They have not forgotten God or been false to His covenant, yet they face death all day long and are considered as sheep to be slaughtered, and they appeal to God to arise and redeem them because of His unfailing love.
Psalm 45: This royal wedding psalm celebrates the king's majesty, grace, truth, and justice, addressing him with words of praise: 'You are the most excellent of men.' The psalm then addresses the bride, urging her to honor the king and describing her splendor in embroidered garments as she is led to the king, and promises the king will have sons to succeed him and his name will be remembered forever.
Psalm 46: God is our refuge and strength, an ever-present help in trouble, therefore we will not fear though mountains fall into the sea and waters roar. There is a river whose streams make glad the city of God where He dwells, and though nations rage, God's voice melts the earth and breaks the bow, so be still and know that He is God, exalted among nations.
Psalm 47: This enthronement psalm calls all peoples to clap hands and shout to God with cries of joy, for the Lord Most High is awesome, the great King over all the earth who subdues nations. God has ascended amid shouts of joy and trumpet blasts—sing praises to our King, for God reigns over the nations, and the nobles of the peoples assemble as the people of the God of Abraham.
Psalm 48: Great is the Lord in the city of our God, His holy mountain beautiful and lofty, the joy of the whole earth, Mount Zion where God has shown Himself to be its fortress. Kings assembled and marched together against it but were astounded and fled, and within God's temple we meditate on His unfailing love, and He will be our guide even to the end.
Psalm 49: This wisdom psalm addresses rich and poor alike with a riddle: don't fear when people grow rich and their splendor increases, for they cannot take it with them and cannot redeem even themselves from death. People despite their wealth are like beasts that perish, but God will redeem the psalmist's life from the grave and take him to Himself.
Psalm 50: The Mighty One, God the Lord, speaks and summons the earth from sunrise to sunset, appearing in awesome splendor. He rebukes Israel not for their sacrifices but because they recite His laws while hating instruction and casting His words behind them, reminding them that He owns every animal and doesn't need their offerings, and warning the wicked that He will tear them to pieces unless they repent.
Psalm 51: After Nathan confronted David about his sin with Bathsheba, David pleads for God's mercy to blot out his transgressions, wash away his iniquity, and cleanse him from sin, acknowledging he was sinful from birth. He asks God to create a pure heart, restore the joy of salvation, and not cast him from His presence or take the Holy Spirit away, and promises to teach transgressors God's ways, knowing God desires a broken and contrite heart.
Psalm 52: David confronts Doeg the Edomite who boasted of evil and loved destructive words like a sharpened razor, declaring God will bring him to everlasting ruin. In contrast, David is like an olive tree flourishing in the house of God, trusting in God's unfailing love forever and praising Him for what He has done.
Psalm 53: Nearly identical to Psalm 14, this psalm declares the fool says 'There is no God,' and all have turned away doing corrupt deeds with no one who does good. God looks down from heaven finding none who seek Him, and though evildoers devour God's people like bread, they will be overwhelmed with dread when God scatters the bones of those who attack, and salvation will come from Zion.
Psalm 54: When the Ziphites betrayed David's location to Saul, David cried out for God to save him by His name and vindicate him by His might. He asks God to hear his prayer against ruthless attackers who have no regard for God, declares that God is his help and the one who sustains him, and promises to sacrifice a freewill offering and praise God's name.
Psalm 55: David is overwhelmed by his enemies' threats and anguished by a close friend's betrayal, wishing he had wings like a dove to fly away to the desert and find rest. He describes how his companion attacked those at peace with him and violated the covenant, with speech smooth as butter but war in his heart, yet David casts his cares on the Lord who will sustain him and never let the righteous be shaken.
Psalm 56: When the Philistines seized David in Gath, he cried out for mercy as enemies pursued him all day long, but declared that when afraid he would trust in God. He asks what mere mortals can do to him, records his lament in God's scroll, and knows that when he calls, his enemies will turn back, for God is for him and he trusts His word, walking before God in the light of life.
Psalm 57: Hiding in the cave from Saul, David cries for mercy, taking refuge in the shadow of God's wings until disaster passes. Though he is in the midst of lions who are eager to devour him, he praises God whose love reaches to the heavens and faithfulness to the skies, awakening the dawn with music, for God is exalted above the heavens and His glory over all the earth.
Psalm 58: David challenges corrupt rulers who do not speak justly or judge people with equity, for the wicked are estranged from birth and spread their venom like serpents. He calls on God to break their teeth, sweep them away, and let the righteous rejoice when they see vengeance, for surely there is a God who judges the earth.
Psalm 59: When Saul sent men to watch David's house to kill him, David cried out for deliverance from enemies who are fierce like dogs prowling about the city. He describes how they return at evening snarling like dogs while he sings of God's strength and love in the morning, for God is his fortress and refuge in times of trouble.
Psalm 60: After military defeats, David laments that God has rejected and broken them, shaking the land and making the people drink the wine of staggering. Yet he appeals to God to save His people with His right hand, claiming the lands in victory, for with God they will gain the victory—He will trample down their enemies.
Psalm 61: From the ends of the earth David calls to God with a fainting heart, asking to be led to the rock that is higher than he. He longs to dwell in God's tent forever and take refuge in the shelter of His wings, for God has heard his vows and given him the heritage of those who fear His name, and he will ever sing praise to God's name.
Psalm 62: David finds rest in God alone who is his rock, salvation, and fortress—he will not be shaken. He pours out his heart before God, trusting in Him at all times and exhorting people not to trust in extortion, robbery, or riches, for power belongs to God and with Him is unfailing love, and He rewards everyone according to what they have done.
Psalm 63: In the Desert of Judah, David earnestly seeks God as one thirsts for water in a dry and parched land, longing to see His power and glory. His soul clings to God whose right hand upholds him, he will praise God as long as he lives lifting up his hands in His name, for God's love is better than life, and he rejoices in the shadow of God's wings.
Psalm 64: David asks God to hear his voice as he complains and protect his life from enemies who plot evil, sharpen their tongues like swords, and shoot from ambush. But God will shoot them with arrows suddenly striking them down, and all people will proclaim God's works, and the righteous will rejoice in the Lord and take refuge in Him.
Psalm 65: Praise awaits God in Zion where vows will be fulfilled and all people will come because He forgives sin and brings them near. The psalm celebrates God who formed the mountains by His power, stilled the roaring seas, answers prayers with awesome deeds, crowns the year with bounty, and makes the valleys overflow with grain singing and shouting for joy.
Psalm 66: This psalm calls all the earth to shout for joy to God and sing His praise, for He rules forever by His power and turned the sea into dry land for Israel to cross. Come and hear what God has done—He has preserved our lives, tested us like silver, and brought us to a place of abundance, so come to His temple with burnt offerings to fulfill vows made in distress.
Psalm 67: May God be gracious and make His face shine upon us so His ways may be known on earth and His salvation among all nations. May the peoples praise God and the nations be glad, for He judges peoples with equity and guides the nations, and the land yields its harvest as God blesses us and all the ends of the earth fear Him.
Psalm 68: This majestic psalm calls for God to arise and scatter His enemies like smoke driven away, while the righteous rejoice and celebrate. It celebrates God as father to the fatherless, defender of widows, the One who daily bears our burdens, gives power and strength to His people, and rides across the ancient heavens in a mighty procession with tens of thousands of chariots, scattering kings and receiving gifts from people.
Psalm 69: David cries out that floodwaters have engulfed him, he is worn out from crying, and those who hate him without reason outnumber the hairs on his head. He has endured scorn for God's sake, become a stranger to his own family, and been mocked by drunkards while sitting in sackcloth, and he pleads for God's rescue, asking Him to answer out of the goodness of His love and vindicate him.
Psalm 70: David urgently pleads for God to hasten to help him as enemies seek to kill him and desire his ruin. He asks that those who seek his life be put to shame while those who seek God rejoice and be glad, and though poor and needy, he asks God not to delay, for the Lord is his help and deliverer.
Psalm 71: The aging psalmist appeals to his lifelong refuge—God who has been his hope since youth and from whom he has never been separated—asking not to be cast aside in old age or forsaken when strength fails. Though enemies plot against him, he will always have hope and will praise God more and more, declaring His righteousness and salvation all day long even though he doesn't understand them fully.
Psalm 72: This royal psalm prays that the king will judge with righteousness and justice, defend the afflicted, crush the oppressor, and endure as long as the sun. It envisions his rule extending from sea to sea, all kings bowing before him, and he will deliver the needy who cry out and take pity on the weak and needy, and may his name endure forever and all nations be blessed through him.
Psalm 73: Asaph confesses he nearly lost his foothold when he envied the prosperity of the wicked who have no struggles, mock God, and oppress others. But when he entered God's sanctuary, he understood their final destiny—God will set them on slippery ground, cast them down to ruin in a moment, and their wealth will be like a dream that disappears, while Asaph's eternal portion is God alone who guides him and will take him into glory.
Psalm 74: Asaph laments the destruction of God's sanctuary, asking why God has rejected His people forever and allowed enemies to roar in His meeting place, smash the carved paneling, and burn His dwelling. He appeals to God's covenant, pleading with Him to remember how fools mock His name and to rise up and defend His cause, for the clamor of His enemies continues unchecked.
Psalm 75: Asaph gives thanks that God's name is near and tells of His wonderful deeds, for God says He chooses the appointed time and judges with equity. Though the earth and all its people quake, He holds its pillars firm, and He warns the arrogant not to boast, for no one from east or west or desert can exalt themselves—it is God who judges, bringing some down and exalting others.
Psalm 76: God is renowned in Judah and His dwelling is in Zion where He broke the flaming arrows, shields, and swords of war. He is radiant with light, more majestic than mountains rich with game, and when He arose to judge and save the afflicted, even human wrath praises Him, and all surrounding lands bring gifts to the One to be feared.
Psalm 77: Asaph cries aloud to God in distress, his soul refusing to be comforted as he remembers the nights of groaning and questioning whether God has rejected him forever. But then he remembers God's miracles of old, meditates on His works, and recalls how He led His people like a flock through the sea by the hand of Moses and Aaron, displaying His power in the thunder and lightning.
Psalm 78: This lengthy instructional psalm recounts Israel's history so future generations will know God's commands and not be like their forebears—a stubborn and rebellious generation. It tells of God's miraculous works in Egypt, parting the Red Sea, providing manna and quail, yet the people continually tested and rebelled against God, but He chose David to shepherd them with integrity and skillful hands.
Psalm 79: Asaph laments that nations have invaded God's inheritance, defiled His temple, destroyed Jerusalem, and poured out blood like water. He pleads for God not to hold past sins against them but to deliver them quickly for His name's sake, repay their neighbors seven times for their reproach, and then His people will thank Him forever and proclaim His praise from generation to generation.
Psalm 80: Asaph cries out for the Shepherd of Israel to restore His people, make His face shine on them, and they will be saved. He laments that God has broken down the walls of the vine He brought from Egypt, allowing wild boars to ravage it and passersby to pluck its fruit, pleading three times 'Restore us, O God; make your face shine on us, that we may be saved.'
Psalm 81: Asaph calls Israel to sing for joy to God their strength, sound the ram's horn at the New Moon, and remember God's deliverance from Egypt. God laments that His people did not listen or submit to Him, but wandered in stubbornness, yet if they would listen, He would quickly subdue their enemies and feed them with the finest wheat and honey from the rock.
Psalm 82: God presides in the divine council, judging among the gods (rulers/judges) and rebuking them for defending the unjust, showing partiality to the wicked, and not rescuing the weak and needy. He declares they will die like mere mortals and fall like every other ruler, and the psalmist calls on God to rise up and judge the earth, for all nations are His inheritance.
Psalm 83: Asaph pleads with God not to remain silent as nations conspire together to destroy Israel, saying 'Let us destroy them as a nation.' He asks God to deal with them as He dealt with Midian, Sisera, and Jabin at the river Kishon, to make them like tumbleweed and chaff before the wind, and to cover their faces with shame so they will seek God's name.
Psalm 84: The psalmist's soul yearns and faints for the courts of the Lord, envying even the sparrow who finds a home near God's altar. Blessed are those who dwell in God's house, who find strength in Him for the pilgrimage to Zion, and better is one day in His courts than a thousand elsewhere—he would rather be a doorkeeper in God's house than dwell in the tents of the wicked.
Psalm 85: The psalmist recalls how God showed favor to the land, forgave iniquity, and set aside wrath, and he prays for restoration again, asking God to revive His people and show them His love and salvation. He listens for what God will say, confident that His salvation is near and His glory will dwell in the land where love and faithfulness meet together and righteousness and peace kiss each other.
Psalm 86: David pleads with God to hear his prayer, for he is poor and needy, calling all day long for the Lord to preserve his life, show mercy, and grant him joy. He declares there is no one like God among the gods, that all nations will worship Him, and asks God to teach him so he may walk in truth and give him an undivided heart to fear His name.
Psalm 87: God loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob, and glorious things are said of the city of God. God records that Philistia, Tyre, and even distant nations were born in Zion, and all singers and dancers proclaim that all their fountains are in her.
Psalm 88: This is the darkest psalm with no note of hope—Heman cries day and night before God, overwhelmed by troubles, cut off from His care, in darkness like those long dead, and afflicted since youth. He asks why God has rejected and hidden His face, surrounded him with terrors, and taken away companions, leaving darkness as his closest friend.
Psalm 89: Ethan celebrates God's unfailing love and faithfulness, recounting God's covenant with David—that his line will continue forever and his throne endure through all generations. Yet now the psalmist laments that God has rejected and spurned His anointed one, broken his covenant, and exalted his enemies, and he asks how long God will hide Himself and calls on God to remember His covenant promises to David.
Psalm 90: Moses reflects that God has been Israel's dwelling place throughout all generations, existing before the mountains were born or the earth formed, while humans return to dust like grass that sprouts in the morning and withers by evening. He asks God to teach them to number their days that they may gain a heart of wisdom, relent from anger, satisfy them with unfailing love, and establish the work of their hands.
Psalm 91: Whoever dwells in the shelter of the Most High will rest in His shadow, and no harm will overtake them for He will command His angels concerning them to guard them in all their ways. The psalm promises deliverance from pestilence, protection from arrows that fly by day and plagues that stalk in darkness, for God says He will rescue those who love Him, protect those who acknowledge His name, and answer when they call.
Psalm 92: It is good to praise the Lord and proclaim His love in the morning and faithfulness at night with music, for God's works make the psalmist glad and the wicked will be destroyed. The righteous will flourish like a palm tree and cedar of Lebanon, planted in the courts of the Lord, still bearing fruit in old age, proclaiming that the Lord is upright and there is no wickedness in Him.
Psalm 93: The Lord reigns in majesty and armed with strength, and the world is established firm and cannot be moved. Though the seas have lifted up their pounding waves, mightier than the breakers of the sea is the Lord on high, and His statutes stand firm and holiness adorns His house for endless days.
Psalm 94: The psalmist calls on the Lord, the God who avenges, to shine forth and repay the arrogant who crush God's people and murder the weak. He asks how long the wicked will be jubilant, but declares blessed is the one whom God disciplines and teaches from His law, for the Lord will not reject His people and will bring down the wicked.
Psalm 95: Come, let us sing for joy to the Lord and bow down in worship before Him our Maker, for He is our God and we are the people of His pasture, the flock under His care. The psalm warns not to harden hearts as the Israelites did at Meribah and in the wilderness where they tested God despite seeing His works for forty years, so He swore in His anger they would never enter His rest.
Psalm 96: Sing to the Lord a new song, all the earth, for He is great and most worthy of praise, more to be feared than all gods. Declare His glory among the nations, His marvelous deeds among all peoples, for He comes to judge the earth in righteousness and the peoples with equity, and let the heavens rejoice and the earth be glad.
Psalm 97: The Lord reigns and the earth is glad, surrounded by clouds and thick darkness with righteousness and justice as His throne's foundation. Fire goes before Him, His lightning lights up the world, the mountains melt like wax, and the heavens proclaim His righteousness while all who worship images are put to shame and Zion rejoices in His judgments.
Psalm 98: Sing a new song to the Lord who has done marvelous things and made His salvation known to the nations. Shout for joy with harps, trumpets, and ram's horn before the King, let the sea resound and the rivers clap their hands, let the mountains sing together for joy, for the Lord comes to judge the earth with righteousness and equity.
Psalm 99: The Lord reigns and nations tremble—He sits enthroned between the cherubim and the earth shakes. He is great in Zion, exalted over all nations, and they praise His great and awesome name, for He is holy, loves justice, and answered Moses, Aaron, and Samuel when they called on Him, and though He punished their misdeeds, He forgave them.
Psalm 100: This joyful psalm calls all lands to shout for joy to the Lord, worship Him with gladness, and come before Him with joyful songs. Know that the Lord is God—it is He who made us and we are His people, the sheep of His pasture—so enter His gates with thanksgiving and courts with praise, for the Lord is good, His love endures forever, and His faithfulness continues through all generations.
Psalm 101: David vows to sing of God's love and justice and to conduct his affairs with a blameless heart, walking in integrity in his house. He promises to set no vile thing before his eyes, have nothing to do with perversity, and will not know evil, silencing slanderers and getting rid of all who are wicked so only the faithful may dwell with him.
Psalm 102: An afflicted person pours out a lament before the Lord, asking God to hear and not hide His face, for his days vanish like smoke and bones burn like glowing embers. Yet he declares that God is enthroned forever, His renown endures through all generations, and He will arise and have compassion on Zion, for the appointed time has come, and future generations will be created to praise the Lord.
Psalm 103: David calls his soul to praise the Lord and not forget all His benefits—He forgives all sins, heals all diseases, redeems life from the pit, crowns with love and compassion, satisfies desires with good things, and renews youth like the eagle's. The Lord is compassionate, slow to anger, and abounding in love—He does not treat us as our sins deserve, for as high as the heavens are above the earth, so great is His love for those who fear Him.
Psalm 104: This creation psalm celebrates the Lord clothed in splendor and majesty who wraps Himself in light, stretches out the heavens, makes clouds His chariot, and walks on the wings of the wind. It describes God's provision for all creatures—springs gushing in valleys, rain watering mountains, grass for cattle, wine to gladden hearts, oil to make faces shine, and bread to sustain—and all creatures look to Him to give them food at the proper time.
Psalm 105: Give praise to the Lord, call on His name, and remember the wonders He has done—the covenant He made with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob to give them Canaan. The psalm recounts Joseph's journey to Egypt, the plagues God sent through Moses and Aaron, and how He brought Israel out with silver and gold, led them with a cloud by day and fire by night, and gave them the lands of nations.
Psalm 106: Praise the Lord and give thanks for His enduring love, yet remember Israel's repeated rebellion—they forgot God's miracles in Egypt, grumbled in the wilderness, made a golden calf at Horeb, rejected the pleasant land, and followed pagan practices. Though God was angered many times and gave them over to nations, He took note of their distress when they cried out, remembered His covenant, and showed compassion according to His great love.
Psalm 107: Give thanks to the Lord for His enduring love—He gathers the redeemed from east and west, north and south. The psalm describes four groups in distress: wanderers in the desert who cried out and God led to a city; prisoners in darkness whom God freed from chains; fools suffering for their sins whom God healed; sailors in a storm whom God calmed—all should give thanks for His unfailing love and wonderful deeds.
Psalm 108: David's heart is steadfast as he sings and makes music, awakening the dawn to praise God whose love is higher than the heavens. He prays for God to save His people with His right hand, for with God they will gain victory, and God will trample down their enemies, for human help is worthless.
Psalm 109: David cries out against wicked enemies who repay his friendship with accusations, returning evil for good and hatred for his love. He calls for severe judgment on his accuser—a short life, children as beggars, and his name blotted out—asking God to save him according to His love, for he is poor and needy with a pierced heart, and he will greatly praise the Lord who stands at the right hand of the needy to save them.
Psalm 110: The Lord says to David's Lord (the Messiah): 'Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.' The Lord will extend His mighty scepter from Zion and rule in the midst of His enemies, His troops will rally willingly, and He will be a priest forever in the order of Melchizedek, crushing kings on the day of His wrath.
Psalm 111: Praise the Lord with all your heart in the council of the upright for His glorious and majestic works which endure forever. He provides food for those who fear Him, remembers His covenant forever, and His redemption for His people stands firm, for His precepts are trustworthy and the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom.
Psalm 112: Blessed is the one who fears the Lord and delights in His commands, for their children will be mighty and wealth and riches will be in their house. Even in darkness light dawns for the upright who are gracious, compassionate, and righteous, who lend freely and conduct their affairs with justice—they will never be shaken and will have no fear of bad news for their hearts are steadfast, trusting in the Lord.
Psalm 113: Praise the Lord, you servants, from the rising to the setting of the sun, for the Lord is exalted above all nations and His glory above the heavens. Who is like the Lord our God who stoops down to look on the heavens and earth, raising the poor from the dust and seating them with princes, and He settles the childless woman in her home as a happy mother of children.
Psalm 114: When Israel came out of Egypt, Judah became God's sanctuary and Israel His dominion. The sea looked and fled, the Jordan turned back, the mountains leaped like rams, and the hills like lambs at the presence of the Lord who turned the rock into a pool and the hard rock into springs of water.
Psalm 115: Not to us, Lord, but to Your name be the glory because of Your love and faithfulness, for our God is in heaven and does whatever pleases Him. Their idols are silver and gold made by human hands—they have mouths but cannot speak, eyes but cannot see, ears but cannot hear—but the Lord blesses those who fear Him, both small and great.
Psalm 116: The psalmist loves the Lord who heard his cry for mercy when death's anguish and the grave's terrors came upon him. He was brought low and the Lord saved him, delivering his soul from death, eyes from tears, and feet from stumbling, so he will walk before the Lord in the land of the living and fulfill his vows in the presence of all God's people.
Psalm 117: Praise the Lord, all you nations, extol Him, all you peoples, for great is His love toward us and the faithfulness of the Lord endures forever. This is the shortest psalm and the middle chapter of the Bible.
Psalm 118: Give thanks to the Lord for He is good and His love endures forever, for it is better to take refuge in the Lord than to trust in humans or princes. Though surrounded by enemies like bees, the psalmist was pushed back but the Lord helped him, and the stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone—this is the day the Lord has made, let us rejoice and be glad in it.
Psalm 119:1-8: Blessed are those whose ways are blameless, who walk according to the law of the Lord and keep His statutes wholeheartedly. The psalmist commits to obey God's decrees and not be put to shame when considering all His commands.
Psalm 119:9-16: How can young people keep their way pure? By living according to God's word, seeking Him with all their heart. The psalmist has hidden God's word in his heart to keep from sin, delights in His decrees, and will not neglect His word.
Psalm 119:17-24: The psalmist asks God to open his eyes that he may see wonderful things in His law, for he is a stranger on earth who does not hide His commands. God's statutes are his delight and counselors.
Psalm 119:25-32: The psalmist is laid low in the dust and asks God to preserve his life according to His word, to give understanding to meditate on His wonders and strengthen him according to His promises. He will run in the path of God's commands when God sets his heart free.
Psalm 119:33-40: The psalmist asks God to teach him His decrees and give him understanding to keep His law with all his heart. He prays to be directed in the path of God's commands, to turn his heart toward His statutes and not toward selfish gain.
Psalm 119:41-48: May God's unfailing love come to the psalmist according to His promise, so he can answer those who taunt him. He finds hope in God's word, speaks of His statutes before kings without shame, and delights in His commands which he loves.
Psalm 119:49-56: The psalmist asks God to remember His word which has given him hope and comfort in suffering. Though the arrogant mock him, he does not turn from God's law, remembering His ancient laws and finding comfort in them.
Psalm 119:57-64: The psalmist declares the Lord is his portion and he has promised to obey His words. Though the wicked bind him with ropes, he does not forget God's law and rises at midnight to give thanks for His righteous laws, for the earth is filled with God's love.
Psalm 119:65-72: The psalmist testifies that God has dealt well with him according to His word, and though he went astray before being afflicted, now he obeys. The law from God's mouth is more precious than thousands of pieces of silver and gold.
Psalm 119:73-80: God's hands made and formed the psalmist, so he asks for understanding to learn His commands. He knows God's laws are righteous and He afflicted him in faithfulness, asking that God's unfailing love may comfort him and His compassion come so he may live.
Psalm 119:81-88: The psalmist faints with longing for God's salvation, his eyes fail looking for His promise, and he is like a wineskin in the smoke. Though persecutors dig pits for him, he does not forsake God's precepts, asking for life according to God's unfailing love.
Psalm 119:89-96: God's word stands firm in the heavens forever and His faithfulness continues through all generations, for He established the earth and it endures. All things serve Him, and if His law had not been the psalmist's delight, he would have perished in his affliction.
Psalm 119:97-104: Oh, how the psalmist loves God's law—he meditates on it all day long. It makes him wiser than his enemies, gives him more insight than his teachers, and more understanding than the elders because he keeps God's precepts, for His word is sweeter than honey to his mouth.
Psalm 119:105-112: God's word is a lamp for the psalmist's feet and a light on his path. Though he is in constant anguish and his life is in peril, he does not forget God's law, for His statutes are his heritage forever and the joy of his heart.
Psalm 119:113-120: The psalmist hates double-minded people but loves God's law. God is his refuge and shield, and he puts his hope in His word, asking to sustain him that he may live and never put to shame his hope.
Psalm 119:121-128: The psalmist has done what is righteous and pleads for God not to leave him to his oppressors, to treat him according to His love and teach him His decrees. It is time for the Lord to act for His law is being broken, so the psalmist loves God's commands more than gold.
Psalm 119:129-136: God's statutes are wonderful, therefore the psalmist keeps them. The unfolding of His word gives light and understanding, and he longs for God's commands, asking to be turned to His statutes with compassion and streams of tears flow from his eyes because people do not keep His law.
Psalm 119:137-144: The Lord is righteous and His laws are fully trustworthy. Though the psalmist is lowly and despised, he does not forget God's precepts, for His righteousness is everlasting and His law is truth, and understanding God's statutes gives him life.
Psalm 119:145-152: The psalmist calls with all his heart for God to answer and save him that he may keep His statutes. He rises before dawn and cries for help, putting his hope in God's word, and his eyes stay open through the watches of the night that he may meditate on His promises.
Psalm 119:153-160: The psalmist asks God to look on his suffering and deliver him, to defend his cause and redeem him, and to preserve his life according to His promise. He is far from the wicked who do not seek His decrees, but all God's words are true and His righteous laws are eternal.
Psalm 119:161-168: Rulers persecute the psalmist without cause, but his heart trembles at God's word. He rejoices in His promise like one who finds great spoil, loves His law and praises Him seven times a day, and great peace have those who love His law—nothing can make them stumble.
Psalm 119:169-176: May the psalmist's cry come before God and may he understand according to His word. His lips will overflow with praise because God teaches him His decrees, and his tongue will sing of His word for all His commands are righteous, yet he has strayed like a lost sheep—may God seek His servant who has not forgotten His commands.
Psalm 120: In distress the psalmist cries to the Lord for deliverance from lying lips and deceitful tongues. He asks what will be done to the deceitful tongue, and laments that he dwells among those who hate peace—when he speaks of peace, they are for war.
Psalm 121: This pilgrimage psalm declares that help comes from the Lord, Maker of heaven and earth, who will not let your foot slip and watches over you. The Lord is your keeper who shades you at your right hand, the sun will not harm you by day nor the moon by night, and the Lord will watch over your coming and going both now and forevermore.
Psalm 122: The psalmist rejoices when people say 'Let us go to the house of the Lord,' for Jerusalem is built as a city closely united where the tribes go up to praise the Lord's name and thrones for judgment stand. He prays for peace within Jerusalem's walls and security within her citadels.
Psalm 123: The psalmist lifts up his eyes to God enthroned in heaven, looking to Him as servants look to their master's hand. He appeals for mercy, for they have endured much contempt from the proud and ridicule from the arrogant.
Psalm 124: If the Lord had not been on Israel's side when people attacked them, they would have swallowed them alive when their anger flared. The flood would have engulfed them and the torrent swept them away, but praise be to the Lord who has not let them be torn by their enemies' teeth—they have escaped like a bird from the fowler's snare.
Psalm 125: Those who trust in the Lord are like Mount Zion which cannot be shaken but endures forever, and as mountains surround Jerusalem, so the Lord surrounds His people both now and forevermore. The scepter of the wicked will not remain over the land, but peace be on Israel.
Psalm 126: When the Lord restored the fortunes of Zion, it was like a dream and mouths were filled with laughter and tongues with songs of joy. The psalmist prays for God to restore their fortunes again like streams in the Negev, for those who sow with tears will reap with songs of joy, and those who go out weeping carrying seed will return with songs of joy carrying sheaves.
Psalm 127: Unless the Lord builds the house, the builders labor in vain, and unless the Lord watches over the city, the guards stand watch in vain. It is vain to rise early and stay up late toiling for food, for God grants sleep to those He loves, and children are a heritage from the Lord—blessed is the man whose quiver is full of them.
Psalm 128: Blessed are all who fear the Lord and walk in obedience to Him, for they will eat the fruit of their labor, their wife will be like a fruitful vine and children like olive shoots around the table. Thus is the one blessed who fears the Lord, and may you see the prosperity of Jerusalem all the days of your life.
Psalm 129: Israel testifies that they have been greatly oppressed from youth, yet they have not prevailed against them. Though plowmen plowed on Israel's back making long furrows, the Lord has cut them free from the cords of the wicked, and may all who hate Zion be turned back in shame.
Psalm 130: Out of the depths the psalmist cries to the Lord, asking Him to hear his voice and listen to his cry for mercy. If the Lord kept a record of sins, who could stand? But with Him is forgiveness, therefore He is feared, and the psalmist waits for the Lord more than watchmen wait for the morning, for with the Lord is unfailing love and full redemption.
Psalm 131: David's heart is not proud and his eyes are not haughty—he does not concern himself with great matters or things too wonderful for him. But he has calmed and quieted himself like a weaned child with its mother, and Israel should put their hope in the Lord both now and forevermore.
Psalm 132: Remember David's hardships, how he swore not to rest until he found a dwelling place for the Mighty One of Jacob. The Lord swore to David that He would place one of his descendants on his throne forever, for the Lord has chosen Zion desiring it for His dwelling, saying 'Here I will sit enthroned, for I have desired it.'
Psalm 133: How good and pleasant it is when God's people live together in unity! It is like precious oil running down Aaron's beard and robes, like dew of Hermon falling on Mount Zion, for there the Lord bestows His blessing—life forevermore.
Psalm 134: Praise the Lord, all you servants who minister by night in the house of the Lord. Lift up your hands in the sanctuary and praise the Lord, and may the Lord who made heaven and earth bless you from Zion.
Psalm 135: Praise the Lord's name for it is good to sing praises to Him who has chosen Jacob and Israel as His treasured possession. The Lord does whatever pleases Him in heaven and earth, and He struck down firstborn of Egypt, sent signs and wonders, and struck down many nations to give their land as an inheritance to Israel, but the idols of the nations are silver and gold with mouths that cannot speak.
Psalm 136: Give thanks to the Lord for His love endures forever—this refrain appears in all 26 verses celebrating God who alone does great wonders, made the heavens and earth, divided the Red Sea, led Israel through the wilderness, struck down great kings, and gave their land as an inheritance. He remembers us in our low estate and frees us from our enemies.
Psalm 137: By the rivers of Babylon the exiles sat and wept when they remembered Zion, hanging their harps on the willows when captors demanded songs. How could they sing the Lord's song in a foreign land? If they forget Jerusalem, may their right hand forget its skill, and if they do not remember it, may their tongue cling to the roof of their mouth.
Psalm 138: David praises God with all his heart, bowing toward His holy temple and giving thanks for His unfailing love and faithfulness. Though the Lord is exalted, He looks kindly on the lowly and though David walks in trouble, God preserves his life and stretches out His hand against his enemies, for the Lord will vindicate him and His love endures forever.
Psalm 139: David marvels that God has searched him and knows him completely—when he sits, rises, and his thoughts from afar. Where can he flee from God's presence? Even in the darkness God sees, for the darkness is as light to Him, and he was fearfully and wonderfully made in his mother's womb where God saw his unformed body and ordained all his days before one of them came to be.
Psalm 140: David cries out for rescue from evil people who devise violence, make their tongues sharp as serpents, and plan to trip his feet. He asks God to keep the wicked from their desires, let burning coals fall on them, and uphold the cause of the poor and needy, for the righteous will surely give thanks and the upright will live in His presence.
Psalm 141: David calls to the Lord urgently, asking Him to accept his prayer as incense and the lifting of his hands as the evening sacrifice. He prays for God to set a guard over his mouth, keep him from being drawn to evil deeds, and let the righteous strike him in kindness rather than let his head be anointed with the oil of the wicked.
Psalm 142: In the cave David pours out his complaint, telling of his trouble to the Lord, for when his spirit grows faint, God knows his way. He cries to the Lord as his refuge and portion in the land of the living, asking God to listen to his cry for he is in desperate need, to free him from prison that he may praise God's name.
Psalm 143: David pleads for the Lord to hear his prayer in His faithfulness and righteousness, not to bring judgment on His servant, for the enemy pursues and crushes him to the ground making him dwell in darkness. He remembers the days of long ago, meditates on God's works, spreads out his hands to Him like a parched land thirsting for water, asking God to teach him to do His will.
Psalm 144: David praises the Lord his Rock who trains his hands for war and fingers for battle, and he marvels that God cares about mere mortals. He asks God to part the heavens and come down, scatter His enemies with arrows of lightning, and reach down from on high to deliver him, that their sons may be like plants and daughters like pillars, their barns full and sheep numbering in the thousands.
Psalm 145: David exalts God the King, declaring he will praise His name forever, for the Lord is great and greatly to be praised. One generation commends His works to another, speaking of His glorious splendor, mighty acts, and awesome works, for the Lord is gracious, compassionate, slow to anger, and rich in love to all He has made, and the Lord is near to all who call on Him in truth.
Psalm 146: Praise the Lord, O my soul, for blessed is the one whose help is the God of Jacob, the Maker of heaven and earth who remains faithful forever. He upholds the cause of the oppressed, gives food to the hungry, sets prisoners free, gives sight to the blind, lifts up those bowed down, watches over the foreigner, and sustains the fatherless and widow, but He frustrates the ways of the wicked.
Psalm 147: Praise the Lord who rebuilds Jerusalem, gathers Israel's exiles, heals the brokenhearted, and binds up their wounds. He determines the number of stars and calls them each by name, yet He delights in those who fear Him and put their hope in His unfailing love, and He sends His word to the earth and His commands run swiftly.
Psalm 148: Praise the Lord from the heavens and heights, all His angels and heavenly hosts, sun and moon and shining stars, for He commanded and they were created. Praise Him from the earth, sea creatures and ocean depths, lightning and hail, mountains and hills, fruit trees and cedars, wild animals and cattle, kings and nations, for His splendor is above earth and heaven.
Psalm 149: Sing to the Lord a new song and praise in the assembly of the faithful, for the Lord takes delight in His people and crowns the humble with victory. Let them rejoice in His glory and sing for joy on their beds with a double-edged sword in their hands to inflict vengeance on the nations and bind their kings with chains.
Psalm 150: Praise the Lord in His sanctuary and mighty heavens for His acts of power and surpassing greatness. Praise Him with trumpet, harp, lyre, tambourine, dancing, strings, pipe, and resounding cymbals—let everything that has breath praise the Lord!
Proverbs 1: Solomon begins with the purpose of proverbs—to gain wisdom, instruction, and understanding for living skillfully. The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, and he warns his son to avoid the enticement of sinners who lurk to ambush the innocent, for wisdom calls aloud in the streets warning that those who reject her will eat the fruit of their ways.
Proverbs 2: If you accept wisdom and store up commands, turning your ear to wisdom and searching for it like silver, then you will understand the fear of the Lord and find the knowledge of God. Wisdom will save you from the ways of wicked men and the adulterous woman, and you will walk in the ways of the good and keep to the paths of the righteous.
Proverbs 3: Do not forget wisdom's teaching but keep commands in your heart, for they will prolong your life many years. Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to Him and He will make your paths straight, and blessed is the one who finds wisdom, for she is more precious than rubies.
Proverbs 4: Solomon recalls how his father taught him to get wisdom above all else, to guard his heart for it is the wellspring of life, and to keep his eyes straight ahead on the path of the righteous that shines ever brighter. He warns to avoid the path of the wicked which is like deep darkness where they stumble and don't know what makes them fall.
Proverbs 5: Solomon warns against the seductive words of the adulteress whose lips drip honey but end in bitterness, leading down to death. Instead, rejoice in the wife of your youth, be captivated by her love, and drink water from your own cistern, for a man's ways are in full view of the Lord who weighs all his paths.
Proverbs 6: Warning against becoming surety for another's debt, Solomon describes the sluggard who should learn from the ant's diligence. He lists seven things the Lord hates including haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood, and vividly warns that adultery will cost a man everything—jealousy arouses a husband's fury and he will show no mercy.
Proverbs 7: Solomon describes watching a young man void of understanding follow an adulteress like an ox going to slaughter, not knowing it will cost him his life. He urges his son to keep his commands and bind them on his fingers, for her house is the highway to the grave, leading down to the chambers of death.
Proverbs 8: Wisdom calls out from the highest points, offering prudence, knowledge, and sound judgment, for her instruction is more valuable than silver and gold. She was there when God established the heavens, marked out the foundations of the earth, and whoever finds her finds life and receives favor from the Lord, but those who fail to find her harm themselves.
Proverbs 9: Wisdom has built her house with seven pillars and prepared a feast, sending out invitations to the simple to leave their ways and gain understanding. In contrast, the woman Folly sits at the door of her house calling to passersby, offering stolen water and food eaten in secret, but her guests don't know that the dead are there and her guests are in the depths of the grave.
Proverbs 10: A wise son brings joy to his father but a foolish son brings grief to his mother. The tongue of the righteous is choice silver while the heart of the wicked is of little value, hatred stirs up conflict but love covers over all wrongs, and the mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
Proverbs 11: The Lord detests dishonest scales but delights in accurate weights. When pride comes, disgrace follows, but with humility comes wisdom, and the righteousness of the upright delivers them while the unfaithful are trapped by evil desires. Whoever is kind to the poor lends to the Lord, and a generous person will prosper while whoever refreshes others will be refreshed.
Proverbs 12: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge but whoever hates correction is stupid. The Lord detects lying lips but delights in people who are trustworthy, and the words of the reckless pierce like swords but the tongue of the wise brings healing. Truthful lips endure forever but a lying tongue lasts only a moment.
Proverbs 13: A wise son heeds his father's instruction but a mocker does not respond to rebukes. Walk with the wise and become wise, but a companion of fools suffers harm, and whoever spares the rod hates their children but the one who loves them is careful to discipline. The righteous eat to their heart's content but the stomach of the wicked goes hungry.
Proverbs 14: The wise woman builds her house but the foolish one tears it down with her own hands. Where there are no oxen, the manger is empty, but from the strength of an ox come abundant harvests, and there is a way that appears right to a man but in the end it leads to death. A patient person has great understanding but one who is quick-tempered displays folly.
Proverbs 15: A gentle answer turns away wrath but a harsh word stirs up anger. The tongue of the wise adorns knowledge but the mouth of the fool gushes folly, and the eyes of the Lord are everywhere keeping watch on the wicked and the good. Better a small serving of vegetables with love than a fattened calf with hatred, and a person's wisdom yields patience and it is to one's glory to overlook an offense.
Proverbs 16: To humans belong the plans of the heart but from the Lord comes the proper answer of the tongue. Commit to the Lord whatever you do and He will establish your plans, and the fear of the Lord is the fountain of life turning a person from the snares of death. Better a little with righteousness than much gain with injustice, and gray hair is a crown of splendor attained in the way of righteousness.
Proverbs 17: Better a dry crust with peace and quiet than a house full of feasting with strife. A friend loves at all times and a brother is born for a time of adversity, and whoever mocks the poor shows contempt for their Maker. Children's children are a crown to the aged and parents are the pride of their children, and a cheerful heart is good medicine but a crushed spirit dries up the bones.
Proverbs 18: An unfriendly person pursues selfish ends and against all sound judgment starts quarrels. The tongue has the power of life and death and those who love it will eat its fruit, and he who finds a wife finds what is good and receives favor from the Lord. The name of the Lord is a fortified tower where the righteous run to it and are safe.
Proverbs 19: Better the poor whose walk is blameless than a fool whose lips are perverse. A hot-tempered person must pay the penalty, for if you rescue them you will have to do it again, and whoever is kind to the poor lends to the Lord and He will reward them for what they have done. Many are the plans in a person's heart but it is the Lord's purpose that prevails.
Proverbs 20: Wine is a mocker and beer a brawler, and whoever is led astray by them is not wise. It is to one's honor to avoid strife but every fool is quick to quarrel, and even small children are known by their actions and whether their conduct is pure and right. The glory of young men is their strength and gray hair the splendor of the old.
Proverbs 21: In the Lord's hand the king's heart is a stream of water that He channels toward all who please Him. A person may think their own ways are right but the Lord weighs the heart, and to do what is right and just is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice. The horse is made ready for the day of battle but victory rests with the Lord.
Proverbs 22: A good name is more desirable than great riches and to be esteemed is better than silver or gold. The rich rule over the poor and the borrower is slave to the lender, and start children off on the way they should go and even when old they will not turn from it. Do not exploit the poor because they are poor or crush the needy in court, for the Lord will take up their case.
Proverbs 23: When you sit to dine with a ruler, note well what is before you and put a knife to your throat if you are given to gluttony. Do not wear yourself out to get rich but have the wisdom to show restraint, and do not move an ancient boundary stone or encroach on the fields of the fatherless. Apply your heart to instruction and your ears to words of knowledge.
Proverbs 24: Do not envy the wicked or desire their company, for their hearts plot violence and their lips talk about making trouble. By wisdom a house is built and through understanding it is established, and through knowledge its rooms are filled with rare and beautiful treasures. If you faint in the day of trouble, how small is your strength!
Proverbs 25: These are more proverbs of Solomon compiled by Hezekiah's men. Like apples of gold in settings of silver is a ruling rightly given, and like a snow-cooled drink at harvest time is a trustworthy messenger. If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat and if thirsty give him water to drink, for you will heap burning coals on his head and the Lord will reward you.
Proverbs 26: Like snow in summer or rain in harvest, honor is not fitting for a fool. Do not answer a fool according to his folly or you will be like him yourself, but answer a fool according to his folly or he will be wise in his own eyes. Like a maniac shooting flaming arrows of death is one who deceives their neighbor and says 'I was only joking!'
Proverbs 27: Do not boast about tomorrow for you do not know what a day may bring. Let someone else praise you and not your own mouth, and wounds from a friend can be trusted but an enemy multiplies kisses. As iron sharpens iron, so one person sharpens another, and whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and whoever protects their master will be honored.
Proverbs 28: The wicked flee though no one pursues but the righteous are as bold as a lion. When the righteous thrive, the people rejoice, but when the wicked rule, the people groan, and whoever conceals their sins does not prosper but whoever confesses and renounces them finds mercy. Whoever increases wealth by taking interest or profit from the poor amasses it for another who will be kind to the poor.
Proverbs 29: Whoever remains stiff-necked after many rebukes will suddenly be destroyed without remedy. When the righteous thrive the people rejoice, but when the wicked rule the people groan, and discipline your children and they will give you peace and bring you the delights you desire. Where there is no revelation people cast off restraint, but blessed is the one who heeds wisdom's instruction.
Proverbs 30: Agur son of Jakeh declares that every word of God is flawless and He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him. He asks God not to give him poverty or riches but only his daily bread, lest he become full and deny God or become poor and steal, dishonoring God's name. He describes four things that are never satisfied and four things that are small yet extremely wise.
Proverbs 31: King Lemuel's mother teaches him not to spend his strength on women or vigor on those who ruin kings, but to speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves and defend the rights of the poor and needy. The chapter ends with the famous description of the wife of noble character who is worth far more than rubies—she brings her husband good, works with eager hands, provides for her family, extends her hands to the poor, and her children call her blessed.
Ecclesiastes 1: The Teacher declares 'Meaningless! Meaningless! Everything is meaningless!' as generations come and go but the earth remains forever. All things are wearisome and there is nothing new under the sun, and the Teacher devoted himself to study and explore by wisdom all that is done under the heavens—what a heavy burden God has laid on mankind! For with much wisdom comes much sorrow and the more knowledge, the more grief.
Ecclesiastes 2: The Teacher tested pleasure, laughter, wine, and great projects—building houses, planting vineyards and gardens, acquiring servants and possessions—amassing silver and gold and becoming greater than anyone before in Jerusalem. Yet when he surveyed all his hands had done, everything was meaningless, a chasing after the wind, and the wise and the fool both share the same fate, so he hated life and all his toil under the sun.
Ecclesiastes 3: There is a time for everything and a season for every activity under the heavens—a time to be born and to die, to plant and uproot, to kill and heal, to tear down and build, to weep and laugh, to mourn and dance. God has made everything beautiful in its time and set eternity in the human heart, yet people cannot fathom what God has done from beginning to end.
Ecclesiastes 4: The Teacher observed the oppression under the sun and saw the tears of the oppressed with no comforter, and considered that the dead are better off than the living and better than both is the one who has never been born. He saw that all toil springs from rivalry, and two are better than one for if either falls down, one can help the other up, and a cord of three strands is not quickly broken.
Ecclesiastes 5: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God and go near to listen rather than offer the sacrifice of fools who do not know they do wrong. Do not be quick with your mouth or hasty in your heart to utter anything before God, and when you make a vow to God, do not delay to fulfill it. Whoever loves money never has enough, and as goods increase so do those who consume them, and what benefit are they to the owners except to feast their eyes on them?
Ecclesiastes 6: The Teacher observed an evil: a person to whom God gives wealth and possessions and honor but does not grant the ability to enjoy them—a stranger enjoys them instead, which is meaningless and a grievous evil. Even if a person lives a thousand years twice over but fails to enjoy prosperity, do not all go to the same place? All human toil is for the mouth yet the appetite is never satisfied.
Ecclesiastes 7: A good name is better than fine perfume and the day of death better than the day of birth. It is better to go to a house of mourning than to a house of feasting, and sorrow is better than laughter because a sad face is good for the heart. Do not be over-righteous or over-wise, and do not be over-wicked or a fool—why die before your time? Wisdom makes one wise person more powerful than ten rulers in a city.
Ecclesiastes 8: Who is like the wise? Who knows the explanation of things? A person's wisdom brightens their face and changes its hard appearance. Obey the king's command because you took an oath before God, and although the wicked may live long, it will not go well with them because they do not fear God, yet this too is meaningless—the righteous get what the wicked deserve and the wicked get what the righteous deserve.
Ecclesiastes 9: The same destiny overtakes all—the righteous and the wicked, the good and the bad, the clean and the unclean, and no one knows when their hour will come. Go, eat your food with gladness and drink your wine with a joyful heart, for God has already approved what you do, and enjoy life with your wife whom you love all the days of your meaningless life, for that is your lot in life and in your toilsome labor under the sun.
Ecclesiastes 10: As dead flies give perfume a bad smell, so a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor. The heart of the wise inclines to the right but the heart of the fool to the left, and even as fools walk along the road they lack sense and show everyone how stupid they are. If a snake bites before it is charmed, the charmer receives no fee, and words from the mouth of the wise are gracious but fools are consumed by their own lips.
Ecclesiastes 11: Ship your grain across the sea and after many days you may receive a return. Whoever watches the wind will not plant and whoever looks at the clouds will not reap, so sow your seed in the morning and at evening let your hands not be idle. Light is sweet and it pleases the eyes to see the sun, so if people live many years let them rejoice in them all, but remember the days of darkness will be many.
Ecclesiastes 12: Remember your Creator in the days of your youth before the days of trouble come and years approach when you will say 'I find no pleasure in them,' before the silver cord is severed and the golden bowl is broken. Fear God and keep His commandments, for this is the duty of all mankind, for God will bring every deed into judgment including every hidden thing whether good or evil.
Song of Solomon 1: The bride longs for her beloved's kisses which are more delightful than wine, and though her skin is darkened by the sun, she is lovely like the tents of Kedar. She asks where he grazes his flock at midday, and he tells her she is the most beautiful among women, comparing her to a mare among Pharaoh's chariot horses and praising her cheeks and neck adorned with jewels.
Song of Solomon 2: The beloved is like a rose of Sharon and lily of the valleys, and she sits in his shade with great delight, his banner over her being love. She charges the daughters of Jerusalem not to arouse or awaken love until it so desires, and her beloved is like a young stag leaping across the mountains, calling her to arise and come away, for winter is past and flowers appear on the earth.
Song of Solomon 3: All night long the bride searches for the one her heart loves, going through the streets seeking him until she finds him and brings him to her mother's house. She charges the daughters not to arouse love until it so desires, and describes her beloved coming from the wilderness like a column of smoke in a royal wedding procession, his carriage crafted by King Solomon with sixty warriors attending it.
Song of Solomon 4: The groom declares his bride is altogether beautiful with no flaw in her, praising her eyes as doves, her hair like a flock of goats, teeth like newly shorn sheep, lips like scarlet ribbon, and temples like halves of a pomegranate. She is a garden locked up, a spring enclosed, a sealed fountain, and he calls for the north and south winds to blow on his garden that its fragrance may spread.
Song of Solomon 5: The groom has come into his garden and gathered myrrh and spices, but when the bride opens the door, her beloved has turned away. She searches for him through the city where the watchmen beat her, and the daughters ask what is so special about her beloved—she describes his head as finest gold, his body like polished ivory, his legs like pillars of marble, and he is altogether lovely.
Song of Solomon 6: The daughters ask where the beloved has gone, and the bride says he has gone down to his garden. Her beloved declares she is beautiful as Timnah, lovely as Jerusalem, majestic as troops with banners, and sixty queens and eighty concubines cannot compare to her—she is his perfect one, the only daughter of her mother, and the queens and concubines praise her.
Song of Solomon 7: The beloved praises his bride's feet in sandals, her graceful legs, navel like a rounded goblet never lacking blended wine, waist like a mound of wheat, breasts like fawns, neck like an ivory tower, and head crowning her like Mount Carmel. She invites him to go to the vineyards early in the morning to see if the vines have budded and pomegranates are in bloom, where she will give him her love.
Song of Solomon 8: The bride wishes her beloved were like a brother so she could kiss him in public without contempt, and she asks to be placed like a seal over his heart, for love is as strong as death and its jealousy as unyielding as the grave. Many waters cannot quench love nor rivers sweep it away, and if one were to give all their wealth for love, it would be utterly scorned.
Isaiah 1: Isaiah son of Amoz sees visions concerning Judah and Jerusalem during the reigns of four kings. God laments that the ox knows its master but Israel does not know Him—the sinful nation is loaded with guilt, rebelling children who have forsaken the Lord. Though they offer countless sacrifices and prayers, God will not listen because their hands are full of blood—stop doing wrong, learn to do right, seek justice, defend the oppressed, and though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be as white as snow.
Isaiah 2: In the last days the mountain of the Lord's temple will be established as highest of mountains, and all nations will stream to it to be taught God's ways and walk in His paths. He will judge between nations and settle disputes, they will beat swords into plowshares and spears into pruning hooks, and nation will not take up sword against nation nor train for war anymore, so come house of Jacob and walk in the light of the Lord.
Isaiah 3: The Lord is about to take from Jerusalem and Judah both supply and support—food, water, leaders, prophets, and elders—giving boys as their officials and children to rule over them. The people will oppress each other and show no respect for elders, and the Lord declares that the women of Zion are haughty, walking with outstretched necks and flirting eyes, so instead of fragrance there will be a stench and instead of beauty, branding.
Isaiah 4: In that day seven women will take hold of one man saying 'We will eat our own food and provide our own clothes; only let us be called by your name to take away our disgrace.' The Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious, the fruit of the land the pride and glory of Israel's survivors, and God will create over Mount Zion a cloud of smoke by day and a glow of flaming fire by night—a canopy of glory over all.
Isaiah 5: Isaiah sings about his loved one's vineyard that he cultivated but it yielded only bad fruit, so he will take away its hedge and break down its wall. The vineyard of the Lord is Israel whom He looked for justice but saw bloodshed, for righteousness but heard cries of distress. Woe to those who add house to house and field to field, who call evil good and good evil, who are wise in their own eyes, for the Lord's anger burns against His people.
Isaiah 6: In the year King Uzziah died, Isaiah saw the Lord seated on a throne high and exalted with seraphs calling 'Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory.' Isaiah cried out 'Woe to me! I am ruined! For I am a man of unclean lips,' but a seraph touched his lips with a live coal, atoning for his sin, and when the Lord asked 'Whom shall I send?' Isaiah said 'Here am I. Send me!'
Isaiah 7: When Aram and Israel march against Jerusalem, the Lord tells Ahaz through Isaiah not to fear these two smoldering stubs of firewood, and offers him a sign. When Ahaz refuses, Isaiah declares the Lord Himself will give a sign: 'The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and will call him Immanuel' (God with us), yet because of Ahaz's unbelief, Assyria will devastate the land.
Isaiah 8: Isaiah records on a scroll 'Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz' (quick to plunder, swift to spoil) as a sign that Assyria will carry off Damascus and Samaria's wealth before the boy can say 'Father' or 'Mother.' The Lord warns not to call conspiracy everything this people calls conspiracy, but to regard the Lord Almighty as holy, and He will be a stone that causes people to stumble and a trap for Jerusalem's inhabitants.
Isaiah 9: The people walking in darkness have seen a great light, for to us a child is born, to us a son is given, and the government will be on His shoulders, and He will be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace, and His kingdom will have no end. Yet the Lord's anger burns against Israel for their pride and arrogance, and His hand is still upraised to strike.
Isaiah 10: Woe to those who make unjust laws and deprive the poor of their rights, for what will you do on the day of reckoning when disaster comes from afar?
