Though God sends Assyria to punish His people, Assyria's king doesn't intend this but plans to destroy many nations, so when the Lord finishes His work against Mount Zion, He will punish Assyria's arrogant boasting, and a remnant of Israel will truly rely on the Lord.
Isaiah 11: A shoot will come up from the stump of Jesse and a Branch from his roots will bear fruit—the Spirit of the Lord will rest on Him with wisdom, understanding, counsel, might, knowledge, and the fear of the Lord. He will judge righteously, strike the earth with the rod of His mouth, and with the breath of His lips slay the wicked, and the wolf will live with the lamb, the leopard lie down with the goat, for the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the Lord as the waters cover the sea.
Isaiah 12: In that day you will say: 'I will praise you, Lord. Although you were angry with me, your anger has turned away and you have comforted me.' Surely God is my salvation; I will trust and not be afraid, and with joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation. Shout aloud and sing for joy, people of Zion, for great is the Holy One of Israel among you.
Isaiah 13: Isaiah prophesies concerning Babylon: the Lord is mustering an army for war, bringing warriors to carry out His wrath. The day of the Lord is coming—cruel, with wrath and fierce anger—to make the land desolate and destroy its sinners, for the stars will not show their light, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and Babylon, the jewel of kingdoms, will be overthrown by God like Sodom and Gomorrah.
Isaiah 14: The Lord will have compassion on Jacob and settle them in their own land again, and when He gives them relief from suffering, they will take up this taunt against Babylon's king: 'How the oppressor has come to an end!' Isaiah describes the king of Babylon cast down to the realm of the dead, mocked for his fall from heaven like a morning star, and Assyria will be broken in God's land and its yoke lifted from Israel's shoulders.
Isaiah 15: An oracle concerning Moab declares that Ar and Kir are ruined, destroyed in a night. Moab wails over Nebo and Medeba with every head shaved and every beard cut off, wearing sackcloth on the roofs and in the streets, and their hearts cry out over their fugitives who flee to Zoar.
Isaiah 16: Isaiah urges Moab to send lambs as tribute to the ruler in Jerusalem and provide shade and shelter for Judah's fugitives. He prophesies that a throne will be established in love in David's tent—one who judges seeks justice and is swift to do righteousness—but Moab's pride will be brought down, and within three years Moab's splendor will become contempt.
Isaiah 17: An oracle concerning Damascus declares it will cease to be a city and become a heap of ruins, and the glory of Jacob will fade because they forgot the God of their salvation. Though they plant pleasant plants, the harvest will be a heap of ruins in a day of disease and incurable pain, and God will rebuke the nations so they flee far away, chased like chaff before the wind.
Isaiah 18: Woe to the land of whirring wings along the rivers of Cush that sends envoys by sea in papyrus boats—go swift messengers! The Lord says He will look on from His dwelling place quietly, and at harvest time He will cut off the shoots with pruning knives, leaving them for mountain birds and wild animals, and then gifts will be brought to the Lord from this tall and smooth-skinned people.
Isaiah 19: An oracle concerning Egypt: The Lord rides on a swift cloud into Egypt making idols tremble, and He will hand Egyptians over to a harsh master. The Nile will dry up, waters fail, and officials will become fools, but in that day there will be an altar to the Lord in Egypt, and the Lord will strike Egypt with a plague then heal them, and Egypt will be a blessing on the earth.
Isaiah 20: In the year the supreme commander sent by Sargon king of Assyria came to Ashdod and captured it, the Lord said through Isaiah who walked stripped and barefoot for three years as a sign that the king of Assyria will lead away Egypt's captives and Cush's exiles, young and old, stripped and barefoot with bare buttocks—to Egypt's shame—and those who trusted in Cush and boasted in Egypt will be dismayed and put to shame.
Isaiah 21: An oracle concerning the Desert by the Sea: a dire vision has been shown—the traitor betrays and the destroyer destroys. Isaiah is staggered by what he hears, dismayed by what he sees, but a lookout cries 'Babylon has fallen!' and all the images of its gods lie shattered on the ground. An oracle concerning Edom and Arabia follows—disaster comes within a year.
Isaiah 22: An oracle concerning the Valley of Vision: what troubles you that you have gone up on the roofs? Jerusalem is full of commotion with slain not killed by sword or dead in battle, for the Lord has a day of tumult. Isaiah weeps bitterly over the destruction of his people, and though they call for weeping and mourning, instead there is joy and revelry, and God will depose Shebna the steward and call Eliakim His servant to replace him.
Isaiah 23: An oracle concerning Tyre: wail, you ships of Tarshish, for Tyre is destroyed without house or harbor, and the Lord planned it to bring down her pride. Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, but at the end of seventy years she will sing like a prostitute and her earnings will be dedicated to the Lord, providing food and fine clothes for those who dwell before Him.
Isaiah 24: The Lord is going to lay waste the earth and devastate it, scattering its inhabitants—priest and people, master and servant alike. The earth dries up and withers under the curse from its inhabitants who have broken laws and violated the covenant, and though there are joyful shouts from the west and songs from the islands, Isaiah says 'I waste away, I waste away! Woe to me!' for terror and pit and snare await earth's people.
Isaiah 25: Isaiah praises the Lord who has done marvelous things, destroying the fortified city and refuge of ruthless nations, being a refuge for the poor and needy in distress. On this mountain the Lord will prepare a feast of rich food for all peoples, will swallow up death forever, wipe away tears from all faces, and remove His people's disgrace from all the earth, and they will say 'This is our God; we trusted in Him, and He saved us.'
Isaiah 26: In that day this song will be sung in Judah: We have a strong city; God makes salvation its walls and ramparts. Trust in the Lord forever, for He is the Rock eternal who humbles the proud and brings the lofty city down to dust. Your dead will live and their bodies will rise, for your dew is like morning dew, and the earth will give birth to her dead, so go my people, enter your rooms and close doors behind you until His wrath has passed.
Isaiah 27: In that day the Lord with His fierce and large sword will punish Leviathan the gliding serpent, killing the monster of the sea. Sing about the fruitful vineyard—the Lord watches over it, watering it continually, guarding it day and night so no one may harm it, and in days to come Jacob will take root and Israel will bud and blossom, filling all the world with fruit as exiles return when the great trumpet sounds.
Isaiah 28: Woe to the wreath of pride of Ephraim's drunkards and to the fading flower of its glorious beauty on the head of a fertile valley, for the Lord will hurl them down with His hand. Yet Jerusalem also mocks Isaiah's teaching as if for children with meaningless repetition, so God will speak to this people through foreign lips and strange tongues, and He lays a stone in Zion, a tested stone, a precious cornerstone for a sure foundation—the one who relies on it will never be stricken with panic.
Isaiah 29: Woe to Ariel (Jerusalem), the city where David settled—the Lord will besiege you, and you will be brought low speaking from the ground. Yet the ruthless will vanish, the mockers disappear, and those who err in spirit will gain understanding, for the Lord who redeemed Abraham says Jacob will no longer be ashamed when they see their children, the work of His hands, sanctifying His name and standing in awe of the God of Israel.
Isaiah 30: Woe to the obstinate children who carry out plans not from the Lord, going down to Egypt for help without consulting Him, but Pharaoh's protection will be your shame. Yet the Lord longs to be gracious and rises to show compassion—blessed are all who wait for Him—and though He gives you bread of adversity and water of affliction, your Teacher will no longer hide Himself, and whether you turn right or left, your ears will hear a voice saying 'This is the way; walk in it.'
Isaiah 31: Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help, relying on horses and trusting in chariots because they are many, but do not look to the Holy One of Israel or seek help from the Lord. As a lion growls over its prey though a band of shepherds is called together against it, so the Lord Almighty will come down to do battle on Mount Zion, and the Assyrians will fall by a sword not of mortals.
Isaiah 32: A king will reign in righteousness and rulers will rule with justice, and each one will be like a shelter from the wind and a refuge from the storm. The fortress will be abandoned until the Spirit is poured on us from on high, and the desert becomes a fertile field, and justice will dwell in the desert and righteousness in the fertile field, producing peace, quietness, and confidence forever.
Isaiah 33: Woe to you destroyer who have not been destroyed, to you betrayer who have not been betrayed—when you stop destroying you will be destroyed. The Lord is exalted, filling Zion with justice and righteousness, and sinners in Zion are terrified asking 'Who can dwell with the consuming fire?' Those who walk righteously and speak what is right will dwell on heights with bread supplied and water assured, and they will see the King in His beauty and view a land that stretches afar.
Isaiah 34: The Lord is angry with all nations and their armies—He will totally destroy them and give them over to slaughter, for the Lord has a day of vengeance. The streams of Edom will become burning pitch and the land burning sulfur, never to be quenched, lying desolate for generations with desert creatures and night creatures making it their home, for the Lord has written their names in His scroll and allotted their portions.
Isaiah 35: The desert and parched land will be glad, the wilderness will rejoice and blossom like the crocus, for water will gush forth in the wilderness and streams in the desert. A highway called the Way of Holiness will be there—only the redeemed will walk on it—and those the Lord has rescued will return singing with everlasting joy upon their heads, overtaking them with gladness and joy while sorrow and sighing flee away.
Isaiah 36: In the fourteenth year of Hezekiah's reign, Sennacherib king of Assyria attacks Judah's fortified cities and captures them. The Assyrian field commander ridicules Hezekiah's trust in Egypt and the Lord, mocking that God told Assyria to march against Judah and destroy it, and he calls out in Hebrew for the people to hear, warning them not to let Hezekiah deceive them that the Lord will deliver them.
Isaiah 37: When King Hezekiah hears the Assyrian threats, he tears his clothes, puts on sackcloth, and goes into the temple of the Lord, sending word to Isaiah who prophesies that the Lord will make Sennacherib hear a rumor and return home where he will be cut down by the sword. Hezekiah prays earnestly before the Lord, and Isaiah sends word that the virgin daughter of Zion despises and mocks Sennacherib, and that night the angel of the Lord strikes down 185,000 in the Assyrian camp.
Isaiah 38: Hezekiah becomes ill and is at the point of death, and Isaiah tells him to put his house in order. Hezekiah turns his face to the wall and prays bitterly, and before Isaiah leaves the middle court, the word of the Lord comes telling him to return and say the Lord has heard his prayer and seen his tears, and will add fifteen years to his life and deliver Jerusalem from Assyria, and as a sign the shadow will go back ten steps.
Isaiah 39: Envoys from Babylon bring letters and a gift to Hezekiah who shows them all his treasures, storehouses, and armory—there is nothing in his palace or kingdom he does not show them. Isaiah comes and asks what the men saw, and prophesies that the time will come when everything in the palace and all that Hezekiah's ancestors have stored up will be carried off to Babylon, and some of his descendants will be taken away to become eunuchs in the palace of Babylon's king.
Isaiah 40: Comfort, comfort my people, says your God—speak tenderly to Jerusalem and proclaim that her hard service has been completed and her sin paid for. A voice cries 'Prepare the way for the Lord in the wilderness,' and though grass withers and flowers fall, the word of our God endures forever. Why do you say the Lord does not see your way? Do you not know? Have you not heard? He gives strength to the weary and increases the power of the weak, and those who hope in the Lord will renew their strength and soar on wings like eagles.
Isaiah 41: Be silent before Me, you islands—let us meet together at the place of judgment. Who has stirred up one from the east? I, the Lord, am the first and with the last—I am He. Do not fear, for I am with you; do not be dismayed, for I am your God. I will strengthen and help you and uphold you with My righteous right hand, for I am the Lord your God who takes hold of your right hand and says 'Do not fear; I will help you.'
Isaiah 42: Here is My servant whom I uphold, My chosen one in whom I delight—I will put My Spirit on Him and He will bring justice to the nations. He will not shout or cry out or raise His voice in the streets; a bruised reed He will not break and a smoldering wick He will not snuff out. Sing to the Lord a new song, His praise from the ends of the earth, but Israel is blind and deaf, robbed and plundered because of their sin.
Isaiah 43: Now this is what the Lord says—He who created you, O Jacob, He who formed you, O Israel: 'Do not fear, for I have redeemed you; I have summoned you by name; you are Mine.' When you pass through the waters, I will be with you, and when you walk through fire you will not be burned, for I am the Lord your God, the Holy One of Israel, your Savior. Forget the former things; see, I am doing a new thing—now it springs up; do you not perceive it?
Isaiah 44: Now listen, Jacob My servant, Israel whom I have chosen—I will pour water on the thirsty land and streams on the dry ground, I will pour out My Spirit on your offspring and My blessing on your descendants. But those who make idols are nothing, and the things they treasure are worthless—a carpenter measures and marks out wood, fashions it and makes it into the image of a man to dwell in a shrine. Yet I, the Lord, made all things, who says of Jerusalem 'It shall be inhabited' and of Cyrus 'He is My shepherd.'
Isaiah 45: This is what the Lord says to Cyrus, His anointed, whose right hand He takes hold of to subdue nations: I will go before you and level the mountains, breaking down gates of bronze and cutting through bars of iron, so you may know that I am the Lord who summons you by name. I form the light and create darkness, make peace and create calamity—I am the Lord who does all these things. Woe to those who quarrel with their Maker; does the clay say to the potter 'What are you making?'
Isaiah 46: Bel bows down and Nebo stoops low—their idols are borne by beasts of burden, but the Lord has made and will carry Israel, even to old age bearing and rescuing them. To whom will you compare God? Remember this and stand firm; recall the former things of old, for I am God and there is no other, declaring the end from the beginning, and My purpose will stand and I will do all that I please.
Isaiah 47: Go down, sit in the dust, Virgin Daughter Babylon, sit on the ground without a throne, Daughter of the Babylonians—no more will you be called tender or delicate. Your nakedness will be exposed and your shame uncovered; I will take vengeance and will spare no one. You felt secure in your wickedness saying 'No one sees me,' but disaster will come upon you suddenly, and your many sorceries and potent spells cannot save you.
Isaiah 48: Listen to this, house of Jacob who are called by the name of Israel—I foretold the former things long ago then suddenly acted and they came to pass, for I knew you were stubborn with a neck of iron and forehead of bronze. For My own sake, for My own sake I do this, and I will not yield My glory to another. Leave Babylon, flee from the Babylonians with shouts of joy, proclaiming to the ends of the earth 'The Lord has redeemed His servant Jacob.'
Isaiah 49: Listen to Me, you islands; the Lord called Me from the womb, from My mother's body He has spoken My name. Though Israel is not gathered, I will be glorious in the eyes of the Lord, for He says 'I will also make you a light for the Gentiles, that My salvation may reach to the ends of the earth.' Can a mother forget the baby at her breast? Though she may forget, I will not forget you—see, I have engraved you on the palms of My hands.
Isaiah 50: Where is your mother's certificate of divorce with which I sent her away? You were sold because of your sins, and your mother was sent away because of your transgressions. The Sovereign Lord has given Me a well-instructed tongue to sustain the weary with a word, and He wakens My ear to listen like one being instructed. I offered My back to those who beat Me, My cheeks to those who pulled out My beard, and did not hide My face from mocking and spitting, but the Lord helps Me, so I set My face like flint.
Isaiah 51: Listen to Me, you who pursue righteousness and who seek the Lord: Look to the rock from which you were cut and to Abraham your father and Sarah who gave you birth. Awake, awake, arm of the Lord! The ransomed of the Lord will return and enter Zion with singing, everlasting joy upon their heads. I am He who comforts you; who are you that you fear mere mortals who are but grass?
Isaiah 52: Awake, awake, Zion, clothe yourself with strength! Shake off your dust, rise up and sit enthroned, Jerusalem, for you were sold for nothing and without money you will be redeemed. How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of those who bring good news, who proclaim peace and salvation, saying to Zion 'Your God reigns!' My servant will act wisely and be raised and lifted up and highly exalted, yet His appearance was so disfigured beyond that of any human being.
Isaiah 53: Who has believed our message? He grew up like a tender shoot and like a root out of dry ground—He had no beauty that we should desire Him, despised and rejected, a man of suffering familiar with pain. But He was pierced for our transgressions, crushed for our iniquities, the punishment that brought us peace was on Him, and by His wounds we are healed. The Lord laid on Him the iniquity of us all, yet after suffering He will see the light of life and be satisfied, justifying many as He bears their iniquities.
Isaiah 54: Sing, barren woman, you who never bore a child, for more are the children of the desolate woman than of her who has a husband. Enlarge the place of your tent and do not hold back, for you will spread out to the right and to the left. Though the mountains be shaken and hills be removed, yet My unfailing love for you will not be shaken, says the Lord who has compassion on you, and all your children will be taught by the Lord.
Isaiah 55: Come, all you who are thirsty, come to the waters, and you who have no money, come buy and eat without money and without cost. Why spend money on what is not bread? Listen, listen to Me, and eat what is good, and you will delight in the richest of fare. Seek the Lord while He may be found; let the wicked forsake their ways and return to the Lord who will freely pardon, for His thoughts are not our thoughts and His ways higher than our ways, and His word will not return empty but will accomplish what He desires.
Isaiah 56: Maintain justice and do what is right, for My salvation is close at hand. Blessed is the one who does this, keeping the Sabbath and keeping their hands from doing evil. Let no foreigner who is bound to the Lord say 'The Lord will surely exclude me,' and let no eunuch complain, for their house will be called a house of prayer for all nations. But Israel's watchmen are blind, they all lack knowledge, they are shepherds who lack understanding, each pursues their own gain.
Isaiah 57: The righteous perish and no one takes it to heart—they are taken away to be spared from evil, entering into peace. But you who practice sorcery and adultery, you offspring of liars and prostitutes, to whom are you mocking? You have made your bed on a high and lofty hill and went up there to offer sacrifices. For this is what the high and exalted One says—I live in a high and holy place, but also with the one who is contrite and lowly in spirit, to revive the spirit of the lowly and the heart of the contrite.
Isaiah 58: Shout it aloud, declare to My people their rebellion—they seek Me daily and delight to know My ways, yet on the day of fasting they do as they please and exploit workers. Is this the kind of fast I have chosen? Is not this the kind I have chosen: to loose the chains of injustice, share your food with the hungry, provide shelter for the poor wanderer, and clothe the naked? Then your light will break forth like the dawn and your healing will quickly appear, and you will call and the Lord will answer.
Isaiah 59: Surely the arm of the Lord is not too short to save, nor His ear too dull to hear, but your iniquities have separated you from your God and your sins have hidden His face. So justice is far from us and righteousness does not reach us; we look for light but all is darkness. The Lord looked and was displeased that there was no justice, so His own arm achieved salvation and His own righteousness sustained Him, and the Redeemer will come to Zion.
Isaiah 60: Arise, shine, for your light has come, and the glory of the Lord rises upon you. Nations will come to your light and kings to the brightness of your dawn, and all assemble and come to you—your sons from afar and daughters carried on the hip. Then you will look and be radiant, your heart will throb and swell with joy, for the wealth on the seas will be brought to you, and you will know that I, the Lord, am your Savior.
Isaiah 61: The Spirit of the Sovereign Lord is on Me, because the Lord has anointed Me to proclaim good news to the poor, to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim freedom for the captives and release from darkness for prisoners, to comfort all who mourn and provide for those who grieve in Zion—bestowing on them a crown of beauty instead of ashes, the oil of joy instead of mourning, and a garment of praise instead of despair. Instead of shame you will receive a double portion, and everlasting joy will be yours.
Isaiah 62: For Zion's sake I will not keep silent until her vindication shines out like the dawn and her salvation like a blazing torch. You will be called by a new name that the mouth of the Lord will bestow—no longer will you be called Deserted or Desolate, but you will be called Hephzibah (My delight is in her) and your land Beulah (Married), for the Lord will take delight in you and your land will be married. See, your Savior comes!
Isaiah 63: Who is this coming from Edom with garments stained crimson from Bozrah? It is I, the Lord, proclaiming victory, mighty to save, who has trodden the winepress alone, and the blood of My enemies has stained all My clothing. Look down from heaven and see—where are Your zeal and Your mighty acts? You are our Father; we are the clay, You are the potter, we are all the work of Your hand.
Isaiah 64: Oh, that You would rend the heavens and come down, that the mountains would tremble before You! When You did awesome things we did not expect, You came down and the mountains trembled. Since ancient times no one has heard, no ear has perceived, no eye has seen any God besides You who acts on behalf of those who wait for Him. Yet You come to the help of those who gladly do right, who remember Your ways.
Isaiah 65: I revealed Myself to those who did not ask for Me and was found by those who did not seek Me, but all day long I have held out My hands to a disobedient and obstinate people. See, I will create new heavens and a new earth, and the former things will not be remembered. I will create Jerusalem to be a delight and her people a joy—the sound of weeping and crying will be heard in her no more, for before they call I will answer.
Isaiah 66: Heaven is My throne and the earth is My footstool—where is the house you will build for Me? This is the one I esteem: those who are humble and contrite in spirit and tremble at My word. As a mother comforts her child, so will I comfort you, and you will be comforted over Jerusalem. For the Lord will come with fire to bring down His rebuke with flames, yet those who consecrate themselves will come to an end together. I will set a sign among them and send survivors to the nations, and they will proclaim My glory among the nations, and all mankind will come and bow down before Me.
Jeremiah 1: The word of the Lord comes to Jeremiah son of Hilkiah during the reign of Josiah, and God tells him that before he was formed in the womb, He knew him and set him apart as a prophet to the nations. Jeremiah protests that he is too young and doesn't know how to speak, but God touches his mouth saying 'I have put my words in your mouth,' and appoints him to uproot and tear down, to destroy and overthrow, to build and to plant.
Jeremiah 2: God declares that Israel has forsaken Him, the spring of living water, and has dug their own broken cisterns that cannot hold water. He recalls how He brought them out of Egypt and through the wilderness, but they defiled His land and made it detestable, and even the priests did not ask 'Where is the Lord?' God marvels that His people have exchanged their glorious God for worthless idols.
Jeremiah 3: God calls Israel a faithless wife who has prostituted herself with many lovers under every spreading tree, yet He invites her to return. Though Judah saw unfaithful Israel sent away and divorced, Judah did not fear but also played the harlot, not returning to God with her whole heart but only in pretense, and God declares faithless Israel more righteous than treacherous Judah.
Jeremiah 4: If Israel will return to the Lord and remove their detestable idols, they will not be uprooted, but Jeremiah sees disaster coming from the north like a hot wind. He sees the earth formless and empty, the heavens with no light, mountains quaking, and no people—desolation because of God's fierce anger, yet He will not destroy completely, and Jeremiah's heart pounds as he hears the trumpet and battle cry.
Jeremiah 5: God commands to go through Jerusalem's streets looking for one person who deals honestly and seeks truth, but even the leaders have broken the yoke and torn off the bonds. Like a cage full of birds, their houses are full of deceit and they have grown fat and sleek, yet they do not plead the case of the fatherless or defend the just cause of the poor, so God will bring a distant nation against them whose quiver is like an open grave.
Jeremiah 6: Flee from Jerusalem for disaster looms from the north and great destruction! The city is full of oppression, violence, and destruction; from the least to the greatest all are greedy for gain, and from prophet to priest all practice deceit, saying 'Peace, peace' when there is no peace. They do not know how to blush, so God will bring disaster upon this people, the fruit of their schemes, for they have not listened to His words or kept His law.
Jeremiah 7: Jeremiah stands at the temple gate and proclaims that they must not trust in deceptive words saying 'This is the temple of the Lord,' for if they truly change their ways and do not oppress the foreigner, fatherless, or widow, then God will let them live in this place. But they steal, murder, commit adultery, burn incense to Baal, yet come and stand before Him in this house and say 'We are safe'—has this house become a den of robbers?
Jeremiah 8: At that time the bones of Judah's kings, officials, priests, and prophets will be removed from their graves and exposed, for death will be preferable to life for all who remain. The people are skilled in doing evil but know not how to do good, and from prophet to priest everyone deals falsely, yet they say 'Peace, peace' when there is no peace, and Jeremiah weeps for his people's wounds.
Jeremiah 9: Jeremiah wishes his head were a spring of water and his eyes a fountain of tears to weep day and night for the slain of his people. They go from one sin to another and do not acknowledge God, friend deceives friend, and no one speaks the truth, so God will refine and test them, for what else can He do because of the sin of His people? Let the wise not boast of their wisdom or the strong of their strength or the rich of their riches, but let those who boast boast that they understand and know the Lord.
Jeremiah 10: Do not learn the ways of the nations or be terrified by signs in the heavens, for the practices of the peoples are worthless—idols are like scarecrows in a cucumber field that cannot speak or walk. But the Lord is the true God, the living God, the eternal King, and when He is angry the earth trembles, yet by His power He made the earth and established the world by His wisdom, and everyone is senseless and without knowledge.
Jeremiah 11: God tells Jeremiah to proclaim the terms of the covenant He made with their ancestors when He brought them out of Egypt, commanding them to obey Him. But they did not listen and followed the stubbornness of their evil hearts, so God will bring on them all the curses of the covenant, and though they cry out to Him in their time of trouble, He will not listen, and Jeremiah is told not to pray for this people or plead with God on their behalf.
Jeremiah 12: Jeremiah questions why the wicked prosper and the faithless live at ease, for they speak well of God but their hearts are far from Him. God responds that if Jeremiah has raced with men on foot and they have worn him out, how can he compete with horses? He declares that He has forsaken His house and abandoned His inheritance, giving the one He loves into the hands of her enemies, yet He will have compassion and bring each one back to their own inheritance.
Jeremiah 13: God tells Jeremiah to buy a linen belt, wear it, then hide it in a rock crevice where it becomes ruined—illustrating how God will ruin the pride of Judah and Jerusalem who refuse to listen. He warns them to give glory to God before He brings darkness, for can Ethiopians change their skin or leopards their spots? Neither can those who are accustomed to doing evil do good, so He will scatter them like chaff driven by the desert wind.
Jeremiah 14: Drought comes upon Judah—nobles send their servants for water but find none, farmers are dismayed, and even the doe abandons her newborn. Though Jeremiah pleads for God to act for His name's sake and acknowledges their wickedness, God tells him not to pray for their well-being, for though Moses and Samuel stood before Him, He would not look on this people with favor, and sword, famine, pestilence, and captivity await them.
Jeremiah 15: God declares that those destined for death will go to death, those for the sword to the sword, and He will make Judah abhorrent to all kingdoms because of what Manasseh did in Jerusalem. Jeremiah laments his birth and asks why his pain is unending and his wound incurable, but God promises that if he repents and speaks worthy words, He will be Jeremiah's spokesman, and though they fight against him, they will not overcome him.
Jeremiah 16: God tells Jeremiah not to marry or have children in this place, for terrible death awaits those born here, and not to enter a house of mourning or feasting, for He has withdrawn His blessing, love, and pity. Yet He promises that days are coming when people will no longer say 'As surely as the Lord lives who brought Israel up out of Egypt' but will speak of God bringing them back from captivity, and He will teach them His power and might.
Jeremiah 17: Judah's sin is engraved with an iron tool on their hearts and on the horns of their altars, and those who turn away from the Lord will be written in the dust because they have forsaken the Lord, the spring of living water. Blessed is the one who trusts in the Lord, whose confidence is in Him—they will be like a tree planted by water that does not fear when heat comes, but cursed is the one who trusts in man and turns away from the Lord.
Jeremiah 18: God sends Jeremiah to the potter's house where he watches the potter shape clay, and when a pot is marred, the potter forms it into another pot. God declares that like clay in the potter's hand, so are nations in His hand—if they repent of evil He relents from disaster, and if they do evil He reconsiders the good He intended, but the people respond 'It's no use, we will continue with our own plans.'
Jeremiah 19: God tells Jeremiah to buy a clay jar, take some elders and priests to the Valley of Ben Hinnom, and proclaim that He will bring such disaster on Jerusalem that the ears of everyone who hears will tingle, for they have filled this place with innocent blood. Jeremiah then breaks the jar as the men watch, declaring God will smash this nation and city as one smashes a potter's vessel that cannot be repaired.
Jeremiah 20: When Pashhur the priest hears Jeremiah prophesying, he has him beaten and put in stocks at the temple gate. The next day Jeremiah tells him that God will make him a terror to himself and all his friends, and Babylon will carry Judah away captive. Jeremiah then curses the day he was born, wishing he had died in the womb rather than see trouble and sorrow and end his days in shame.
Jeremiah 21: When King Zedekiah sends messengers asking Jeremiah to inquire of the Lord because Nebuchadnezzar is attacking, God responds that He will fight against them with an outstretched hand and mighty arm in fierce anger. He offers the people a choice—the way of life or the way of death—for those who stay in the city will die by sword, famine, or plague, but those who go out and surrender to the Babylonians will live.
Jeremiah 22: Go down to the palace of the king of Judah and declare that if he administers justice, he will have successors on David's throne, but if not, this palace will become a ruin. Concerning Jehoiakim: He will have the burial of a donkey, dragged away and thrown outside Jerusalem's gates, and concerning Jehoiachin (Coniah): Even if he were a signet ring on God's right hand, God would pull him off and give him to Babylon, and none of his descendants will sit on David's throne.
Jeremiah 23: Woe to the shepherds who destroy and scatter the sheep of God's pasture! God will gather the remnant of His flock and place shepherds over them who will care for them, and He will raise up for David a righteous Branch who will reign wisely and do what is just and right. The prophets are ungodly—both prophet and priest are profane, and the prophets of Jerusalem commit adultery and live a lie, prophesying out of their own minds and saying 'I had a dream!' but God did not send them.
Jeremiah 24: After Nebuchadnezzar carries Jehoiachin into exile, God shows Jeremiah two baskets of figs—one with very good figs and one with very bad figs too rotten to eat. The good figs represent the exiles God sent to Babylon whom He will watch over for their good and bring back, giving them a heart to know Him, but the bad figs represent Zedekiah and those who remain in Jerusalem whom God will make abhorrent to all kingdoms.
Jeremiah 25: In the fourth year of Jehoiakim, Jeremiah declares that for twenty-three years God has spoken but the people have not listened, so He will bring Nebuchadnezzar against Judah and they will serve the king of Babylon for seventy years. Then God will punish Babylon, and He gives Jeremiah a cup filled with the wine of His wrath to make all the nations drink, causing them to stagger and go mad because of the sword He will send among them.
Jeremiah 26: Early in Jehoiakim's reign, God tells Jeremiah to stand in the temple courtyard and proclaim that unless they listen and turn from their evil ways, He will make this temple like Shiloh. The priests and prophets seize Jeremiah saying he must die for prophesying against the temple and city, but the officials and people defend him, remembering how Micah prophesied similarly in Hezekiah's time and was not put to death.
Jeremiah 27: Early in Zedekiah's reign, God tells Jeremiah to make a yoke with straps and put it on his neck, then send messages to surrounding kings that God has given all these lands to Nebuchadnezzar. Do not listen to prophets who say 'You will not serve the king of Babylon,' for they are prophesying lies—serve him and live, for why should your city become a ruin?
Jeremiah 28: The prophet Hananiah proclaims in the temple that God will break the yoke of Babylon and within two years bring back the articles from the temple and all the exiles. Jeremiah responds 'Amen! May the Lord do so!' but warns that prophets who prophesy peace are recognized as truly sent only when their predictions come true, and when Hananiah breaks the yoke off Jeremiah's neck, Jeremiah returns saying God will replace the wooden yoke with an iron one, and Hananiah will die this year for preaching rebellion.
Jeremiah 29: Jeremiah sends a letter to the exiles in Babylon saying to build houses, plant gardens, and multiply there, for after seventy years God will bring them back. 'For I know the plans I have for you,' declares the Lord, 'plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future.' But concerning the false prophets Ahab and Zedekiah in Babylon—the king will roast them in the fire for their vileness and adultery.
Jeremiah 30: God tells Jeremiah to write in a book all the words He has spoken, for days are coming when He will bring His people back from captivity and restore them to the land. Though Jacob will be saved from a time of trouble unequaled from ancient times, God will not completely destroy them but will discipline them with justice, breaking the yoke from their neck and tearing off their bonds, and David their king will rule over them.
Jeremiah 31: At that time God will be the God of all Israel's families and they will be His people, for the Lord has appeared from afar saying 'I have loved you with an everlasting love; I have drawn you with unfailing kindness.' He will bring them from the land of the north and gather them, and Rachel weeping for her children will be comforted, for they will return. God will make a new covenant with Israel, writing His law on their hearts, and all will know Him from the least to the greatest.
Jeremiah 32: While Jeremiah is confined in the courtyard during Jerusalem's siege, God tells him to buy his cousin's field in Anathoth, for houses, fields, and vineyards will again be bought in this land. After completing the purchase, Jeremiah prays acknowledging God's power in creation and redemption, and God responds that He will gather His people from all lands where He has banished them and bring them back, giving them singleness of heart to fear Him, and they will be His people.
Jeremiah 33: While Jeremiah is still confined, God speaks promising to bring health and healing to the city, restoring Judah and Israel and cleansing them from all their sins. Joy and gladness will be heard again—the voices of bride and bridegroom and those bringing thank offerings to the temple, for God will restore the fortunes of the land, and a righteous Branch will spring from David's line who will do what is just and right.
Jeremiah 34: While Nebuchadnezzar is fighting against Jerusalem, God tells Jeremiah to warn Zedekiah that the city will be given to Babylon and burned, though he will die peacefully. Later, after the people free their Hebrew slaves in covenant but then take them back, God condemns them for proclaiming freedom for their slaves then taking them back, so He proclaims 'freedom' for them—freedom to fall by sword, plague, and famine.
Jeremiah 35: God sends Jeremiah to the Rekabite family who refuse to drink wine because their ancestor Jehonadab commanded them not to, and they have obeyed for generations, never building houses or planting vineyards. God uses them as an example—if the Rekabites obeyed their ancestor, why hasn't Judah obeyed Him? Because of Judah's disobedience, disaster will come, but the Rekabites will always have descendants to serve Him.
Jeremiah 36: In the fourth year of Jehoiakim, God tells Jeremiah to write on a scroll all the words spoken against Israel, Judah, and the nations. Baruch writes as Jeremiah dictates, then reads the scroll in the temple, and when officials hear it they report to the king who cuts the scroll apart and burns it in the fire, but God tells Jeremiah to take another scroll and write all the words again, adding more besides.
Jeremiah 37: King Zedekiah sends messengers to Jeremiah asking him to pray, and Jeremiah prophesies that the Babylonian army will return and burn Jerusalem—even if you defeated the entire Babylonian army, only wounded men would remain in their tents, yet they would rise up and burn the city. When Jeremiah tries to leave the city, he is arrested as a deserter, beaten, and imprisoned in a dungeon where he remains many days until Zedekiah secretly asks if there is any word from the Lord.
Jeremiah 38: Officials hear Jeremiah telling soldiers to surrender to the Babylonians to save their lives, so they convince the king to put him to death, lowering him with ropes into a cistern with mud but no water. Ebed-Melek the Cushite speaks to the king who allows him to lift Jeremiah out with old rags and worn-out clothes under his arms, and when Zedekiah questions Jeremiah privately, he urges him to surrender to Babylon's officers to save his life and the city.
Jeremiah 39: In Zedekiah's ninth year, Nebuchadnezzar besieges Jerusalem, and in the eleventh year the city wall is broken through. Zedekiah flees but is captured, his sons are killed before his eyes, his eyes are put out, and he is taken to Babylon in bronze shackles. The Babylonians burn the royal palace and houses and tear down Jerusalem's walls, but Nebuchadnezzar orders Jeremiah to be taken care of and freed.
Jeremiah 40: After being freed at Ramah, Jeremiah chooses to stay with Gedaliah whom the king of Babylon appointed as governor over the towns of Judah. Jews scattered in various countries hear that Babylon has left a remnant and return to Gedaliah, but Johanan warns Gedaliah that Ishmael is coming to kill him, though Gedaliah refuses to believe it.
Jeremiah 41: Ishmael son of Nethaniah comes with ten men and kills Gedaliah along with the Judeans and Babylonian soldiers with him. The next day eighty men arrive to bring offerings to the temple, and Ishmael kills them all except ten who bribe him with hidden stores of wheat and barley, then he takes captives including the king's daughters, but Johanan pursues and rescues them, and Ishmael escapes to the Ammonites.
Jeremiah 42: The army officers and all the people ask Jeremiah to pray and inquire of the Lord whether they should stay in Judah or flee to Egypt. After ten days God answers through Jeremiah: If you stay in this land, I will build you up and plant you, but if you go to Egypt you will die by sword, famine, and plague, for My anger will be poured out on you and you will never see this place again.
Jeremiah 43: Azariah, Johanan, and arrogant men accuse Jeremiah of lying and claim Baruch is inciting him against them, so they refuse to obey God's command to stay in Judah and take everyone including Jeremiah and Baruch to Egypt. God tells Jeremiah to take large stones and bury them in the pavement at Pharaoh's palace in Tahpanhes, prophesying that Nebuchadnezzar will set his throne over these stones and strike down Egypt.
Jeremiah 44: Jeremiah speaks to all the Jews living in Egypt, reminding them of Jerusalem's destruction because of their wickedness and idol worship, and warns that if they persist in burning incense to other gods in Egypt, they will be consumed by sword and famine. The people refuse to listen, saying they will continue burning incense to the Queen of Heaven as they and their ancestors did, and Jeremiah declares God's name will no longer be invoked in Egypt and only a few fugitives will return to Judah.
Jeremiah 45: In the fourth year of Jehoiakim, Jeremiah speaks to Baruch who laments 'Woe to me! The Lord has added sorrow to my pain; I am worn out with groaning and find no rest.' God tells Baruch that what He has built He will tear down, and what He has planted He will uproot, yet Baruch should not seek great things for himself but be content that God will let him escape with his life wherever he goes.
Jeremiah 46: Concerning Egypt: God declares that Egypt's army will stumble and fall at the Euphrates River, for this is the day of the Lord when He will take vengeance on His foes. Yet Israel should not be afraid, for God will save them from distant lands, bring them back from captivity, and discipline them with justice but not completely destroy them, though He will completely destroy all the nations where He scatters them.
Jeremiah 47: This is the word of the Lord concerning the Philistines before Pharaoh attacks Gaza: Waters are rising in the north and becoming an overflowing torrent that will overflow the land and everything in it. Gaza will shave her head in mourning and Ashkelon will be silenced, for the Lord has a sword against the Philistines and the remnant from the coasts.
Jeremiah 48: Concerning Moab: Woe to Nebo for it will be ruined, and Kiriathaim will be disgraced and captured. Moab has been at rest from youth like wine left on its dregs, never poured from one jar to another or gone into exile, but days are coming when God will send those who will pour her out. Moab will be ashamed of Chemosh as Israel was ashamed of Bethel, and the pride of Moab will be destroyed.
Jeremiah 49: Concerning Ammon: Does Israel have no sons or heirs? Why then has Molek taken possession of Gad? Concerning Edom: If grape pickers came they would leave gleanings, if thieves at night they would steal only what they wanted, but God has stripped Esau bare and his descendants will be destroyed. Concerning Damascus, Kedar, Hazor, and Elam—all will face God's judgment and destruction.
Jeremiah 50: Concerning Babylon: Declare among the nations that Babylon will be captured and Bel put to shame, for a nation from the north will attack her. Israel and Judah will come weeping to seek the Lord their God, joining themselves in an everlasting covenant, for their shepherds led them astray. Come out of Babylon and be like goats leading the flock, for God will stir up and bring against Babylon an alliance of great nations from the north.
Jeremiah 51: God will raise up a destroyer against Babylon and those who live in Leb Kamai—sharpen the arrows and fill the quivers! Though Babylon reached the heavens and fortified her lofty stronghold, destroyers will come, for this is the vengeance of the Lord. Flee from Babylon, run for your lives, for God will repay her for her deeds, and though heaven and earth shout for joy over Babylon's fall, her wounded will groan.
Jeremiah 52: This final chapter records the fall of Jerusalem—Zedekiah rebels against Babylon in his ninth year, the city is besieged for two years, famine becomes severe, the city wall is broken through, and Zedekiah is captured. The Babylonians burn the temple, royal palace, and all important buildings, break down the walls, and carry the people into exile. Yet in the thirty-seventh year of exile, Jehoiachin king of Judah is released from prison and given a seat of honor above other kings.
Lamentations 1: How deserted lies the city once full of people, now like a widow! She who was great among nations is now a slave, weeping bitterly at night with tears on her cheeks. All her friends have betrayed her, her gates are desolate, her priests groan, her young women grieve, and her enemies have become her masters because of her many sins, for the Lord has brought her grief.
Lamentations 2: How the Lord has covered Daughter Zion with the cloud of His anger! He has thrown down Israel's splendor from heaven, cut off every horn of Israel in His fierce anger, and withdrawn His right hand. He has bent His bow like an enemy and poured out His wrath like fire, destroying the temple He once called His dwelling place, and both prophet and priest have been killed in the sanctuary of the Lord.
Lamentations 3: The writer is the man who has seen affliction by the rod of God's wrath—He has driven him into darkness without light, besieged him, and made his skin and flesh grow old. Yet there is hope because of the Lord's great love and compassion that never fail, for His compassions are new every morning, and though He brings grief, He will show compassion according to His unfailing love, and it is good to wait quietly for the Lord's salvation.
Lamentations 4: How the gold has lost its luster and the fine gold become dull! The precious children of Zion once worth their weight in gold are now considered as clay pots. Even jackals offer their breasts to nurse their young, but the daughter of my people has become heartless like ostriches in the desert, and young children beg for bread but no one gives it to them, for the punishment of my people is greater than that of Sodom.
Lamentations 5: Remember, Lord, what has happened to us—our inheritance has been turned over to foreigners, we have become fatherless orphans and our mothers are widows. We must buy the water we drink and the wood we burn, and we are pursued to the point of exhaustion with no rest. Mount Zion lies desolate with jackals prowling over it, yet You, Lord, reign forever and Your throne endures through all generations—restore us to Yourself, O Lord, that we may return.
Ezekiel 1: In the thirtieth year, in the fourth month, while Ezekiel is among the exiles by the Kebar River in Babylon, the heavens are opened and he sees visions of God. He sees an immense cloud with flashing lightning surrounded by brilliant light, and in the fire are four living creatures with human form but four faces and four wings each, beside them wheels within wheels, and above them an expanse like crystal with a throne of lapis lazuli, and high above is a figure like that of a man radiating brilliant light—the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the Lord.
Ezekiel 2: The voice says 'Son of man, stand up on your feet and I will speak to you,' and the Spirit enters Ezekiel and sets him on his feet. God sends him to the rebellious Israelites who are obstinate and stubborn, telling him not to be afraid of them or their words though briers and thorns are all around and he lives among scorpions, for they are a rebellious people, yet whether they listen or fail to listen, they will know a prophet has been among them.
Ezekiel 3: God gives Ezekiel a scroll to eat that tastes as sweet as honey in his mouth, then sends him to the exiles to speak His words whether they listen or fail to listen. God makes Ezekiel's forehead like the hardest stone, harder than flint, and appoints him as a watchman for Israel—if he warns the wicked and they don't turn from their wickedness, they will die for their sin, but if he fails to warn them, God will hold him accountable for their blood.
Ezekiel 4: God commands Ezekiel to take a clay tablet, draw Jerusalem on it, and lay siege against it with ramps and battering rams as a sign to Israel. He must lie on his left side for 390 days bearing Israel's sin, then on his right side for 40 days bearing Judah's sin, and eat rationed food cooked over cow dung to symbolize the defiled food Israel will eat in the nations where God scatters them.
Ezekiel 5: God tells Ezekiel to shave his head and beard, divide the hair into thirds—burning one third in the city, striking one third with the sword around the city, and scattering one third to the wind while pursuing them with drawn sword. This symbolizes what God will do to Jerusalem because they have rejected His laws and been more wicked than the nations around them, so He will inflict punishment in anger and wrath.
Ezekiel 6: The word of the Lord comes against the mountains of Israel, declaring He will destroy their high places and idols, slaughtering the people before their idols and scattering their bones around the altars. Yet He will spare some who will be scattered among the nations, and they will remember the Lord and loathe themselves for the evil they have done, knowing that He is the Lord.
Ezekiel 7: The end has come upon the four corners of the land—God's anger is unleashed, He will judge according to their conduct and repay for all their detestable practices. Disaster after disaster is coming, the day has come with doom near, panic instead of joy on the mountains, and though they throw their silver into the streets and gold becomes unclean, their wealth cannot save them on the day of the Lord's wrath.
Ezekiel 8: In the sixth year, while Ezekiel sits in his house with the elders of Judah, the hand of the Sovereign Lord comes on him and a figure like a man takes him in visions to Jerusalem. There he sees detestable things—an idol that provokes jealousy at the entrance, elders burning incense to idols in dark rooms, women mourning for Tammuz, and men with their backs to the temple worshiping the sun.
Ezekiel 9: God calls for the guards of the city who come with deadly weapons, and a man clothed in linen with a writing kit is told to go through Jerusalem and put a mark on the foreheads of those who grieve and lament over the detestable things. The others are commanded to follow and kill without mercy—old men, young men, young women, mothers and children—but not to touch anyone with the mark, and they begin at the sanctuary.
Ezekiel 10: God tells the man clothed in linen to take burning coals from among the cherubim and scatter them over the city. Ezekiel sees the glory of the Lord rise from the cherubim and move to the threshold of the temple, and the cherubim lift their wings and rise with the wheels beside them, and the glory of the Lord departs from over the threshold of the temple and stops above the cherubim.
Ezekiel 11: The Spirit lifts Ezekiel up and brings him to the gate of the temple where he sees twenty-five men including leaders giving wicked counsel, saying 'Haven't our houses been recently rebuilt? This city is a pot, and we are the meat in it.' God says this pot is not a refuge—He will drag them out and execute judgment at Israel's borders, and He will give the exiles an undivided heart and a new spirit.
Ezekiel 12: God tells Ezekiel to pack belongings for exile and dig through the wall in the evening while the people watch, for this is a sign concerning the prince in Jerusalem and all Israel. The people say 'The days go by and every vision comes to nothing,' but God replies the days are near when every vision will be fulfilled, and there will no longer be false visions or flattering divinations among Israel.
Ezekiel 13: Woe to the foolish prophets who follow their own spirit and have seen nothing! They prophesy peace when there is no peace, and when people build a flimsy wall, they cover it with whitewash, but God will tear down the wall and expose its foundation. He is also against women who practice magic charms on their wrists and veils on their heads to ensnare people, for they profane Him for handfuls of barley and scraps of bread.
Ezekiel 14: When some elders come to inquire of the Lord, God tells Ezekiel they have set up idols in their hearts, so He will answer them according to their idolatry. Even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in Jerusalem, they could save only themselves by their righteousness, not their sons or daughters, yet God will send survivors out of Jerusalem to the exiles who will see their conduct and be consoled about the disaster He has brought.
Ezekiel 15: God asks how the wood of a vine is better than any other wood—is wood taken from it to make anything useful? If it was not useful before being burned, how much less after fire consumes it! So it is with the people of Jerusalem—God has given them over to the fire, and though they come out of one fire, another will consume them, for they have been unfaithful.
Ezekiel 16: God reminds Jerusalem that she was abandoned at birth like an unwanted child, but He passed by and made her grow, later entering into a covenant and dressing her in fine garments and jewelry. Yet she trusted in her beauty and used her fame to become a prostitute, even sacrificing her children to idols, so she is worse than Sodom and Samaria, yet God will remember His covenant and establish an everlasting covenant with her.
Ezekiel 17: God tells Ezekiel a riddle about a great eagle that took the top of a cedar to a city of traders, then planted a seed that became a spreading vine. But the vine turned toward another eagle, so God declares the first eagle (Babylon) will uproot it and it will wither, for Zedekiah broke his treaty and will be taken to Babylon and die there, yet God will take a shoot from the top of the cedar and plant it on a high mountain where it will become a splendid cedar.
Ezekiel 18: The people quote a proverb: 'The parents eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge,' but God declares this proverb will no longer be quoted, for every soul belongs to Him—the one who sins will die. The righteous person will live, the wicked will die, and if the wicked turn from their ways they will live, for God takes no pleasure in the death of anyone but wants them to turn and live.
Ezekiel 19: Take up a lament for the princes of Israel: Your mother was like a lioness who raised her cubs, and one became a strong lion that learned to tear prey and devour people, but nations trapped him and led him with hooks to Egypt. She raised another cub who also became a strong lion, but he was captured and brought to Babylon in a cage where his roar is heard no more on the mountains of Israel.
Ezekiel 20: In the seventh year, elders come to inquire of the Lord, and God tells the history of Israel's rebellion—how He swore to bring them out of Egypt to a land flowing with milk and honey, yet they rebelled and did not forsake Egyptian idols. Again in the wilderness they rebelled, profaning His Sabbaths, yet for His name's sake He did not destroy them but scattered them among the nations, and still they will be judged.
Ezekiel 21: The word of the Lord comes against Jerusalem—God will draw His sword from its sheath and cut off both the righteous and the wicked. The sword is sharpened and polished for slaughter, and it will strike Ammon as well, for God has drawn His sword and it will not return to its sheath until His wrath is satisfied and the city becomes a desolate waste.
Ezekiel 22: God condemns Jerusalem as the city of bloodshed full of idols that defile herself, bringing her days to a close and the end of her years. Her princes are like wolves tearing prey to shed blood, her prophets whitewash their deeds, her priests violate the law, and her people practice extortion and oppress the poor, so God will pour out His wrath and consume them with His fiery anger.
Ezekiel 23: There were two sisters, Oholah (Samaria) and Oholibah (Jerusalem), who became prostitutes in Egypt from their youth. Oholah lusted after Assyria and was given to her lovers who stripped her naked and killed her, yet her sister Oholibah became even more depraved, lusting after Babylonians, so God will bring her lovers against her in wrath and deal with her in anger and jealous fury.
Ezekiel 24: On the very day Nebuchadnezzar lays siege to Jerusalem, God tells Ezekiel to put a pot on the fire, add choice pieces of meat and bones, and boil it, symbolizing the city full of violence. Then God tells him his wife will die, but he must not mourn or weep, for this is a sign to the exiles—when Jerusalem falls, they too will not mourn openly but will waste away because of their sins.
Ezekiel 25: The word of the Lord comes against Ammon, Moab, Edom, and Philistia because they rejoiced over Israel's fall and the desecration of the sanctuary. God will stretch out His hand against them—giving Ammon to the people of the East, making Moab desolate, taking vengeance on Edom, and executing great vengeance on Philistia—and they will know He is the Lord when He takes vengeance on them.
Ezekiel 26: Because Tyre rejoiced over Jerusalem's fall saying 'The gate to the nations is broken,' God will bring many nations against her like the sea casting up waves. Nebuchadnezzar will come from the north with horses, chariots, and a great army, breaking down towers and walls, and Tyre will become a bare rock, a place to spread fishnets, never to be rebuilt.
Ezekiel 27: Take up a lament for Tyre, the city at the gateway to the sea, merchant of peoples on many coasts—you were perfect in beauty like a ship with planks of juniper, mast of cedar, and sails of fine embroidered linen. Your wealth and merchandise were abundant, but when your rowers bring you to high seas, the east wind will break you to pieces in the heart of the sea, and all who live by the sea will be appalled.
Ezekiel 28: The word of the Lord comes against the ruler of Tyre who says 'I am a god; I sit on the throne of a god,' yet he is a mere mortal. Because his heart is proud, God will bring foreigners against him to draw swords against his beauty and wisdom, and he will die a violent death in the heart of the seas. A lament follows for the king of Tyre, describing him as in Eden wearing precious stones until wickedness was found in him and he was cast to earth.
Ezekiel 29: In the tenth year, the word comes against Pharaoh king of Egypt: God will put hooks in his jaws and make the fish stick to his scales, pulling him out of his streams. Egypt will become a desolate wasteland because Pharaoh said 'The Nile is mine; I made it,' and after forty years of exile God will gather the Egyptians back but they will be the lowliest of kingdoms, no longer a source of confidence for Israel.
Ezekiel 30: Wail for the day, for the day of the Lord is near, a day of clouds and doom for the nations! The sword will come against Egypt, her allies will fall, and her proud strength will fail from Migdol to Aswan. God will set fire to Egypt and break the power of Pharaoh, and when He breaks Pharaoh's arms, he will groan before Nebuchadnezzar like a mortally wounded man.
Ezekiel 31: In the eleventh year, God tells Pharaoh to consider Assyria—it was once like a great cedar in Lebanon with beautiful branches providing shade, taller than all trees, but because it towered on high and its top was among the clouds with pride in its height, God handed it over to the ruler of nations who cut it down. So too will Egypt and her hordes go down to the realm of the dead with those killed by the sword.
Ezekiel 32: In the twelfth year, Ezekiel takes up a lament for Pharaoh: You are like a lion among nations, thrashing about in your streams, but God will spread His net over you and haul you up, throwing you on the land where birds and animals will gorge themselves. God will bring darkness over Egypt when He brings about her destruction, and she will lie among the uncircumcised, with those killed by the sword.
Ezekiel 33: God appoints Ezekiel as a watchman for Israel—if he sees the sword coming and does not blow the trumpet to warn the people, their blood will be on his hands, but if he warns them and they do not listen, they will die for their sin and he will have saved himself. The people say God's way is not just, but God says it is their ways that are not just, for if the righteous turn from righteousness they will die, and if the wicked turn from wickedness they will live.
Ezekiel 34: Woe to Israel's shepherds who only take care of themselves! They have not strengthened the weak, healed the sick, or searched for the lost, and the sheep were scattered with no one to search for them, becoming food for wild animals. God will search for His sheep Himself, rescue them, bring them back to their own land, and place over them one shepherd, His servant David, who will tend them.
Ezekiel 35: The word of the Lord comes against Mount Seir (Edom): Because you harbored ancient hostility and delivered Israel over to the sword in their time of disaster, God will make you desolate forever. You said 'Israel and Judah will be ours,' but God will treat you according to the anger and jealousy you showed, and you will know He is the Lord when He judges you.
Ezekiel 36: Prophesy to the mountains of Israel that God will bring people back to settle them and make them more prosperous than before, for the nations sneered and took possession of them. God will sprinkle clean water on Israel and cleanse them from impurities, give them a new heart and put a new spirit in them, removing their heart of stone and giving them a heart of flesh, and they will be His people.
Ezekiel 37: The hand of the Lord sets Ezekiel in a valley full of dry bones, and God asks if they can live. Ezekiel prophesies to the bones and they come together, then prophesies to the breath and they come to life—a vast army standing on their feet. God explains these bones are Israel who say 'Our bones are dried up and our hope is gone,' but He will open their graves, bring them back to their land, and put His Spirit in them.
Ezekiel 38: The word of the Lord comes against Gog of the land of Magog, chief prince of Meshek and Tubal, who will come from the far north with a vast army against Israel like a cloud covering the land. God will summon a sword against Gog and execute judgment with plague, bloodshed, torrents of rain, hailstones, burning sulfur, and all the nations will know He is the Lord when He shows Himself holy through Gog.
Ezekiel 39: God declares He will strike the bow from Gog's left hand and make the arrows drop from his right, and Gog will fall on the mountains of Israel with all his hordes. It will take seven months to bury the dead and seven years to burn the weapons, and God will display His glory among the nations, no longer hiding His face from Israel but pouring out His Spirit on the house of Israel.
Ezekiel 40: In the twenty-fifth year of exile, God brings Ezekiel in visions to Israel where a man with a measuring rod shows him a new temple with intricate measurements. The man measures the outer court with gates, rooms, and porticoes, then the inner court with more gates and rooms, and the temple structure itself with chambers, all following precise measurements and architectural details.
Ezekiel 41: The man brings Ezekiel to the main hall of the temple and measures its dimensions—the inner sanctuary, the side rooms, and the temple structure. There are palm trees and cherubim carved on the walls, with each cherub having two faces—the face of a human looking toward one palm tree and the face of a lion looking toward another, and the altar of wood stands before the Lord.
Ezekiel 42: The man leads Ezekiel to the outer court and shows him rooms along the north side for the priests, where they will eat the most holy offerings and store the grain offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings. After measuring the inside of the temple area, he leads Ezekiel to the east gate and measures the surrounding area—500 cubits on each side with a wall separating the holy from the common.
Ezekiel 43: The man brings Ezekiel to the east gate, and the glory of the God of Israel comes from the east sounding like rushing waters, and the glory of the Lord enters the temple. God's voice tells Ezekiel this is the place of His throne where He will live among the Israelites forever, and He gives detailed instructions for the altar, including a seven-day consecration period with sin offerings and burnt offerings.
Ezekiel 44: The man brings Ezekiel back to the outer gate facing east, and it is shut because the Lord entered through it, so it must remain shut. God declares that no foreigner uncircumcised in heart may enter His sanctuary, and the Levites who went astray will be temple guards, while the Levitical priests descended from Zadok will minister before Him, wearing linen garments and following specific regulations for service.
Ezekiel 45: When the land is divided, a sacred portion will be set aside for the priests and Levites with the sanctuary in the center, and the prince's land will border the sacred portion. God gives regulations for offerings—the people must provide grain for offerings, and the prince will provide burnt offerings, grain offerings, and drink offerings at festivals, and specific measurements are given for the ephah and bath.
Ezekiel 46: God gives regulations for the prince's worship—on Sabbaths and New Moons he will worship at the entrance of the inner court, and his burnt offering will be six lambs and a ram on the Sabbath. The prince will go in through the portico and out the same way, and when he makes a freewill offering, the gate will be opened for him, and specific inheritance laws are given for the prince's property.
Ezekiel 47: The man brings Ezekiel back to the temple entrance where water is flowing from under the threshold toward the east, becoming deeper until it is a river that cannot be crossed. The water flows to the Dead Sea making the salt water fresh, and wherever the river flows, everything will live with swarms of living creatures and many fish, and fruit trees will grow on both banks with leaves that will not wither and fruit that will not fail.
Ezekiel 48: This is the list of the tribes by name: Dan will have one portion in the far north, followed by Asher, Naphtali, Manasseh, Ephraim, Reuben, and Judah. The sacred portion will be in the center with the temple, and south of the sacred portion will be Benjamin, Simeon, Issachar, Zebulun, and Gad. The city will have twelve gates named after the twelve tribes, and the name of the city will be 'The Lord is There.'
Daniel 1: In the third year of Jehoiakim's reign, Nebuchadnezzar besieges Jerusalem and God delivers it into his hand along with articles from the temple. The king orders that young men from Israel's royal family be brought to serve in the palace—Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah are chosen and renamed Belteshazzar, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. They resolve not to defile themselves with royal food, eating only vegetables and water for ten days, and God gives them knowledge and understanding, and they are found ten times better than all the magicians and enchanters.
Daniel 2: Nebuchadnezzar has troubling dreams and demands his wise men tell him both the dream and its interpretation or be executed. When none can do it, Daniel asks for time and God reveals the mystery in a vision—the king dreamed of a statue with a gold head, silver chest, bronze belly, iron legs, and feet of mixed iron and clay, struck by a rock that becomes a great mountain. Daniel interprets: the statue represents successive kingdoms, and God will establish a kingdom that will never be destroyed.
Daniel 3: King Nebuchadnezzar makes a gold image ninety feet tall and commands everyone to bow down and worship it when they hear music, or be thrown into a blazing furnace. Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego refuse, saying their God can rescue them but even if He doesn't, they will not serve other gods. The king has them thrown into a furnace heated seven times hotter, but they walk around unharmed with a fourth figure like a son of the gods, and they emerge without even the smell of fire.
Daniel 4: King Nebuchadnezzar has a dream of an enormous tree that reaches heaven, providing shelter for all, but a messenger from heaven orders it cut down, leaving only a stump. Daniel interprets that the king will be driven from people to live with wild animals and eat grass like cattle until he acknowledges that the Most High is sovereign, and twelve months later it happens as prophesied, but after seven times pass, Nebuchadnezzar's sanity returns and he praises the King of heaven.
Daniel 5: King Belshazzar holds a great banquet drinking from gold goblets taken from Jerusalem's temple, and suddenly fingers of a human hand appear and write on the wall: 'MENE, MENE, TEKEL, PARSIN.' Daniel is brought in to interpret—God has numbered the days of Belshazzar's reign and brought it to an end, he has been weighed and found wanting, and his kingdom will be divided and given to the Medes and Persians, and that very night Belshazzar is slain.
Daniel 6: King Darius appoints 120 satraps with Daniel as one of three administrators over them, and Daniel so distinguishes himself that the king plans to set him over the whole kingdom. The other officials convince the king to issue a decree that anyone who prays to any god or human except the king for thirty days will be thrown into the lions' den, and when Daniel continues praying, he is thrown in, but God sends an angel who shuts the lions' mouths, and the next morning Daniel is found unharmed.
Daniel 7: In the first year of Belshazzar, Daniel has a vision of four great beasts coming out of the sea—a lion with eagle's wings, a bear with three ribs in its mouth, a leopard with four wings and four heads, and a terrifying fourth beast with iron teeth and ten horns. Daniel sees the Ancient of Days take His seat and one like a son of man coming with the clouds, given authority and sovereign power over an eternal kingdom that will never be destroyed.
Daniel 8: In the third year of Belshazzar, Daniel has a vision of a ram with two horns standing beside a canal, then a goat with a prominent horn between its eyes comes from the west and shatters the ram's horns. The goat's horn breaks off and four prominent horns grow in its place, and from one comes a little horn that grows powerful, casting down some of the starry host. Gabriel explains the ram represents Persia and Media, the goat is Greece, and the vision concerns the distant future.
Daniel 9: In the first year of Darius the Mede, Daniel understands from Jeremiah's prophecy that Jerusalem's desolation will last seventy years. He prays confessing Israel's sin and pleading for mercy, and Gabriel comes to give insight—seventy 'sevens' are decreed to finish transgression, atone for wickedness, and bring everlasting righteousness, and after the Anointed One is put to death, the people of the ruler who will come will destroy the city and sanctuary.
Daniel 10: In the third year of Cyrus, Daniel receives a revelation about a great war and has a vision beside the Tigris River—he sees a man dressed in linen with a belt of gold, face like lightning, eyes like flaming torches, and a voice like the sound of a multitude. The man touches Daniel and explains he was delayed twenty-one days by the prince of Persia but Michael came to help, and he has come to explain what will happen to Daniel's people in the future.
Daniel 11: The man continues revealing the future—kings of the south and north will wage war, with intricate details of their conflicts, alliances through marriage, and invasions. A contemptible person will arise who will invade the kingdom when people feel secure, honor the god of fortresses with gold and silver, and become very strong, but ships from the western coastlands will oppose him, and he will pitch his royal tents between the seas at the beautiful holy mountain, yet he will come to his end with no one to help him.
Daniel 12: At that time Michael the great prince will arise and there will be a time of distress unequaled since nations began, but everyone whose name is written in the book will be delivered. Multitudes who sleep in the dust will awake—some to everlasting life and some to everlasting contempt—and those who are wise will shine like the brightness of the heavens. Daniel is told to seal the words until the time of the end when many will go here and there to increase knowledge.
Hosea 1: The word of the Lord comes to Hosea son of Beeri, and God tells him to marry a promiscuous woman and have children with her, for like an adulterous wife Israel has been unfaithful to the Lord. Hosea marries Gomer daughter of Diblaim who bears him three children—Jezreel, Lo-Ruhamah (not loved), and Lo-Ammi (not my people)—symbolizing God's judgment on Israel, yet God promises a day when they will be called 'children of the living God.'
Hosea 2: God says to rebuke your mother Israel who is not His wife, for she chases after lovers giving her food, water, wool, and linen. God will block her path with thornbushes and wall her in so she cannot find her lovers, and she will return to her first husband, for it was better then than now. In that day God will betroth her to Himself forever in righteousness and justice, love and compassion, and He will show love to Lo-Ruhamah and say to Lo-Ammi 'You are my people.'
Hosea 3: The Lord tells Hosea to love his wife again though she is an adulteress, as the Lord loves the Israelites though they turn to other gods. Hosea buys her back for fifteen shekels of silver and tells her to live with him many days without prostitution or another man, just as Israel will live many days without king or sacrifice or sacred stones, but afterward they will return and seek the Lord their God and David their king, coming trembling to the Lord and His blessings in the last days.
Hosea 4: The Lord has a charge to bring against Israel—there is no faithfulness, love, or acknowledgment of God in the land, only cursing, lying, murder, stealing, and adultery. Because the people reject knowledge, God will reject them as priests, and the more priests there were, the more they sinned, so He will punish them for their ways, for a spirit of prostitution leads them astray and they are unfaithful to their God.
Hosea 5: Hear this, priests and house of Israel! Judgment is coming because you have been a snare at Mizpah and a net spread on Tabor, and Ephraim is given to prostitution. Their deeds do not permit them to return to God because a spirit of prostitution is in their heart, and when they go with their flocks to seek the Lord, they will not find Him for He has withdrawn, and God will tear them like a lion until they admit their guilt and seek His face.
Hosea 6: Come, let us return to the Lord—He has torn us to pieces but He will heal us; He has injured us but He will bind up our wounds. After two days He will revive us, on the third day He will restore us that we may live in His presence, yet your love is like morning mist, so what can God do with you? For He desires mercy not sacrifice, acknowledgment of God rather than burnt offerings, but they have broken the covenant like Adam.
Hosea 7: Whenever God would heal Israel, the sins of Ephraim are exposed—they practice deceit, thieves break into houses, bandits rob in the streets, and they do not realize God remembers their evil deeds. They are all adulterers, hot as an oven, and Ephraim mixes with the nations becoming a flat loaf not turned over, and foreigners sap his strength yet he does not realize it, for they do not return to the Lord or seek Him.
Hosea 8: Put the trumpet to your lips! An eagle is over the house of the Lord because they have broken the covenant and rebelled against His law. Israel cries out 'Our God, we acknowledge You!' yet they set up kings without God's consent and make idols from their silver and gold.
