They sow the wind and reap the whirlwind—though they build many altars for sin offerings, they have become altars for sinning, and Israel will return to Egypt.
Hosea 9: Do not rejoice, Israel, with exultation like the nations, for you have been unfaithful to your God. Ephraim will return to Egypt and eat unclean food in Assyria with no wine offerings to please the Lord, and they will become wanderers among the nations. Because of their great wickedness and hostility, the days of punishment are coming, and Ephraim is blighted—even if they bear children, God will slay their cherished offspring.
Hosea 10: Israel was a spreading vine that yielded fruit for himself, but the more his fruit increased, the more altars he built. Their heart is deceitful and now they must bear their guilt—the Lord will demolish their altars and destroy their sacred stones. Sow righteousness for yourselves, reap the fruit of unfailing love, and break up your unplowed ground, for it is time to seek the Lord until He comes and showers righteousness on you.
Hosea 11: When Israel was a child, God loved him and called His son out of Egypt, teaching Ephraim to walk and taking them in His arms, but the more God called Israel, the further they went from Him. How can God give them up or hand them over? His heart recoils within Him and His compassion is aroused, for He is God and not a mere mortal, the Holy One among them, and they will follow the Lord who will roar like a lion.
Hosea 12: Ephraim feeds on the wind, pursues the east wind all day, and multiplies lies and violence, making a treaty with Assyria and sending olive oil to Egypt. The Lord has a charge to bring against Judah and will punish Jacob according to his ways, for Jacob grasped his brother's heel in the womb and struggled with God as a man, weeping and begging for His favor, so return to your God, maintain love and justice, and wait for Him always.
Hosea 13: When Ephraim spoke, people trembled for he was exalted in Israel, but he became guilty of Baal worship and died. Now they sin more and more, making idols from their silver, yet they will be like morning mist, like dew that disappears, like chaff swirling from a threshing floor, like smoke escaping through a window. God has been their God since Egypt, yet they forgot Him, so He will pounce on them like a lion, but He will ransom them from the power of the grave.
Hosea 14: Return, Israel, to the Lord your God, for your sins have been your downfall. Take words with you and return saying 'Forgive all our sins and receive us graciously,' for Assyria cannot save and idols cannot help. God responds that He will heal their waywardness and love them freely, His anger turning away, and Israel will blossom like a lily, taking root like Lebanon's cedars. Who is wise? Let them realize these things—the ways of the Lord are right, and the righteous walk in them.
Joel 1: The word of the Lord comes to Joel son of Pethuel: Hear this, you elders! Has anything like this ever happened? Tell it to your children and let them tell their children—what the locust swarm has left, the great locusts have eaten, and what the great locusts have left, the young locusts have eaten. Wake up and weep, all you drunkards, for the new wine is taken from your lips, and a nation has invaded the land with teeth of a lion, devastating vines and fig trees.
Joel 2: Blow the trumpet in Zion and sound the alarm on God's holy hill, for the day of the Lord is coming—a day of darkness and gloom with a large and mighty army before whom the earth shakes and the heavens tremble. Even now, declares the Lord, return to Me with all your heart, with fasting, weeping, and mourning, for He is gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and abounding in love, and He will pour out His Spirit on all people—your sons and daughters will prophesy, old men will dream dreams, and young men will see visions.
Joel 3: In those days when God restores the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem, He will gather all nations to the Valley of Jehoshaphat and enter into judgment with them for scattering His people and dividing His land. Proclaim this among the nations: Prepare for war, beat your plowshares into swords and pruning hooks into spears, for multitudes wait in the valley of decision where the Lord will roar from Zion, but Judah will be inhabited forever and the Lord will dwell in Zion.
Amos 1: The words of Amos, a shepherd from Tekoa, who prophesied two years before the earthquake during the reigns of Uzziah and Jeroboam: The Lord roars from Zion and thunders from Jerusalem. He declares judgment against Damascus, Gaza, Tyre, Edom, and Ammon for their atrocities—threshing Gilead with iron sledges, carrying whole communities into exile, breaking treaties, pursuing brothers with swords, and ripping open pregnant women to extend borders.
Amos 2: The Lord continues pronouncing judgment—against Moab for burning the bones of Edom's king to lime, and against Judah for rejecting His law and following false gods. But His fiercest words are for Israel: You oppress the righteous, take bribes, deny justice to the poor, and father and son use the same girl, profaning His holy name. You made the Nazirites drink wine and commanded prophets not to prophesy, so I will crush you as a cart crushes when loaded with grain.
Amos 3: Hear this word the Lord has spoken against you, people of Israel, against the whole family I brought up out of Egypt: You only have I chosen of all the families of the earth, therefore I will punish you for all your sins. Can two walk together unless they have agreed to do so? Does a lion roar when it has no prey? The Sovereign Lord does nothing without revealing His plan to His prophets, and when disaster comes to a city, has not the Lord caused it?
Amos 4: Hear this word, you cows of Bashan on Mount Samaria, you women who oppress the poor and crush the needy and say to your husbands 'Bring us some drinks!' The Sovereign Lord declares He will take you away with hooks, through breaks in the wall you will be led out, and you will be thrown toward Harmon. God withheld rain, struck gardens with blight and mildew, sent plagues and killed your young men in battle, yet you have not returned to Me, so prepare to meet your God, Israel.
Amos 5: Hear this word, Israel, this lament I take up concerning you: Fallen is Virgin Israel, never to rise again, deserted in her own land with no one to lift her up. Seek the Lord and live, or He will sweep through the tribes of Joseph like fire, for you have turned justice into bitterness and cast righteousness to the ground. I hate, I despise your religious festivals and assemblies—take away the noise of your songs, but let justice roll on like a river and righteousness like a never-failing stream!
Amos 6: Woe to you who are complacent in Zion and feel secure on Mount Samaria, you notable men of the foremost nation! You lie on beds adorned with ivory, dine on choice lambs and fattened calves, strum on harps, drink wine by the bowlful, and use the finest lotions, but you do not grieve over the ruin of Joseph. Therefore you will be among the first to go into exile, and your feasting and lounging will end.
Amos 7: This is what the Sovereign Lord showed Amos: He was preparing swarms of locusts, then a fire that consumed the land, but when Amos pleaded, God relented. Then God showed him a plumb line—He will spare Israel no longer, and the high places of Isaac will be destroyed. Amaziah the priest tells King Jeroboam that Amos is conspiring and orders him to leave, but Amos replies he was no prophet but a shepherd whom the Lord took and said 'Go, prophesy to my people Israel.'
Amos 8: This is what the Sovereign Lord showed Amos: a basket of ripe fruit, declaring 'The time is ripe for my people Israel; I will spare them no longer.' The songs in the temple will turn to wailing, and dead bodies will be everywhere, for you trample the needy and do away with the poor, using dishonest scales and selling even the sweepings with the wheat. The days are coming when God will send a famine—not of food or water, but of hearing the words of the Lord.
Amos 9: I saw the Lord standing by the altar saying 'Strike the tops of the pillars so that the thresholds shake,' and not one will get away—though they dig down to the depths below or climb up to the heavens, God's hand will take them. Yet He will not totally destroy the descendants of Jacob, for in that day He will restore David's fallen shelter, repair its broken walls, and rebuild its ruins, and they will possess the remnant of Edom and all the nations that bear His name.
Obadiah 1: The vision of Obadiah concerning Edom: The Lord says 'I will make you small among the nations; you will be utterly despised.' The pride of your heart has deceived you, you who live in the clefts of the rocks and say 'Who can bring me down to the ground?' Though you soar like the eagle, I will bring you down. Because of violence against your brother Jacob, you will be covered with shame and destroyed forever, for you stood aloof when strangers carried off his wealth, and the day of the Lord is near for all nations—as you have done, it will be done to you, but on Mount Zion will be deliverance and the kingdom will be the Lord's.
Jonah 1: The word of the Lord comes to Jonah telling him to go to Nineveh and preach against it, but Jonah flees to Tarshish instead, boarding a ship. The Lord sends a violent storm, and the sailors cast lots to find who is responsible—the lot falls on Jonah who tells them to throw him into the sea. They reluctantly do so and the storm ceases, and the Lord provides a huge fish to swallow Jonah, and he remains in its belly three days and three nights.
Jonah 2: From inside the fish Jonah prays to the Lord, saying 'In my distress I called to the Lord and He answered me, from deep in the realm of the dead I called for help and You listened to my cry.' The engulfing waters threatened him, seaweed was wrapped around his head, but when his life was ebbing away, he remembered the Lord, and his prayer rose to God's holy temple. What he has vowed he will make good—salvation comes from the Lord—and the Lord commands the fish to vomit Jonah onto dry land.
Jonah 3: The word of the Lord comes to Jonah a second time telling him to go to Nineveh and proclaim the message God gives him. Jonah obeys, goes to the great city requiring three days to go through it, and proclaims 'Forty more days and Nineveh will be overthrown.' The Ninevites believe God, declare a fast, and put on sackcloth from the greatest to the least, and when God sees how they turn from their evil ways, He relents and does not bring the destruction He had threatened.
Jonah 4: Jonah is greatly displeased and angry that God spared Nineveh, saying he knew God was gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and abounding in love, and he'd rather die than live. The Lord asks 'Is it right for you to be angry?' Jonah goes east of the city where God provides a leafy plant that grows up over him for shade, making Jonah very happy, but the next day God provides a worm that chews the plant so it withers, and God says if Jonah is concerned about a plant, should He not be concerned about Nineveh with 120,000 people who cannot tell their right hand from their left?
Micah 1: The word of the Lord comes to Micah concerning Samaria and Jerusalem: Look! The Lord is coming from His dwelling place to tread on the heights of the earth, and the mountains melt beneath Him and valleys split apart. All this is because of Jacob's transgression and Israel's sins—Samaria will become a heap of rubble, and her idols will be destroyed. Micah will weep and wail, going barefoot and naked, for Jerusalem's wound is incurable and has reached the very gate of His people.
Micah 2: Woe to those who plan iniquity and work evil on their beds! At morning's light they carry it out because it is in their power to do it, coveting fields and seizing houses, oppressing people and their inheritance. Therefore God will devise disaster against them from which they cannot save themselves, and He will take away their fields. The prophets say 'Do not prophesy,' but the Lord will gather the remnant of Israel like sheep in a pen, and their King will pass through before them, the Lord at their head.
Micah 3: Then Micah says: Listen, leaders of Jacob, you who hate good and love evil, who tear the skin from my people and break their bones in pieces! You will cry out to the Lord, but He will not answer because of the evil you have done. As for the prophets who lead my people astray, proclaiming peace when they have something to eat but war against those who put nothing in their mouths—because of you, Zion will be plowed like a field, Jerusalem will become a heap of rubble, and the temple hill a mound overgrown with thickets.
Micah 4: In the last days the mountain of the Lord's temple will be established as the highest of the mountains and raised above the hills, and all nations will stream to it. They will beat their swords into plowshares and spears into pruning hooks, and nation will not take up sword against nation or train for war anymore. Though the people walk in the names of their gods, Israel will walk in the name of the Lord forever, and He will gather the lame and those driven away, and the Lord will rule over them in Mount Zion from that day and forever.
Micah 5: Marshal your troops now, city of troops, for a siege is laid against us—they will strike Israel's ruler on the cheek with a rod. But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah, though you are small among the clans of Judah, out of you will come for Me one who will be ruler over Israel, whose origins are from of old, from ancient times. He will stand and shepherd His flock in the strength of the Lord, and they will live securely, for then His greatness will reach to the ends of the earth, and He will be our peace.
Micah 6: Listen to what the Lord says: Stand up, plead your case before the mountains, and let the hills hear what you have to say. What have I done to make you weary of Me? I brought you up out of Egypt and sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam to lead you. With what shall I come before the Lord? Shall I come with burnt offerings, with thousands of rams? He has shown you what is good—what does the Lord require of you but to act justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with your God?
Micah 7: What misery is mine! I am like one who gathers summer fruit at the gleaning of the vineyard—there is no cluster to eat, and the godly have been swept from the land. Do not trust a neighbor or put confidence in a friend, for a son dishonors his father and a man's enemies are the members of his own household. But as for me, I watch in hope for the Lord, I wait for God my Savior, and He will hear me. Who is a God like You, who pardons sin and forgives transgression? You will again have compassion on us and hurl all our iniquities into the depths of the sea.
Nahum 1: A prophecy concerning Nineveh—the Lord is a jealous and avenging God who takes vengeance on His foes and vents His wrath against His enemies. The Lord is slow to anger but great in power, and He will not leave the guilty unpunished, His way is in the whirlwind and storm, and clouds are the dust of His feet. Who can withstand His indignation or endure His fierce anger? Yet the Lord is good, a refuge in times of trouble, and He cares for those who trust in Him.
Nahum 2: An attacker advances against you, Nineveh! Guard the fortress, watch the road, brace yourselves, marshal all your strength! The shields of the soldiers are red, the warriors are clad in scarlet, and metal on the chariots flashes on the day they are made ready. The river gates are thrown open and the palace collapses, and it is decreed that Nineveh be exiled and carried away, though she was like a pool whose water is draining away, for the Lord will restore the splendor of Jacob.
Nahum 3: Woe to the city of blood, full of lies and plunder, never without victims! The crack of whips, the clatter of wheels, galloping horses and jolting chariots! I am against you, declares the Lord Almighty, and I will lift your skirts over your face and show the nations your nakedness. All who see you will flee from you saying 'Nineveh is in ruins'—are you better than Thebes that was situated by the Nile with water surrounding her? Nothing can heal you, and your wound is fatal, for who has not felt your endless cruelty?
Habakkuk 1: The prophet Habakkuk complains: How long, Lord, must I call for help and You do not listen or cry out about violence but You do not save? Why do You make me look at injustice and tolerate wrongdoing? The Lord answers that He is raising up the Babylonians, that ruthless and impetuous people who sweep across the earth to seize dwellings not their own. Habakkuk responds: Your eyes are too pure to look on evil, so why do You tolerate the treacherous and remain silent while the wicked swallow up those more righteous than themselves?
Habakkuk 2: Habakkuk says he will stand at his watch and station himself on the ramparts to see what God will say. The Lord answers: Write down the revelation and make it plain on tablets—though it linger, wait for it, for the righteous person will live by his faithfulness. Woe to him who builds his house by unjust gain, who plunders many nations, and to him who builds a city with bloodshed! For the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the Lord as the waters cover the sea.
Habakkuk 3: Habakkuk's prayer: Lord, I have heard of Your fame and stand in awe of Your deeds—repeat them in our day! God comes from Teman and the Holy One from Mount Paran, His glory covers the heavens, His splendor fills the earth, and His brilliance is like the sunrise. Though the fig tree does not bud and there are no grapes on the vines, though the olive crop fails and fields produce no food, yet I will rejoice in the Lord and be joyful in God my Savior, for the Sovereign Lord is my strength.
Zephaniah 1: The word of the Lord comes to Zephaniah during the reign of Josiah: I will sweep away everything from the face of the earth, and I will stretch out My hand against Judah and Jerusalem to destroy every remnant of Baal worship. The great day of the Lord is near—it will be a day of wrath, distress, anguish, trouble, ruin, darkness, gloom, clouds, and blackness, and neither their silver nor gold will be able to save them on the day of the Lord's wrath.
Zephaniah 2: Gather together, shameful nation, before the decree takes effect and the day passes like windblown chaff! Seek the Lord, all you humble of the land who do what He commands—seek righteousness, seek humility, perhaps you will be sheltered on the day of the Lord's anger. Gaza will be abandoned, Ashkelon left in ruins, Moab will become like Sodom and Ammon like Gomorrah, Cush will be slain by God's sword, and He will stretch out His hand against Assyria leaving Nineveh utterly desolate.
Zephaniah 3: Woe to the city of oppressors, rebellious and defiled! She obeys no one, accepts no correction, does not trust in the Lord or draw near to her God. Her officials are roaring lions, her rulers evening wolves, her prophets unprincipled, and her priests profane the sanctuary. Yet the Lord says: I will leave within you the meek and humble who trust in My name—the remnant of Israel will tell no lies, and a deceitful tongue will not be found in their mouths. Sing, Daughter Zion, shout aloud, Israel! The Lord has taken away your punishment and turned back your enemy.
Haggai 1: In the second year of King Darius, the word of the Lord comes through Haggai to Zerubbabel the governor and Joshua the high priest: This people says 'The time has not yet come to rebuild the Lord's house,' yet you live in paneled houses while this house remains a ruin. You have planted much but harvested little, you eat but never have enough, and your wages go into a purse with holes—consider your ways! Go up into the mountains, bring down timber, and build the house, and the Lord stirs up their spirits to work.
Haggai 2: The word of the Lord comes again: Who of you is left who saw this house in its former glory? How does it look to you now? Does it not seem like nothing? But be strong and work, for I am with you, and in a little while I will shake the heavens and earth, and the desired of all nations will come, and I will fill this house with glory. The glory of this present house will be greater than the glory of the former house, and in this place I will grant peace.
Zechariah 1: In the eighth month of the second year of Darius, the word of the Lord comes to Zechariah: Return to Me, and I will return to you, says the Lord, and do not be like your ancestors who did not listen. Zechariah has a vision of a man riding a red horse among myrtle trees in a ravine with red, brown, and white horses behind him—they report that the whole world is at rest and peace. The Lord declares He is very jealous for Jerusalem and angry with the nations that feel secure, for while He was only a little angry, they went too far with punishment.
Zechariah 2: Zechariah looks up and sees a man with a measuring line going to measure Jerusalem, but an angel tells him to run and say that Jerusalem will be a city without walls because of the great number of people and animals in it, and the Lord Himself will be a wall of fire around it and its glory within. Shout and be glad, Daughter Zion, for I am coming and will live among you, and many nations will be joined with the Lord in that day and become His people.
Zechariah 3: Zechariah sees Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the Lord, and Satan standing at his right side to accuse him. The Lord rebukes Satan saying 'The Lord who has chosen Jerusalem rebuke you! Is not this man a burning stick snatched from the fire?' Joshua is dressed in filthy clothes, but the angel orders the filthy clothes removed and rich garments put on him, and a clean turban placed on his head, and the angel declares that if Joshua walks in God's ways, the Lord will bring His servant, the Branch.
Zechariah 4: The angel wakes Zechariah and asks what he sees—a solid gold lampstand with a bowl at the top and seven lamps, and two olive trees beside it. The angel explains this is the word of the Lord to Zerubbabel: Not by might nor by power, but by My Spirit. What are you, mighty mountain? Before Zerubbabel you will become level ground, and he will bring out the capstone with shouts of 'God bless it!' for the hands of Zerubbabel have laid the foundation and will complete it.
Zechariah 5: Zechariah looks again and sees a flying scroll, thirty feet long and fifteen feet wide, which is the curse going out over the whole land against thieves and those who swear falsely. Then he sees a basket with a woman inside representing wickedness, and she is pushed back down and covered with a lead cover, and two women with wings like storks carry the basket to Babylonia to build a house for it, and when ready, the basket will be set there in its place.
Zechariah 6: Zechariah sees four chariots coming from between two mountains—the first with red horses, second with black horses, third with white horses, and fourth with dappled horses, going out to the four spirits of heaven. The angel says they are going throughout the earth, and the one going toward the north country will give God's Spirit rest there. Then God tells Zechariah to take silver and gold and make a crown for Joshua the high priest, declaring he will be called the Branch who will build the Lord's temple and bear royal honor.
Zechariah 7: In the fourth year of King Darius, people from Bethel send men to ask the priests and prophets: Should we mourn and fast in the fifth month as we have done for years? The word of the Lord comes asking: When you fasted and mourned, was it really for Me? And when you ate and drank, were you not just feasting for yourselves? The Lord told your ancestors to administer true justice, show mercy and compassion, do not oppress the widow or fatherless, but they refused to pay attention and turned their backs stubbornly.
Zechariah 8: The word of the Lord Almighty comes: I am very jealous for Zion and burning with jealousy for her. This is what the Lord says: I will return to Zion and dwell in Jerusalem, which will be called the Faithful City. Once again men and women of ripe old age will sit in Jerusalem's streets with cane in hand because of their age, and the city streets will be filled with boys and girls playing. The fasts of the fourth, fifth, seventh, and tenth months will become joyful and glad occasions—therefore love truth and peace.
Zechariah 9: A prophecy declares judgment on Damascus, Hamath, Tyre, and Sidon, and the cities of Philistia—they will be destroyed and their wealth carried off. But rejoice greatly, Daughter Zion! See, your King comes to you, righteous and victorious, lowly and riding on a donkey, on a colt the foal of a donkey. He will proclaim peace to the nations, His rule will extend from sea to sea and from the River to the ends of the earth, and the Lord will appear over them, His arrow flashing like lightning.
Zechariah 10: Ask the Lord for rain in the springtime, for it is the Lord who sends the thunderstorms. The idols speak deceitfully and diviners see visions that lie, so the people wander like sheep oppressed for lack of a shepherd, and God's anger burns against the shepherds. Yet He will care for His flock and make them like a proud horse in battle, and the cornerstone and tent peg will come from Judah—they will be like warriors trampling their enemies in the mud of the streets.
Zechariah 11: Open your doors, Lebanon, that fire may devour your cedars! Wail, you juniper, for the cedar has fallen and the stately trees are ruined! The Lord tells Zechariah to shepherd the flock marked for slaughter whose buyers kill them and go unpunished. He takes two staffs, one called Favor and one called Union, but breaks both staffs symbolizing the breaking of God's covenant and the breaking of brotherhood between Judah and Israel. Then he takes the wages of thirty pieces of silver and throws them to the potter in the house of the Lord.
Zechariah 12: A prophecy concerning Israel: The Lord who stretches out the heavens and forms the human spirit within a person declares He will make Jerusalem an immovable rock for all nations—all who try to move it will injure themselves. On that day God will strike every horse with panic and every rider with madness, but He will watch over Judah, and they will be like a firepot among wood or a flaming torch among sheaves, consuming all surrounding peoples right and left, and God will pour out a spirit of grace and supplication on David's house and Jerusalem's inhabitants.
Zechariah 13: On that day a fountain will be opened for David's house and Jerusalem's inhabitants to cleanse them from sin and impurity. I will remove the prophets and spirit of impurity from the land, and if anyone still prophesies, their own parents will say 'You must die because you have told lies in the Lord's name,' and they will pierce them. Strike the shepherd and the sheep will be scattered, and God will turn His hand against the little ones—two-thirds will be struck down and die, but one-third will be left and refined like silver and tested like gold.
Zechariah 14: A day of the Lord is coming when Jerusalem will be captured, houses ransacked, and women raped, and half the city will go into exile. Then the Lord will go out and fight against those nations, and His feet will stand on the Mount of Olives which will be split in two from east to west forming a great valley. On that day there will be no light or cold or frost—it will be a unique day with no daytime or nighttime, and living water will flow from Jerusalem. The Lord will be King over the whole earth—on that day there will be one Lord and His name the only name.
Malachi 1: A prophecy—the word of the Lord to Israel through Malachi: I have loved you, says the Lord, but you ask 'How have You loved us?' Was not Esau Jacob's brother? Yet I have loved Jacob but Esau I have hated. A son honors his father and a servant his master—if I am a father, where is the honor due Me? You bring blind, lame, and diseased animals for sacrifice—would your governor be pleased with that? Oh, that one of you would shut the temple doors so you would not light useless fires on My altar!
Malachi 2: And now, you priests, this warning is for you—if you do not honor My name, I will send a curse on you. You have violated the covenant with Levi and caused many to stumble by your teaching. Have we not all one Father? Did not one God create us? Why do we profane the covenant by being unfaithful to one another? Judah has desecrated the sanctuary the Lord loves by marrying women who worship foreign gods. I hate divorce, says the Lord God of Israel, so do not be unfaithful to the wife of your youth.
Malachi 3: I will send My messenger who will prepare the way before Me, and then suddenly the Lord you are seeking will come to His temple—the messenger of the covenant whom you desire will come. But who can endure the day of His coming? For He will be like a refiner's fire purifying the Levites. Will a mere mortal rob God? Yet you rob Me in tithes and offerings—bring the whole tithe into the storehouse that there may be food in My house, and test Me in this and see if I will not throw open the floodgates of heaven and pour out so much blessing there will not be room enough to store it.
Malachi 4: Surely the day is coming burning like a furnace when all the arrogant and evildoers will be stubble, and that day will set them on fire leaving them neither root nor branch. But for you who revere My name, the sun of righteousness will rise with healing in its rays, and you will go out and frolic like well-fed calves, trampling down the wicked who will be ashes under the soles of your feet. Remember the law of My servant Moses, and see, I will send the prophet Elijah before that great and dreadful day of the Lord comes, and he will turn the hearts of the parents to their children and the hearts of the children to their parents.
Matthew 1: Matthew traces Jesus' genealogy from Abraham through David to Joseph, establishing Jesus as the legal heir to David's throne and the fulfillment of God's covenant promises. The angel announces to Joseph that Mary will bear a son conceived by the Holy Spirit, and he is to name Him Jesus (meaning 'the Lord saves'), for He will save His people from their sins, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy about Immanuel—'God with us.'
Matthew 2: Wise men from the east follow a star to Jerusalem seeking the newborn King of the Jews, and Herod directs them to Bethlehem where they worship Jesus and present gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh. Warned in a dream, they return home another way, and an angel tells Joseph to flee to Egypt because Herod plans to kill the child, and after Herod's death, they return and settle in Nazareth, fulfilling multiple prophecies.
Matthew 3: John the Baptist appears in the wilderness of Judea preaching 'Repent, for the kingdom of heaven has come near,' baptizing with water for repentance while confronting the religious leaders as a brood of vipers. Jesus comes from Galilee to be baptized by John, who protests, but Jesus insists to 'fulfill all righteousness,' and when He comes up from the water, the heavens open, the Spirit descends like a dove, and the Father's voice declares 'This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.'
Matthew 4: Jesus is led by the Spirit into the wilderness where He fasts forty days and is tempted by Satan three times—to turn stones to bread, to throw Himself from the temple, and to worship Satan for all the kingdoms—but Jesus resists each with Scripture. After John is imprisoned, Jesus begins His ministry in Galilee proclaiming 'Repent, for the kingdom of heaven has come near,' and He calls His first disciples—Simon Peter, Andrew, James, and John—who immediately leave their nets to follow Him.
Matthew 5: Jesus goes up on a mountainside and teaches the Beatitudes—blessed are the poor in spirit, those who mourn, the meek, those who hunger for righteousness, the merciful, the pure in heart, the peacemakers, and the persecuted. He declares His followers are the salt of the earth and light of the world, and He has not come to abolish the Law but to fulfill it. He teaches about anger and murder, lust and adultery, divorce, oaths, retaliation ('turn the other cheek'), and loving enemies, commanding His followers to be perfect as their heavenly Father is perfect.
Matthew 6: Jesus teaches about giving to the needy in secret, praying in private rather than to be seen by others, and provides the Lord's Prayer as a model. He teaches about fasting without making it obvious, storing up treasures in heaven rather than on earth where moth and rust destroy, and warns that no one can serve two masters—you cannot serve both God and money. He commands not to worry about life, food, drink, or clothing, for your heavenly Father knows what you need, so seek first His kingdom and righteousness and these things will be given to you.
Matthew 7: Jesus teaches not to judge others or you will be judged by the same measure, and first remove the plank from your own eye before trying to remove the speck from your brother's. He promises that everyone who asks receives, who seeks finds, and to those who knock the door will be opened, for your Father in heaven gives good gifts to those who ask. Enter through the narrow gate that leads to life, beware of false prophets who are wolves in sheep's clothing, and those who hear His words and puts them into practice is like a wise man who built his house on the rock.
Matthew 8: Jesus comes down from the mountain and cleanses a leper with a touch, then heals the centurion's paralyzed servant from a distance, marveling at the centurion's faith which surpasses any He has found in Israel. He heals Peter's mother-in-law and many demon-possessed people, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy, and He teaches about the cost of discipleship—foxes have dens but the Son of Man has no place to lay His head. He calms a furious storm on the sea with a word, and the disciples marvel 'What kind of man is this? Even the winds and waves obey him!' He casts demons out of two men into a herd of pigs.
Matthew 9: Jesus heals a paralyzed man, first forgiving his sins, demonstrating that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins. He calls Matthew the tax collector to follow Him and eats with tax collectors and sinners, explaining that He came not to call the righteous but sinners, and teaches about fasting, new wine, and new wineskins. He heals a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years and raises Jairus's daughter from the dead, gives sight to two blind men who proclaim His fame throughout the region, and heals a mute demon-possessed man, but the Pharisees claim He drives out demons by the prince of demons.
Matthew 10: Jesus gives His twelve apostles authority to drive out impure spirits and heal every disease and sickness, naming them: Simon Peter, Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Thomas, Matthew, James son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot. He sends them to the lost sheep of Israel with instructions: proclaim that the kingdom of heaven is near, heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse lepers, drive out demons, take no money or extra provisions, and whoever does not receive you, shake the dust off your feet. He warns they will be persecuted, handed over to councils, flogged, and brought before governors, but the Spirit will speak through them, and whoever stands firm to the end will be saved.
Matthew 11: When John the Baptist sends disciples to ask if Jesus is the Messiah, Jesus points to His miracles as evidence and declares John is the greatest born of women, yet the least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he. Jesus denounces the unrepentant cities where He performed most miracles—Chorazin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum—declaring it will be more bearable for Sodom on judgment day. He praises the Father for hiding these things from the wise and revealing them to little children, then issues His famous invitation: 'Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.'
Matthew 12: The Pharisees accuse Jesus' disciples of breaking the Sabbath by picking grain, and Jesus responds that the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath, then heals a man's withered hand on the Sabbath, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy about the gentle servant. When Jesus casts out a demon, the Pharisees claim He does it by Beelzebul, and Jesus warns that blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven, that a tree is known by its fruit, and every careless word will be judged. He declares that no sign will be given except the sign of Jonah—as Jonah was three days in the fish, so the Son of Man will be three days in the earth—and true family are those who do the will of the Father.
Matthew 13: Jesus teaches in parables by the lake: the parable of the sower whose seed falls on different soils representing different responses to the word, the parable of the weeds among wheat explaining that both will grow until the harvest, the parables of the mustard seed and yeast showing the kingdom's growth. He explains the parable of the weeds—the field is the world, good seed are kingdom sons, weeds are sons of the evil one, and at the end the angels will separate them. He shares parables of the hidden treasure, the pearl of great value, and the net catching all kinds of fish, and the people of His hometown take offense at Him.
Matthew 14: Herod beheads John the Baptist after John condemned his marriage to Herodias, and Herodias's daughter requests John's head on a platter. When Jesus hears the news, He withdraws by boat to a solitary place, but crowds follow, and He has compassion, heals their sick, then feeds five thousand men plus women and children with five loaves and two fish, with twelve baskets of leftovers. He sends the disciples ahead across the lake, and in the early morning walks on the water to them, and when Peter asks to come to Him on the water, Peter walks briefly but begins to sink when he doubts, and Jesus reaches out to save him.
Matthew 15: Pharisees and teachers of the law criticize Jesus' disciples for not washing hands before eating, and Jesus exposes their hypocrisy—they honor God with their lips but break God's commands by their traditions, nullifying God's word for the sake of tradition. He teaches that what goes into the mouth does not defile, but what comes out of the heart—evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sexual immorality, theft, false testimony, and slander. A Canaanite woman begs Jesus to heal her demon-possessed daughter, and when she persists despite His testing, Jesus commends her great faith and heals her daughter, then He heals many and feeds four thousand with seven loaves and a few fish.
Matthew 16: The Pharisees and Sadducees demand a sign from heaven, and Jesus warns them no sign will be given except Jonah's, then warns His disciples about the yeast of the Pharisees—their teaching. When Jesus asks who people say He is, Peter declares 'You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God,' and Jesus blesses him, saying on this rock He will build His church and gives him the keys of the kingdom. Jesus then predicts His death and resurrection for the first time, and when Peter rebukes Him, Jesus says 'Get behind me, Satan!' He teaches that those who want to follow Him must deny themselves, take up their cross, and whoever loses their life for Him will find it.
Matthew 17: Jesus takes Peter, James, and John up a high mountain where He is transfigured—His face shines like the sun and His clothes become white as light—and Moses and Elijah appear talking with Him. A voice from the cloud declares 'This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him!' Jesus tells them not to tell anyone until He rises from the dead, and He comes down to heal a demon-possessed boy whom the disciples could not heal because of their little faith. Jesus again predicts His death and resurrection, then provides a miracle coin from a fish's mouth to pay the temple tax.
Matthew 18: When the disciples ask who is greatest in the kingdom of heaven, Jesus calls a little child, saying unless you change and become like children, you will never enter the kingdom, and whoever welcomes such a child welcomes Him. He warns about causing little ones to stumble—better to have a millstone hung around your neck and be drowned—and teaches to confront a sinning brother privately, then with witnesses, then tell the church. He teaches about binding and loosing, promises that where two or three gather in His name He is with them, and tells Peter to forgive not seven times but seventy-seven times, illustrating with the parable of the unmerciful servant.
Matthew 19: Pharisees test Jesus about divorce, and He teaches that God made them male and female from the beginning, a man leaves father and mother to be united with his wife as one flesh, and Moses permitted divorce because of hard hearts, but 'what God has joined together, let no one separate.' Little children are brought to Jesus and He blesses them, saying the kingdom belongs to such as these, then the rich young ruler asks about eternal life, and Jesus tells him to sell his possessions and follow Him, but he goes away sad, and Jesus says it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for the rich to enter heaven.
Matthew 20: Jesus tells the parable of the workers in the vineyard hired at different times but all receiving the same wage, teaching that the last will be first and the first last. He predicts His death and resurrection a third time, saying the Son of Man will be betrayed, mocked, flogged, and crucified, but will rise on the third day. When James and John's mother asks for her sons to sit at His right and left in His kingdom, Jesus teaches that whoever wants to be great must be a servant, for the Son of Man came not to be served but to serve and give His life as a ransom for many, then He heals two blind men near Jericho.
Matthew 21: Jesus enters Jerusalem on a donkey, fulfilling Zechariah's prophecy, and crowds spread cloaks and palm branches, shouting 'Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!' He cleanses the temple, overturning money changers' tables and declaring 'My house will be called a house of prayer, but you are making it a den of robbers.' He curses a fig tree that withers immediately, teaches about faith that moves mountains, and when religious leaders question His authority, He tells the parables of the two sons and the tenants who kill the vineyard owner's son, revealing they are rejecting Him.
Matthew 22: Jesus tells the parable of the wedding banquet where invited guests refuse to come, so the king sends servants to invite anyone they can find, but one guest without wedding clothes is thrown out. Pharisees try to trap Jesus with questions about paying taxes to Caesar ('Give back to Caesar what is Caesar's, and to God what is God's'), Sadducees question Him about resurrection and marriage (God is the God of the living), and a Pharisee asks which is the greatest commandment—Jesus answers: love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, and mind, and love your neighbor as yourself, then He asks them whose son the Messiah is.
Matthew 23: Jesus warns the crowds and disciples about the teachers of the law and Pharisees who do not practice what they preach, love places of honor, and burden people with heavy loads. He pronounces seven woes against them: you shut the door of the kingdom in people's faces, you travel to make converts who become sons of hell, you are blind guides with twisted priorities about oaths, you give a tenth but neglect justice and mercy, you clean the outside but are full of greed and self-indulgence, you are like whitewashed tombs beautiful outside but full of dead bones inside, and you build tombs for the prophets your ancestors killed, and He laments over Jerusalem who kills the prophets.
Matthew 24: As Jesus leaves the temple, disciples point out the magnificent buildings, but He prophesies not one stone will be left on another. On the Mount of Olives, He describes the signs before His return: false messiahs will appear, wars and rumors of wars, famines and earthquakes, persecution of believers, the gospel preached to all nations, the abomination of desolation, great tribulation, false prophets, and cosmic signs. The Son of Man will come on clouds with power and glory, gathering His elect, but no one knows the day or hour, so watch and be ready like a faithful servant, for the Son of Man will come at an unexpected hour.
Matthew 25: Jesus tells three parables about His return: the ten virgins where five wise ones have oil for their lamps but five foolish ones don't and miss the bridegroom's arrival; the talents where servants are given different amounts and two invest wisely but one buries it in fear; and the sheep and goats where the King separates people based on whether they fed the hungry, gave drink to the thirsty, welcomed strangers, clothed the naked, and visited the sick and imprisoned, declaring 'Whatever you did for the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me,' and the righteous go to eternal life but the cursed to eternal punishment.
Matthew 26: Jesus tells disciples the Passover is in two days and He will be crucified, and the chief priests plot to arrest Him. Mary of Bethany anoints Jesus with expensive perfume, and when disciples object, He defends her, saying she has prepared Him for burial. Judas agrees to betray Jesus for thirty pieces of silver, and at the Last Supper, Jesus institutes communion, saying the bread is His body and the wine is His blood of the covenant poured out for forgiveness of sins. In Gethsemane, He prays three times 'My Father, if it is possible, take this cup from me. Yet not as I will, but as you will,' then Judas betrays Him with a kiss, He is arrested, Peter denies Him three times, and the Sanhedrin condemns Him to death.
Matthew 27: The religious leaders bind Jesus and hand Him over to Pilate, and when Judas sees Jesus condemned, he returns the thirty pieces of silver, says 'I have sinned by betraying innocent blood,' and hangs himself. Pilate questions Jesus, offers to release Him during Passover, but the crowd demands Barabbas and shouts 'Crucify him!' so Pilate washes his hands and releases Jesus to be crucified. Soldiers mock Jesus, put a crown of thorns on His head, then crucify Him at Golgotha between two criminals, and darkness covers the land from noon to 3 PM when Jesus cries out 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?' breathes His last, and the temple curtain tears in two from top to bottom, and Joseph of Arimathea buries Him in his own new tomb.
Matthew 28: After the Sabbath, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary go to the tomb, and an angel rolls back the stone, appearing like lightning in white as snow, telling them Jesus has risen. As they hurry to tell the disciples, Jesus meets them saying 'Greetings,' and they worship Him. The guards are bribed to say the disciples stole the body while they slept, and Jesus appears to the eleven disciples in Galilee, giving the Great Commission: 'All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. And surely I am with you always, to the very end of the age.'
Mark 1: Mark begins 'The beginning of the good news about Jesus the Messiah, the Son of God,' introducing John the Baptist who baptizes with water and proclaims one coming after him who will baptize with the Holy Spirit. Jesus is baptized, the Spirit descends like a dove, and the Father declares 'You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased,' then the Spirit drives Jesus into the wilderness where He is tempted by Satan forty days. After John is arrested, Jesus proclaims 'The time has come. The kingdom of God has come near. Repent and believe the good news!' He calls His first disciples, casts out an impure spirit in the synagogue, heals Peter's mother-in-law and many others, and prays alone in a solitary place early in the morning.
Mark 2: Jesus heals a paralyzed man lowered through the roof, first forgiving his sins and demonstrating the Son of Man's authority to forgive sins on earth. He calls Levi the tax collector to follow Him and eats with tax collectors and sinners, saying 'It is not the healthy who need a doctor, but the sick. I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners.' When questioned about fasting, He explains that wedding guests don't fast while the bridegroom is with them, and teaches about new wine requiring new wineskins. The Pharisees accuse His disciples of breaking the Sabbath, and Jesus declares 'The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath. So the Son of Man is Lord even of the Sabbath.'
Mark 3: Jesus heals a man with a shriveled hand on the Sabbath, and the Pharisees begin plotting with the Herodians to kill Him. Great crowds follow as He heals many and casts out demons who recognize Him as the Son of God, then He appoints twelve apostles to be with Him and to preach and have authority to drive out demons. When teachers of the law accuse Him of being possessed by Beelzebul, Jesus explains that a kingdom divided against itself cannot stand, warns that blasphemy against the Holy Spirit will never be forgiven, and declares that whoever does God's will is His brother, sister, and mother.
Mark 4: Jesus teaches in parables by the lake: the parable of the sower with seed falling on different soils representing different responses to God's word—the path where Satan takes it away, rocky places with no root, thorns that choke it, and good soil producing a crop. He explains that parables reveal mysteries of the kingdom to those who have ears to hear, teaches about the growing seed and mustard seed showing the kingdom's growth, and when a furious squall comes up on the lake, He calms it with 'Quiet! Be still!' and the disciples ask in awe 'Who is this? Even the wind and waves obey him!'
Mark 5: Jesus casts a legion of demons out of a man living among the tombs, sending them into a herd of pigs that rush down the steep bank into the lake, and the healed man begs to go with Jesus but is told to go home and tell what the Lord has done for him. Jairus, a synagogue leader, begs Jesus to heal his dying daughter, and on the way, a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years touches Jesus' cloak and is instantly healed. When word comes that Jairus's daughter has died, Jesus says 'Don't be afraid; just believe,' goes to the house, and takes her hand saying 'Talitha koum!' (Little girl, get up!), and she rises immediately.
Mark 6: Jesus teaches in His hometown synagogue where people take offense, and He says 'A prophet is not without honor except in his own town, among his relatives and in his own home,' and He could not do many miracles there because of their lack of faith. He sends out the twelve in pairs with authority over impure spirits, and they drive out demons and heal many. Herod has John the Baptist beheaded after Herodias's daughter requests his head, and Jesus feeds five thousand with five loaves and two fish, then walks on water to the disciples' boat, and wherever He goes, people bring the sick to touch even the edge of His cloak and are healed.
Mark 7: Pharisees and teachers of the law criticize Jesus' disciples for eating with ceremonially unclean hands, and Jesus exposes their hypocrisy—they set aside God's commands to hold to human traditions. He teaches that nothing outside a person defiles them, but what comes from within—evil thoughts, sexual immorality, theft, murder, adultery, greed, malice, deceit, lewdness, envy, slander, arrogance, and folly. A Syrophoenician woman begs Jesus to drive a demon out of her daughter, and when she responds to His test with remarkable faith ('even the dogs eat the children's crumbs'), He heals her daughter, then He heals a deaf man by putting His fingers in his ears and touching his tongue, saying 'Ephphatha!' (Be opened!).
Mark 8: Jesus feeds four thousand people with seven loaves and a few small fish, then the Pharisees demand a sign and He sighs deeply, warning disciples about the yeast of the Pharisees and Herod. He heals a blind man at Bethsaida in two stages, then asks disciples who people say He is—Peter declares 'You are the Messiah'—and Jesus predicts His death and resurrection for the first time. When Peter rebukes Him, Jesus says 'Get behind me, Satan!' and teaches that whoever wants to follow Him must deny themselves and take up their cross, for whoever loses their life for Him and the gospel will save it, and what good is it to gain the whole world yet forfeit your soul?
Mark 9: Jesus takes Peter, James, and John up a high mountain where He is transfigured before them—His clothes become dazzling white—and Elijah and Moses appear. A voice from the cloud says 'This is my Son, whom I love. Listen to him!' Coming down, Jesus heals a demon-possessed boy whom the disciples couldn't help, saying 'Everything is possible for one who believes,' and the father cries out 'I do believe; help me overcome my unbelief!' Jesus again predicts His death and resurrection, teaches that whoever wants to be first must be servant of all, welcomes a child in His name, warns about causing little ones to stumble, and teaches that everyone will be salted with fire and to have salt among yourselves and be at peace.
Mark 10: Pharisees test Jesus about divorce, and He teaches that Moses permitted it because of hard hearts, but from the beginning God made them male and female to become one flesh, so what God has joined together let no one separate. He blesses little children and says the kingdom of God belongs to such as these, tells the rich young ruler to sell all and follow Him (he goes away sad), teaches it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for the rich to enter heaven, and promises rewards to those who have left everything to follow Him. James and John request places of honor, and Jesus teaches that whoever wants to be great must be a servant, for even the Son of Man came to serve and give His life as a ransom for many, then He heals blind Bartimaeus near Jericho.
Mark 11: Jesus enters Jerusalem on a colt, people spread cloaks and branches shouting 'Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord! Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David!' He enters the temple courts looking around at everything, then curses a fig tree the next morning. He cleanses the temple, overturning money changers' tables and saying 'My house will be called a house of prayer for all nations, but you have made it a den of robbers.' The disciples see the fig tree withered from the roots, and Jesus teaches about faith, prayer, and forgiveness—if you believe, you will receive whatever you ask in prayer, and when you stand praying, forgive so your Father in heaven may forgive you.
Mark 12: Jesus tells the parable of the tenants who kill the vineyard owner's servants and finally his son, declaring the stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone. Religious leaders try to trap Him with questions about paying taxes to Caesar ('Give back to Caesar what is Caesar's and to God what is God's'), resurrection and marriage (God is the God of the living), and the greatest commandment—Jesus answers: 'Love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, mind and strength' and 'Love your neighbor as yourself.' He warns about teachers of the law who devour widows' houses, and praises a poor widow who puts two small coins in the temple treasury, saying she put in more than all the others because she gave all she had to live on.
Mark 13: As Jesus leaves the temple, disciples marvel at the magnificent buildings, but He prophesies not one stone will be left on another. He describes signs before His return: false messiahs, wars, earthquakes, famines, persecution of believers, the abomination of desolation, great distress, false prophets performing signs and wonders, cosmic disturbances, and the Son of Man coming in clouds with great power and glory to gather His elect. He teaches the lesson of the fig tree—when its twigs get tender you know summer is near—so when you see these things happening, know it is near. Heaven and earth will pass away but His words will never pass away, yet no one knows the day or hour, so keep watch, be alert, and pray.
Mark 14: Chief priests and teachers of the law plot to arrest Jesus, and a woman anoints Him with expensive perfume, which He says prepares His body for burial. Judas agrees to betray Jesus for money, and at the Last Supper, Jesus institutes communion, saying the bread is His body and the wine is His blood of the covenant poured out for many. He predicts Peter will deny Him three times before the rooster crows twice, then in Gethsemane prays 'Abba, Father, everything is possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.' Judas betrays Him with a kiss, He is arrested, Peter denies Him three times, and the Sanhedrin condemns Him to death when He affirms He is the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One.
Mark 15: The chief priests bind Jesus and hand Him over to Pilate, who asks if He is the king of the Jews. Pilate wants to release Jesus, but the crowd demands Barabbas and shouts 'Crucify him!' so Pilate hands Him over to be crucified. Soldiers mock Jesus, put a purple robe and crown of thorns on Him, then lead Him to Golgotha and crucify Him with two rebels. At noon, darkness covers the land for three hours, and at 3 PM Jesus cries out 'Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?' (My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?), breathes His last, and the temple curtain tears in two from top to bottom. The centurion declares 'Surely this man was the Son of God!' and Joseph of Arimathea buries Jesus in a tomb cut out of rock.
Mark 16: After the Sabbath, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome go to the tomb with spices, but find the stone rolled away and a young man in a white robe who says 'He has risen! He is not here. Go, tell his disciples and Peter he is going ahead of you into Galilee.' Jesus appears first to Mary Magdalene who tells the disciples, then to two walking in the country, and finally to the eleven as they are eating, rebuking their lack of faith. He commissions them: 'Go into all the world and preach the gospel to all creation. Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved,' then He is taken up into heaven and sits at the right hand of God.
Luke 1: Luke writes an orderly account to Theophilus, beginning with Zechariah the priest who is struck mute when he doesn't believe the angel's announcement that his elderly wife Elizabeth will bear a son named John. The angel Gabriel appears to Mary in Nazareth, announcing she will conceive by the Holy Spirit and bear a son to be called Jesus who will reign on David's throne forever, and Mary responds 'I am the Lord's servant. May your word to me be fulfilled.' Mary visits Elizabeth, who is filled with the Spirit and proclaims 'Blessed are you among women,' and Mary praises God in the Magnificat. When John is born, Zechariah's tongue is loosed and he prophesies the Benedictus about God's salvation.
Luke 2: Caesar Augustus issues a decree for a census, and Joseph goes from Nazareth to Bethlehem with Mary, who gives birth to Jesus and lays Him in a manger because there is no guest room. Angels appear to shepherds announcing 'Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord,' and the shepherds find the baby and spread the word. After eight days Jesus is circumcised, and at the temple Simeon holds Jesus, declares he can die in peace having seen God's salvation, and prophesies to Mary that a sword will pierce her own soul. At twelve, Jesus stays behind in Jerusalem, and His parents find Him in the temple courts sitting among the teachers, listening and asking questions, and He grows in wisdom and stature and in favor with God and man.
Luke 3: In the fifteenth year of Tiberius Caesar, the word of God comes to John son of Zechariah in the wilderness, and he proclaims a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins, preparing the way for the Lord. John tells crowds to share with those in need, tells tax collectors to collect no more than required, tells soldiers not to extort money or accuse falsely, and warns against trusting in Abraham as father, for God can raise up children for Abraham from stones. Jesus is baptized, the Holy Spirit descends on Him in bodily form like a dove, and a voice from heaven says 'You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased,' and Luke traces Jesus' genealogy back through David and Abraham all the way to Adam, the son of God.
Luke 4: Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, is led into the wilderness where He is tempted by the devil forty days—to turn stones to bread, to worship Satan for authority over kingdoms, and to throw Himself from the temple—but Jesus resists each with Scripture. He returns to Galilee in the power of the Spirit and reads from Isaiah in the Nazareth synagogue: 'The Spirit of the Lord is on me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor,' declaring 'Today this scripture is fulfilled in your hearing.' When people take offense, He says a prophet is not accepted in his hometown, and they try to throw Him off a cliff, but He walks through the crowd and goes on His way, then casts out demons and heals many, including Peter's mother-in-law.
Luke 5: Jesus teaches from Simon's boat, then tells him to put out into deep water and let down nets, resulting in such a large catch the nets begin to break and boats nearly sink, and Simon Peter falls at Jesus' knees saying 'Go away from me, Lord; I am a sinful man!' Jesus says 'Don't be afraid; from now on you will fish for people,' and they leave everything to follow Him. Jesus heals a man with leprosy with a touch, then heals a paralyzed man lowered through the roof after forgiving his sins, demonstrating the Son of Man's authority to forgive sins on earth. He calls Levi the tax collector to follow Him, eats with tax collectors and sinners, and teaches that He came to call sinners to repentance, not the righteous, and that new wine must be poured into new wineskins.
Luke 6: On the Sabbath, Jesus' disciples pick grain and eat it, and Pharisees object, but Jesus declares the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath. He heals a man with a shriveled hand on the Sabbath, and the Pharisees are furious, then He chooses twelve apostles after praying all night. He delivers the Sermon on the Plain with beatitudes and woes: blessed are the poor, hungry, weeping, and persecuted, but woe to the rich, well-fed, laughing, and popular. He teaches to love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, turn the other cheek, give to everyone who asks, treat others as you want to be treated, be merciful as your Father is merciful, don't judge, forgive, give generously, and a tree is recognized by its fruit—why do you call Me 'Lord, Lord' but not do what I say?
Luke 7: Jesus heals a centurion's servant without going to the house, marveling at the centurion's faith—'I have not found such great faith even in Israel.' At Nain, He raises a widow's son from the dead, touching the coffin and saying 'Young man, I say to you, get up!' When John the Baptist's disciples ask if Jesus is the Messiah, Jesus points to His miracles and praises John as the greatest born of women. A sinful woman anoints Jesus' feet with perfume and tears at a Pharisee's house, and Jesus tells a parable about two debtors—the one forgiven more loves more—and declares to the woman 'Your sins are forgiven... Your faith has saved you; go in peace.'
Luke 8: Jesus travels proclaiming the good news of the kingdom with the Twelve and women who support them out of their means, including Mary Magdalene, Joanna, and Susanna. He teaches the parable of the sower and explains that seed on good soil represents those who hear the word, retain it, and produce a crop, and that nothing is hidden that won't be disclosed. He calms a storm on the lake, casts a legion of demons out of a man into pigs, heals a woman who touched His cloak after bleeding twelve years, and raises Jairus's daughter from death saying 'My child, get up!'
Luke 9: Jesus sends out the Twelve with power and authority to drive out demons and cure diseases, proclaiming the kingdom of God. Herod is perplexed about Jesus, having beheaded John, asking 'Who is this I hear such things about?' Jesus feeds five thousand with five loaves and two fish, then asks disciples who they say He is—Peter answers 'God's Messiah'—and Jesus predicts His death and resurrection, teaching that whoever wants to follow Him must deny themselves and take up their cross daily. He is transfigured on a mountain before Peter, James, and John, appearing in glorious splendor with Moses and Elijah, and the Father's voice declares 'This is my Son, whom I have chosen; listen to him!' He heals a demon-possessed boy, again predicts His betrayal, teaches that whoever is least is greatest, and resolutely sets out for Jerusalem.
Luke 10: Jesus sends out seventy-two disciples in pairs to every town He is about to visit, saying the harvest is plentiful but workers are few, and they return with joy reporting even demons submit to them in His name. Jesus rejoices in the Holy Spirit and says no one knows who the Son is except the Father, or who the Father is except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal Him. When a legal expert asks what he must do to inherit eternal life, Jesus tells the parable of the Good Samaritan—a Samaritan helps a beaten man after a priest and Levite pass by—showing that loving your neighbor means showing mercy. At Martha and Mary's home, Martha is distracted with preparations while Mary sits at Jesus' feet listening, and Jesus says 'Mary has chosen what is better.'
Luke 11: Jesus teaches the disciples to pray the Lord's Prayer, then tells a parable about a persistent friend asking for bread at midnight, teaching to ask and it will be given, seek and you will find, knock and the door will be opened. When accused of driving out demons by Beelzebul, He warns that a kingdom divided against itself falls, and when an impure spirit leaves a person, it returns with seven other spirits if the house remains empty. He pronounces woes on Pharisees and experts in the law for their hypocrisy—they love important seats, load people with burdens, neglect justice and God's love, and are like unmarked graves that people walk over without knowing it.
Luke 12: Jesus warns His disciples to beware of the yeast of the Pharisees—hypocrisy—for everything concealed will be disclosed. Don't be afraid of those who kill the body, but fear God who has authority to throw into hell, yet not one sparrow is forgotten by God and the hairs on your head are numbered. When the Holy Spirit comes on you, He will teach you what to say, so don't worry about what to eat, drink, or wear—life is more than food and body more than clothes—but seek His kingdom and these things will be given. Be ready, for the Son of Man will come at an unexpected hour like a thief in the night, and from everyone given much, much will be demanded.
Luke 13: Jesus warns that unless you repent, you will all perish, and tells a parable about a fig tree given one more year to bear fruit. He heals a crippled woman on the Sabbath, and when the synagogue leader objects, Jesus exposes the hypocrisy—don't you untie your ox on the Sabbath to give it water? He teaches parables about the kingdom—it's like a mustard seed that grows large, like yeast that works through dough—and warns to make every effort to enter through the narrow door, for many will try and not be able, and He will say 'I don't know you or where you come from. Away from me, all you evildoers!' He laments over Jerusalem who kills the prophets and stones those sent to her.
Luke 14: At a Pharisee's house, Jesus heals a man with abnormal swelling on the Sabbath, asking whether it's lawful to heal on the Sabbath or not, and they remain silent. He teaches about humility—don't take the place of honor at a banquet but take the lowest place—and when you give a banquet, invite the poor, crippled, lame, and blind who cannot repay you. He tells the parable of the great banquet where invited guests make excuses, so the master sends servants to bring in the poor, crippled, blind, and lame from the streets. He teaches about counting the cost of discipleship—anyone who doesn't carry their cross and follow Him cannot be His disciple—and warns that salt that loses saltiness is thrown out.
Luke 15: When tax collectors and sinners gather to hear Jesus, the Pharisees mutter 'This man welcomes sinners and eats with them,' so Jesus tells three parables about the lost: a shepherd leaves ninety-nine sheep to find one that is lost and rejoices when he finds it; a woman searches diligently for one lost coin and celebrates when she finds it; and a father welcomes home his prodigal son who squandered his inheritance but returned repentant, while the older brother is angry and refuses to join the celebration. In each, there is great rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents.
Luke 16: Jesus tells the parable of the shrewd manager who reduces debts to prepare for his future, teaching to use worldly wealth to gain friends so when it's gone you'll be welcomed into eternal dwellings, and whoever is faithful with little will be faithful with much. The Pharisees, who love money, sneer at Him, and He warns that what people value highly is detestable in God's sight. He teaches that the Law and Prophets point to the kingdom, and it's easier for heaven and earth to disappear than for the least stroke of the Law to drop out. He tells the parable of the rich man and Lazarus—the rich man feasts daily while Lazarus begs at his gate, and when both die, Lazarus is carried to Abraham's side but the rich man is in torment, and Abraham says if they don't listen to Moses and the Prophets, they won't be convinced even if someone rises from the dead.
Luke 17: Jesus teaches about sin, repentance, and faith: if your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him, even if he sins against you seven times in a day and returns repenting. If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree 'Be uprooted and planted in the sea' and it will obey. He heals ten men with leprosy, but only one—a Samaritan—returns to give thanks and praise God, and Jesus says 'Your faith has made you well.' He teaches that the kingdom of God is in your midst, and describes His return—people will be eating, drinking, buying, selling, planting, building, just like in Noah's and Lot's day—so remember Lot's wife and don't look back, for whoever tries to keep their life will lose it.
Luke 18: Jesus tells a parable about a persistent widow and an unjust judge to show that disciples should always pray and not give up, for if an unjust judge gives justice, how much more will God grant justice to His chosen ones who cry out day and night! He tells the parable of the Pharisee and tax collector praying—the Pharisee boasts of his righteousness, but the tax collector beats his breast saying 'God, have mercy on me, a sinner'—and Jesus declares the tax collector went home justified, for all who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted. He blesses little children, tells a rich ruler to sell all and follow Him, teaches it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for the rich to enter heaven, predicts His death and resurrection, and heals a blind beggar near Jericho.
Luke 19: In Jericho, Zacchaeus the chief tax collector climbs a sycamore tree to see Jesus, who looks up and says 'Come down immediately. I must stay at your house today,' and Zacchaeus receives Him joyfully and pledges to give half his possessions to the poor and pay back four times anything he cheated. Jesus declares 'Today salvation has come to this house... For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.' He tells the parable of ten minas given to servants to invest during the master's absence, then enters Jerusalem on a colt while crowds spread cloaks and shout 'Blessed is the king who comes in the name of the Lord!' He weeps over Jerusalem, knowing the days will come when enemies will encircle and destroy her because she didn't recognize the time of God's coming, then He cleanses the temple.
Luke 20: Religious leaders question Jesus' authority, and He asks them about John's baptism—was it from heaven or from human origin? When they won't answer, He won't tell them by what authority He acts. He tells the parable of the tenants who beat the owner's servants and kill his son, declaring the stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone. Teachers of the law try to trap Him with questions about paying taxes to Caesar ('Give back to Caesar what is Caesar's, and to God what is God's'), and Sadducees question Him about resurrection and marriage (those worthy to attain the resurrection neither marry nor can die, for they are like angels), then He asks them how David calls the Messiah 'Lord' if He is David's son, and warns against teachers of the law who devour widows' houses.
Luke 21: Jesus watches the rich putting gifts into the temple treasury, then sees a poor widow put in two small copper coins and declares she has put in more than all the others, for they gave out of their wealth but she out of her poverty gave all she had to live on. When disciples marvel at the temple's magnificent stones, He prophesies not one will be left on another. He describes signs before His return: false messiahs, wars, earthquakes, famines, persecutions, betrayals by family and friends, Jerusalem surrounded by armies, great distress, cosmic disturbances, and the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory. He teaches the parable of the fig tree—when it sprouts leaves you know summer is near—so when these things happen, know the kingdom of God is near.
Luke 22: The Festival of Unleavened Bread approaches, chief priests seek a way to kill Jesus, and Satan enters Judas who agrees to betray Him. At the Last Supper, Jesus institutes communion saying the bread is His body given for them and the cup is the new covenant in His blood poured out for them, and He predicts Peter will deny Him three times before the rooster crows. In great anguish on the Mount of Olives, He prays 'Father, if you are willing, take this cup from me; yet not my will, but yours be done,' and an angel strengthens Him as His sweat becomes like drops of blood. Judas betrays Him with a kiss, He heals the high priest's servant's ear, Peter denies Him three times, and the council condemns Him, mocking and beating Him and demanding 'If you are the Messiah, tell us.'
Luke 23: The assembly brings Jesus to Pilate, accusing Him of subverting the nation, opposing payment of taxes to Caesar, and claiming to be Messiah, a king. Pilate finds no basis for charges and sends Him to Herod who questions Him at length, but Jesus gives no answer, so Herod's soldiers mock Him and send Him back. Pilate declares he will punish and release Jesus, but the crowd shouts 'Crucify him! Crucify him!' demanding Barabbas instead. At Golgotha they crucify Jesus between two criminals, and Jesus says 'Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing.' One criminal mocks Him, but the other asks to be remembered, and Jesus promises 'Today you will be with me in paradise.' At noon darkness covers the land until 3 PM when Jesus calls out 'Father, into your hands I commit my spirit' and breathes His last, the temple curtain tears in two, and the centurion praises God saying 'Surely this was a righteous man.'
Luke 24: On the first day of the week, women go to the tomb with spices but find the stone rolled away and the body gone, and two men in gleaming clothes ask 'Why do you look for the living among the dead? He is not here; he has risen!' On the road to Emmaus, Jesus walks with two disciples explaining how the Messiah had to suffer these things according to the Scriptures, and when He breaks bread with them their eyes are opened and they recognize Him, then He vanishes. He appears to the disciples in Jerusalem, shows them His hands and feet, eats fish, opens their minds to understand the Scriptures, and commissions them to preach repentance for the forgiveness of sins to all nations beginning in Jerusalem. He leads them to Bethany, blesses them, and is taken up into heaven, and they return to Jerusalem with great joy, continually praising God in the temple.
John 1: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God—through Him all things were made, and in Him was life, the light of all mankind. John the Baptist testifies he is not the Messiah but came to prepare the way, and when he sees Jesus, he declares 'Look, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!' and 'I have seen and testify that this is God's Chosen One.' Andrew follows Jesus and brings his brother Simon (whom Jesus calls Peter), then Philip finds Nathanael and brings him to Jesus who says 'Here truly is an Israelite in whom there is no deceit,' and when Nathanael asks how Jesus knows him, Jesus says He saw him under the fig tree, and Nathanael declares 'Rabbi, you are the Son of God; you are the king of Israel.'
John 2: At a wedding in Cana, Jesus turns water into wine in His first sign, revealing His glory, and His disciples believe in Him. He goes to Jerusalem for Passover, makes a whip of cords, and drives out those selling cattle, sheep, and doves from the temple courts, overturning money changers' tables and declaring 'Stop turning my Father's house into a market!' When Jews demand a sign, He says 'Destroy this temple, and I will raise it again in three days,' speaking of His body. Many believe in His name when they see His signs, but Jesus doesn't entrust Himself to them because He knows what is in each person.
John 3: Nicodemus, a Pharisee, comes to Jesus at night, and Jesus tells him 'Very truly I tell you, no one can see the kingdom of God unless they are born again,' explaining that flesh gives birth to flesh but the Spirit gives birth to spirit. He declares 'Just as Moses lifted up the snake in the wilderness, so the Son of Man must be lifted up, that everyone who believes may have eternal life in him,' and speaks the famous words: 'For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.' John the Baptist rejoices that Jesus is increasing while he decreases, testifying that whoever believes in the Son has eternal life, but whoever rejects the Son will not see life.
John 4: At Jacob's well in Samaria, Jesus asks a Samaritan woman for water and tells her about living water that becomes a spring welling up to eternal life. When she mentions she has no husband, Jesus reveals He knows she has had five husbands and the man she's with now is not her husband, and she recognizes Him as a prophet. He declares that true worshipers will worship the Father in Spirit and in truth, and when she mentions the Messiah, Jesus says 'I, the one speaking to you—I am he.'
