Many Samaritans believe because of the woman's testimony, and after staying two days, many more believe because of His words. In Galilee, Jesus heals a royal official's son from a distance, and the official and his whole household believe.
John 5: At the pool of Bethesda, Jesus heals a man who had been an invalid for thirty-eight years, telling him 'Get up! Pick up your mat and walk,' and he is instantly cured. Because Jesus does this on the Sabbath, Jewish leaders persecute Him, but Jesus says 'My Father is always at his work to this very day, and I too am working,' making Himself equal with God. He declares the Son gives life to whom He is pleased to give it, the Father has entrusted all judgment to the Son, whoever hears His word and believes has eternal life and has crossed over from death to life, and a time is coming when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God and come out—those who have done good to resurrection of life, and those who have done evil to resurrection of judgment.
John 6: Jesus feeds five thousand with a boy's five loaves and two fish, and the people want to make Him king by force, but He withdraws. He walks on water to the disciples' boat, and the next day when the crowd finds Him, He says they're looking for Him not because of signs but because they ate the loaves and had their fill—don't work for food that spoils, but for food that endures to eternal life. He declares 'I am the bread of life. Whoever comes to me will never go hungry, and whoever believes in me will never be thirsty,' and 'I am the living bread that came down from heaven. Whoever eats this bread will live forever. This bread is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.' Many disciples turn back, and Jesus asks the Twelve if they want to leave too, but Peter responds 'Lord, to whom shall we go? You have the words of eternal life.'
John 7: Jesus goes to Jerusalem for the Festival of Tabernacles and teaches in the temple courts, and people are divided about Him—some believing He is the Messiah, others questioning how the Messiah could come from Galilee. Nicodemus defends Him, asking if their law condemns a man without first hearing him, but the Pharisees reply 'Are you from Galilee, too? Look into it, and you will find that a prophet does not come out of Galilee.' On the last and greatest day of the festival, Jesus stands and cries out 'Let anyone who is thirsty come to me and drink. Whoever believes in me, as Scripture has said, rivers of living water will flow from within them,' speaking about the Spirit.
John 8: Teachers of the law bring a woman caught in adultery, testing Jesus about whether to stone her, but He bends down and writes on the ground, then says 'Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her,' and one by one they leave, and He tells her 'Neither do I condemn you. Go now and leave your life of sin.' Jesus declares 'I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life,' and 'Before Abraham was born, I am!' causing the Jews to pick up stones to stone Him for blasphemy, but He hides and slips away from the temple grounds.
John 9: Jesus sees a man blind from birth, spits on the ground, makes mud, puts it on the man's eyes, and tells him to wash in the Pool of Siloam—he goes, washes, and comes home seeing. Pharisees investigate, questioning the man and his parents, and they throw him out when he defends Jesus, asking 'Do you want to become his disciples too?' Jesus finds him and asks 'Do you believe in the Son of Man?' and when the man asks who He is, Jesus says 'You have now seen him; in fact, he is the one speaking with you,' and the man worships Him. Jesus declares He came into this world for judgment so the blind will see and those who see will become blind.
John 10: Jesus declares 'I am the gate for the sheep'—whoever enters through Him will be saved, will come in and go out and find pasture, for the thief comes to steal, kill, and destroy, but He came that they may have life and have it abundantly. He says 'I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep,' and 'I have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd.' At the Festival of Dedication, Jews surround Him demanding He tell them plainly if He is the Messiah, and He says 'I and the Father are one,' and they pick up stones to stone Him for blasphemy, but He escapes their grasp.
John 11: When Jesus hears Lazarus is sick, He stays where He is two more days, then goes to Bethany where Lazarus has been dead four days. Martha comes to meet Him saying 'Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died,' and Jesus declares 'I am the resurrection and the life. The one who believes in me will live, even though they die; and whoever lives by believing in me will never die. Do you believe this?' She responds 'Yes, Lord, I believe that you are the Messiah, the Son of God.' At the tomb, Jesus prays, then calls 'Lazarus, come out!' and the dead man comes out wrapped in grave clothes, and many Jews believe in Him, but the chief priests and Pharisees plot to kill Him.
John 12: Six days before Passover, Mary anoints Jesus' feet with expensive perfume and wipes them with her hair, and when Judas objects, Jesus says 'Leave her alone. It was intended that she should save this perfume for the day of my burial. You will always have the poor among you, but you will not always have me.' Jesus enters Jerusalem on a young donkey, and crowds shout 'Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!' He declares the hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified—unless a kernel of wheat falls to the ground and dies, it remains only a single seed, but if it dies, it produces many seeds. A voice from heaven speaks, and Jesus says 'Now is the time for judgment on this world; now the prince of this world will be driven out. And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all people to myself.'
John 13: Before the Passover Festival, Jesus knows the hour has come to leave this world and go to the Father, so He rises from the meal, wraps a towel around His waist, and washes His disciples' feet, teaching them to serve one another as He has served them. He predicts His betrayal—'Very truly I tell you, one of you is going to betray me'—and when Judas takes the bread Jesus gives him, Satan enters him, and Jesus says 'What you are about to do, do quickly,' and Judas goes out into the night. Jesus gives a new command: 'Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another. By this everyone will know that you are my disciples, if you love one another,' and He predicts Peter will deny Him three times before the rooster crows.
John 14: Jesus comforts the troubled disciples: 'Do not let your hearts be troubled. You believe in God; believe also in me. My Father's house has many rooms... I am going there to prepare a place for you... I will come back and take you to be with me.' He declares 'I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me,' and 'Anyone who has seen me has seen the Father.' He promises to send the Advocate, the Holy Spirit, who will teach them all things and remind them of everything He has said, and He gives them His peace, not as the world gives—'Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid.'
John 15: Jesus teaches 'I am the true vine, and my Father is the gardener'—every branch that bears fruit He prunes to make it more fruitful, and branches that don't remain in the vine are thrown away and burned. 'Remain in me, as I also remain in you. No branch can bear fruit by itself; it must remain in the vine. Neither can you bear fruit unless you remain in me. I am the vine; you are the branches.' He commands them to love each other as He has loved them—greater love has no one than this: to lay down one's life for one's friends. He warns they will be hated by the world because they are not of the world, just as the world hated Him first, and He will send the Advocate, the Spirit of truth.
John 16: Jesus warns that a time is coming when anyone who kills them will think they are offering service to God, but He tells them these things so when their time comes they will remember He warned them. It's for their good that He goes away, for unless He goes, the Advocate won't come, but when He goes, He will send the Spirit who will guide them into all truth. He speaks of a woman in labor having pain but forgetting the anguish in joy that a child is born—'So with you: Now is your time of grief, but I will see you again and you will rejoice, and no one will take away your joy.' In a little while they won't see Him, then after a little while they will, and He declares 'I have told you these things, so that in me you may have peace. In this world you will have trouble. But take heart! I have overcome the world.'
John 17: Jesus looks toward heaven and prays: 'Father, the hour has come. Glorify your Son, that your Son may glorify you,' and 'Now this is eternal life: that they know you, the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom you have sent.' He prays for His disciples: 'I have revealed you to those whom you gave me out of the world... Sanctify them by the truth; your word is truth... As you sent me into the world, I have sent them into the world.' He prays for all believers: 'I pray also for those who will believe in me through their message, that all of them may be one, Father, just as you are in me and I am in you... Father, I want those you have given me to be with me where I am, and to see my glory.'
John 18: In the garden across the Kidron Valley, Judas brings soldiers and officials to arrest Jesus, and when Jesus says 'I am he,' they draw back and fall to the ground. Peter draws his sword and cuts off the high priest's servant's ear, but Jesus tells him to put it away—'Shall I not drink the cup the Father has given me?' Annas questions Jesus who refers him to His public teaching, and when an official strikes Jesus for answering that way, Jesus asks 'If I said something wrong, testify as to what is wrong. But if I spoke the truth, why did you strike me?' Meanwhile, Peter denies Jesus three times, and the rooster crows. Pilate questions Jesus who says His kingdom is not of this world, and when Pilate asks 'What is truth?' he finds no basis for charges, but the crowd demands Barabbas.
John 19: Pilate has Jesus flogged, and soldiers twist a crown of thorns, put it on His head, dress Him in a purple robe, and strike Him. Pilate brings Jesus out wearing the crown, saying 'Here is the man!' but chief priests shout 'Crucify! Crucify!' When they claim 'We have a law, and according to that law he must die, because he claimed to be the Son of God,' Pilate is even more afraid, but when they say 'If you let this man go, you are no friend of Caesar,' Pilate hands Him over. At Golgotha they crucify Jesus with two others, and above His head Pilate places a sign: JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWS. From the cross, Jesus entrusts His mother to John's care, then says 'I am thirsty' and 'It is finished,' and bows His head and gives up His spirit. Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus take His body and wrap it with myrrh and aloes, laying Him in a new tomb.
John 20: Early on the first day of the week while it is still dark, Mary Magdalene finds the stone removed from the tomb and runs to tell Peter and John who run to the tomb and find the linen cloths but no body. Mary stays weeping outside, and when she looks in, two angels ask why she's crying, then Jesus appears and says 'Mary,' and she turns crying 'Rabboni!' He tells her to go tell the disciples 'I am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.' That evening Jesus appears to the disciples, shows them His hands and side, breathes on them saying 'Receive the Holy Spirit,' and gives them authority to forgive sins. Thomas isn't there and says he won't believe unless he sees the nail marks, but a week later Jesus appears and tells Thomas 'Put your finger here; see my hands. Reach out your hand and put it into my side. Stop doubting and believe,' and Thomas declares 'My Lord and my God!'
John 21: At the Sea of Galilee, Peter and six other disciples fish all night but catch nothing, then Jesus appears on shore at dawn and tells them to throw the net on the right side—they catch 153 large fish and the net doesn't break. After eating breakfast, Jesus asks Peter three times 'Do you love me?' and each time tells him 'Feed my lambs,' 'Take care of my sheep,' 'Feed my sheep,' restoring Peter after his three denials. He predicts how Peter will die glorifying God, and when Peter asks about John's fate, Jesus says 'If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you? You must follow me.' John closes declaring there are many other things Jesus did—if every one were written down, the whole world would not have room for the books.
Acts 1: After His resurrection, Jesus appears to the apostles for forty days teaching about the kingdom of God, then commands them to wait in Jerusalem for the Holy Spirit who will empower them to be His witnesses to the ends of the earth. He is taken up into heaven, and the apostles return to Jerusalem where they pray together and choose Matthias to replace Judas among the Twelve.
Acts 2: On Pentecost, the Holy Spirit fills the believers with a rushing wind and tongues of fire, enabling them to speak in other languages so visiting Jews from every nation hear God's wonders in their own tongues. Peter preaches that Jesus, whom they crucified, has been raised and exalted by God as both Lord and Messiah, and 3,000 people believe, are baptized, and devote themselves to the apostles' teaching, fellowship, breaking of bread, and prayer.
Acts 3: Peter heals a lame beggar at the temple gate in Jesus' name, and when crowds gather amazed, Peter preaches that they killed the author of life but God raised Him from the dead. He calls them to repent and turn to God so their sins may be wiped out.
Acts 4: The priests and Sadducees arrest Peter and John, but 5,000 who heard the message believe. When questioned by the Sanhedrin, Peter boldly declares salvation is found in no one else but Jesus, and though ordered not to speak in His name, they reply they must obey God rather than men.
Acts 5: Ananias and Sapphira lie about their giving and both drop dead when exposed by Peter, striking fear in the church. The apostles perform many miracles, are arrested but freed by an angel, and when brought before the Sanhedrin again, they declare they must obey God rather than men, receiving a flogging but rejoicing they were counted worthy to suffer for the Name.
Acts 6: When Grecian widows are overlooked in daily distribution, the apostles appoint seven men including Stephen and Philip to serve tables so they can focus on prayer and the word. Stephen performs great wonders and signs, but members of the Synagogue of the Freedmen bring false charges that he speaks against Moses and the temple.
Acts 7: Stephen delivers a lengthy sermon recounting Israel's history of resisting God, from Abraham through Moses to Solomon, concluding that they are stiff-necked people who always resist the Holy Spirit just like their ancestors. As they stone him to death, he sees Jesus standing at God's right hand and prays 'Lord, do not hold this sin against them,' while Saul approves of his execution.
Acts 8: Persecution scatters believers throughout Judea and Samaria, and Philip preaches in Samaria with great signs and joy. The Spirit directs Philip to an Ethiopian eunuch reading Isaiah, Philip explains the gospel about Jesus, and the eunuch believes and is baptized.
Acts 9: On the road to Damascus to arrest believers, Saul encounters the risen Jesus in a blinding light and hears 'Saul, why do you persecute me?' Ananias restores his sight, Saul is baptized and filled with the Holy Spirit, then immediately begins preaching in synagogues that Jesus is the Son of God, astonishing everyone who knew him as a persecutor.
Acts 10: God gives Peter a vision of unclean animals with a voice saying 'Do not call anything impure that God has made clean,' preparing him to go to the Gentile Cornelius's house. While Peter preaches about Jesus, the Holy Spirit falls on all the Gentiles present, and Peter has them baptized, realizing God shows no favoritism but accepts people from every nation.
Acts 11: When criticized for eating with Gentiles, Peter explains his vision and how the Spirit came on the Gentiles just as on the apostles, silencing objections and leading believers to praise God for granting even Gentiles repentance unto life. In Antioch, many Greeks believe and turn to the Lord, Barnabas rejoices at God's grace, and he brings Saul to teach for a year—the disciples are first called Christians there.
Acts 12: Herod executes James and imprisons Peter, but an angel frees Peter from prison the night before his trial while believers are praying for him. When Peter appears at Mary's house and knocks, the servant girl Rhoda is so excited she forgets to open the door, and when Herod delivers a speech accepting worship as a god, an angel strikes him down and he dies eaten by worms.
Acts 13: The Holy Spirit sets apart Barnabas and Saul for missionary work, and they preach in synagogues that Jesus is the Messiah through whom everyone who believes receives forgiveness and justification. When Jews reject their message, Paul and Barnabas boldly turn to the Gentiles, and many believe.
Acts 14: In Lystra, Paul heals a lame man and the crowd thinks they are gods, trying to sacrifice to them, but Jews from other cities stone Paul and drag him outside the city. He gets up, returns to the city, then they continue preaching, strengthening disciples, appointing elders, and committing them to the Lord.
Acts 15: The Jerusalem Council addresses whether Gentiles must be circumcised to be saved, and Peter declares God gave the Holy Spirit to Gentiles just as to Jews, purifying their hearts by faith. The council decides not to burden Gentiles with the law except to abstain from idols, sexual immorality, strangled animals, and blood, and Paul and Barnabas part ways over taking John Mark.
Acts 16: Paul has a vision of a Macedonian man begging 'Come help us,' so they go to Philippi where Lydia believes and is baptized with her household. After Paul casts a spirit out of a slave girl, her owners have Paul and Silas beaten and imprisoned, but an earthquake opens the prison doors, and the jailer and his household believe and are baptized.
Acts 17: In Thessalonica, some believe but other Jews form a mob, so Paul goes to Berea where people examine the Scriptures daily and many believe. In Athens, Paul preaches to philosophers about the unknown God who made the world and appointed a day of judgment through the man He raised from the dead.
Acts 18: Paul stays in Corinth for eighteen months working as a tentmaker with Aquila and Priscilla and testifying that Jesus is the Messiah. When opposed by Jews, he declares he will go to the Gentiles, and many Corinthians believe and are baptized.
Acts 19: In Ephesus, Paul teaches daily in the lecture hall of Tyrannus for two years, and God does extraordinary miracles through him. When some Jewish exorcists try to use Jesus' name, a demon-possessed man attacks them, and many who practiced sorcery publicly burn their scrolls, but a riot breaks out when a silversmith claims Paul threatens their Artemis worship.
Acts 20: In Troas, Eutychus falls from a third-story window during Paul's lengthy message and dies, but Paul raises him back to life. Paul meets the Ephesian elders at Miletus and delivers a moving farewell, warning them to guard the flock and remember Jesus said 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'
Acts 21: Despite prophetic warnings that he will be bound and handed over to Gentiles, Paul is determined to go to Jerusalem. In the temple, Jews from Asia stir up a crowd against him, drag him out, and try to kill him, but Roman soldiers rescue him and allow him to address the crowd.
Acts 22: Paul recounts his background as a zealous Pharisee who persecuted Christians, his encounter with Jesus on the Damascus road, and how the Lord sent him to the Gentiles. When he mentions Gentiles, the crowd erupts demanding his death, and the commander orders him flogged until learning Paul is a Roman citizen.
Acts 23: Paul divides the Sanhedrin by declaring he's on trial for believing in resurrection, causing Pharisees and Sadducees to argue. The Lord appears to Paul that night saying 'Take courage! As you testified about me in Jerusalem, so you must testify in Rome,' and when Paul's nephew warns of an assassination plot, the commander sends Paul under heavy guard to Governor Felix.
Acts 24: Jewish leaders present charges before Felix, accusing Paul of being a troublemaker and sect leader who tried to desecrate the temple. Paul defends himself as a follower of the Way who believes in the resurrection of both righteous and wicked, and Felix keeps him in custody for two years.
Acts 25: When the new governor Festus asks Paul to stand trial in Jerusalem, Paul appeals to Caesar, saying he has done nothing wrong to the Jews. King Agrippa arrives and expresses interest in hearing Paul's case.
Acts 26: Paul recounts his conversion before King Agrippa, explaining how Jesus commissioned him to open Gentiles' eyes so they may turn from darkness to light and from Satan to God. When Festus says Paul's learning is driving him insane, Paul insists he speaks truth, and Agrippa says 'Do you think you can persuade me to be a Christian in such a short time?'
Acts 27: Sailing to Rome, Paul's ship encounters a violent storm called the Northeaster, and after days without seeing sun or stars, all hope seems lost. An angel assures Paul that he must stand before Caesar and God will spare all 276 people on board, and they run aground on Malta where everyone reaches land safely.
Acts 28: On Malta, a viper bites Paul but he suffers no harm, and he heals many including the chief official's father. After three months they sail to Rome where Paul is allowed to live under house arrest, preaching the kingdom of God and teaching about Jesus boldly and without hindrance for two years.
Romans 1: Paul declares he is not ashamed of the gospel because it is God's power bringing salvation to everyone who believes, revealing a righteousness by faith from first to last. He describes how people suppressed the truth about God evident in creation, exchanged His glory for idols, and were given over to shameful lusts and depraved minds filled with every kind of wickedness.
Romans 2: Paul warns that when you judge others while doing the same things, you condemn yourself and will not escape God's judgment, for He will repay each person according to what they have done. True circumcision is not merely outward and physical but circumcision of the heart by the Spirit, and a true Jew is one inwardly.
Romans 3: All are under sin—there is no one righteous, not even one—and no one will be declared righteous by observing the law. But now God's righteousness has been revealed through faith in Jesus Christ to all who believe, for all have sinned and fall short of God's glory, yet are justified freely by His grace through the redemption in Christ Jesus.
Romans 4: Abraham believed God and it was credited to him as righteousness—not by works but by faith—and this was before he was circumcised, making him the father of all who believe. The words 'it was credited to him' were written not only for Abraham but also for us who believe in Him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.
Romans 5: Since we are justified by faith, we have peace with God through Jesus Christ and rejoice in hope of God's glory, and even in suffering which produces perseverance, character, and hope. God demonstrates His love in this: while we were still sinners, Christ died for us, and just as one trespass brought condemnation to all, one righteous act brought justification and life to all.
Romans 6: Shall we go on sinning so grace may increase? By no means! We died to sin—how can we live in it any longer? We were buried with Christ through baptism into death so we too may live a new life, and we must count ourselves dead to sin but alive to God in Christ Jesus.
Romans 7: The law has authority over someone only as long as they live, and we have been released from the law by dying to what once bound us so we serve in the new way of the Spirit. The law is holy and good, but sin used it to produce death in me, and what I want to do I do not do, but what I hate I do—what a wretched man I am! Who will rescue me from this body of death? Thanks be to God, who delivers me through Jesus Christ our Lord.
Romans 8: There is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus, because through Him the Spirit of life has set you free from the law of sin and death. The Spirit testifies with our spirit that we are God's children, heirs with Christ who share in His sufferings and glory, and in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, and if God is for us, who can be against us? Neither death nor life, angels nor demons, present nor future, height nor depth, nor anything in all creation can separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Romans 9: Paul has great sorrow for his fellow Israelites who have the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the law, and the promises, yet not all Israel are truly Israel. God has mercy on whom He wants to have mercy, and whom He wants to harden, He hardens, for He says to Pharaoh 'I raised you up for this very purpose, that I might display my power in you.'
Romans 10: Israel pursued righteousness by works rather than by faith, stumbling over the stumbling stone, but Christ is the culmination of the law so that there may be righteousness for everyone who believes. If you declare with your mouth 'Jesus is Lord' and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved, for everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved, and how can they call on Him without believing, or believe without hearing, or hear without someone preaching?
Romans 11: God did not reject His people Israel, for there is always a remnant chosen by grace, and Israel's transgression means salvation for the Gentiles to make Israel envious. Do not be arrogant toward the branches that were broken off, for if God did not spare the natural branches, He will not spare you either, and oh, the depth of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God—how unsearchable His judgments and unfathomable His ways!
Romans 12: Offer your bodies as living sacrifices, holy and pleasing to God, and be transformed by the renewing of your mind. We have different gifts according to the grace given—prophecy, serving, teaching, encouraging, giving, leading, showing mercy—so use them faithfully. Love must be sincere, hate what is evil, be devoted to one another, never be lacking in zeal, be joyful in hope, patient in affliction, bless those who persecute you, live in harmony, and do not be overcome by evil but overcome evil with good.
Romans 13: Everyone must submit to governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established, and the authorities are God's servants for your good. Love fulfills the law, for love does no harm to a neighbor, and the hour has already come for you to wake from slumber—the night is nearly over and the day is almost here, so clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ.
Romans 14: Accept the one whose faith is weak without quarreling over disputable matters, for one person's faith allows them to eat anything while another eats only vegetables. Each one should be fully convinced in their own mind, for we will all stand before God's judgment seat, so stop passing judgment on one another and make up your mind not to put any stumbling block in the way of a brother or sister.
Romans 15: We who are strong ought to bear with the failings of the weak and not please ourselves, for even Christ did not please Himself. Paul explains his ministry as a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, priestly duty of proclaiming the gospel so the Gentiles might become an offering acceptable to God, and he plans to visit Rome on his way to Spain after delivering a contribution to the poor in Jerusalem.
Romans 16: Paul commends Phoebe, a deaconess, and sends greetings to many believers including Priscilla and Aquila, Mary, Andronicus and Junia, and others who have worked hard in the Lord. He warns about those who cause divisions contrary to the teaching and urges them to be wise about what is good and innocent about what is evil, then closes with a doxology praising God who is able to strengthen them according to the gospel and the mystery now revealed through the prophetic writings.
1 Corinthians 1: Paul addresses the church in Corinth, thanking God for the grace given them in Christ Jesus, but appeals to them to agree with one another and not be divided, for some say 'I follow Paul,' others 'I follow Apollos' or 'I follow Cephas' or 'I follow Christ.' He declares he was sent not to baptize but to preach the gospel—not with wisdom and eloquence lest the cross be emptied of its power—for the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing but the power of God to those being saved.
1 Corinthians 2: Paul came to Corinth in weakness and fear, resolving to know nothing except Jesus Christ and Him crucified, so their faith might not rest on human wisdom but on God's power. We speak God's wisdom, a mystery hidden but revealed to us by the Spirit, for 'What no eye has seen, what no ear has heard, what no human mind has conceived'—these things God has prepared for those who love Him, and the person without the Spirit does not accept the things of the Spirit for they are foolishness to them.
1 Corinthians 3: Paul could not address them as people of the Spirit but as worldly—mere infants in Christ—for they are still acting like mere humans with jealousy and quarreling. He and Apollos are merely servants through whom they believed—Paul planted, Apollos watered, but God made it grow, and they are God's field and building, so let each one be careful how they build on the foundation of Jesus Christ.
1 Corinthians 4: People ought to regard apostles as servants of Christ and stewards of God's mysteries, faithful in their trust, and Paul cares very little if he is judged by them or any human court. The apostles have become a spectacle—fools for Christ, weak, dishonored, hungry, thirsty, brutally treated, and homeless—yet when cursed, they bless, when persecuted, they endure, and he appeals to them to imitate him as their father in Christ Jesus.
1 Corinthians 5: Paul rebukes the church for tolerating sexual immorality—a man has his father's wife—that doesn't even occur among pagans, and they should hand this man over to Satan so his spirit may be saved. He instructs them not to associate with sexually immoral people who call themselves believers, quoting 'A little yeast works through the whole batch of dough' and 'Expel the wicked person from among you.'
1 Corinthians 6: When you have a dispute with another believer, how dare you take it before the ungodly for judgment instead of before the Lord's people who will judge the world? Don't you know your bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, so you are not your own—you were bought at a price, therefore honor God with your bodies.
1 Corinthians 7: Concerning matters you wrote about, it is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman, but since sexual immorality is occurring, each man should have his own wife, and the wife does not have authority over her own body but her husband does. To the unmarried and widows Paul says it is good to stay as he is, but if they cannot control themselves, they should marry, for it is better to marry than to burn with passion, and he gives instructions about marriage, divorce, and remaining as you were when called.
1 Corinthians 8: Concerning food sacrificed to idols, 'We know that an idol is nothing' and 'We all possess knowledge,' but knowledge puffs up while love builds up. Be careful that the exercise of your rights does not become a stumbling block to the weak, for when you sin against them and wound their weak conscience, you sin against Christ.
1 Corinthians 9: Am I not free? Am I not an apostle? Paul defends his apostolic authority and right to financial support but says he has not used these rights, choosing instead to preach the gospel free of charge. He has become all things to all people so that by all possible means he might save some, and he disciplines his body making it his slave so that after preaching to others, he himself will not be disqualified.
1 Corinthians 10: Paul warns them not to be idolaters like their ancestors in the wilderness who were judged despite experiencing miracles. These things happened as examples to keep us from setting our hearts on evil, and when tempted, God will provide a way out so you can endure it, so flee from idolatry, and whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God.
1 Corinthians 11: Paul addresses head coverings in worship, explaining man is the head of woman as Christ is the head of man. He rebukes them for divisions at the Lord's Supper where some go hungry while others get drunk, and he recounts the institution of the Lord's Supper, warning that those who eat and drink without recognizing the body eat and drink judgment on themselves.
1 Corinthians 12: There are different gifts but the same Spirit, different kinds of service but the same Lord, and to each is given the manifestation of the Spirit for the common good. The body is a unit though made of many parts, and God has placed each part just as He wanted, so you are the body of Christ and each one is a part, and now I will show you the most excellent way.
1 Corinthians 13: If I speak in tongues but have not love, I am only a resounding gong; if I have faith that can move mountains but have not love, I am nothing. Love is patient and kind, does not envy or boast, is not proud or dishonest, keeps no record of wrongs, always protects, trusts, hopes, and perseveres, and now these three remain: faith, hope and love, but the greatest of these is love.
1 Corinthians 14: Follow the way of love and eagerly desire gifts of the Spirit, especially prophecy, for those who speak in a tongue edify themselves but those who prophesy edify the church. Paul would rather speak five intelligible words to instruct others than ten thousand words in a tongue, for God is not a God of disorder but of peace, so everything should be done in a fitting and orderly way.
1 Corinthians 15: Paul reminds them of the gospel—that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures, was buried, was raised on the third day, and appeared to many including him, the least of the apostles. If Christ has not been raised, our preaching is useless and so is your faith, but Christ has indeed been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep, and just as we have borne the image of the earthly man, we will bear the image of the heavenly man, for the dead will be raised imperishable and we will be changed.
1 Corinthians 16: Concerning the collection for the Lord's people, on the first day of every week each should set aside a sum according to your income. Paul plans to visit after passing through Macedonia and may spend winter with them, and he sends greetings from the churches in Asia, Aquila and Priscilla, and all the brothers and sisters, closing with 'My love to all of you in Christ Jesus.'
2 Corinthians 1: Paul thanks God who comforts us in all our troubles so we can comfort those in any trouble with the comfort we ourselves receive from God. He explains why he changed his travel plans—it was to spare them and not because he is fickle, for as surely as God is faithful, his message is not 'Yes' and 'No,' and it is God who makes us stand firm in Christ, anoints us, and puts His Spirit in our hearts as a deposit.
2 Corinthians 2: Paul decided not to make another painful visit but wrote with tears, not to grieve them but to let them know the depth of his love. He urges them to forgive and comfort the offender so Satan will not outwit them, for when he came to Troas and Titus wasn't there, he had no peace of mind, but thanks be to God who always leads us as captives in Christ's triumphal procession and uses us to spread the aroma of the knowledge of Him everywhere.
2 Corinthians 3: Are we beginning to commend ourselves again? You yourselves are our letter, written on our hearts, known and read by everyone, a letter from Christ written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God. We are ministers of a new covenant—not of the letter but of the Spirit, for the letter kills but the Spirit gives life, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom, and we are being transformed into His image with ever-increasing glory.
2 Corinthians 4: Since we have this ministry, we do not lose heart, for we do not preach ourselves but Jesus Christ as Lord, and God has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of His glory. We have this treasure in jars of clay to show that this all-surpassing power is from God and not from us, and though outwardly we are wasting away, inwardly we are being renewed day by day, for our light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory that far outweighs them all.
2 Corinthians 5: We know that if our earthly tent is destroyed, we have a building from God, an eternal house in heaven, and we live by faith, not by sight. For Christ's love compels us, because He died for all so those who live should no longer live for themselves but for Him, and if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come—the old has gone, the new is here! God reconciled us to Himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation, so we are Christ's ambassadors, as though God were making His appeal through us: Be reconciled to God.
2 Corinthians 6: As God's co-workers we urge you not to receive God's grace in vain, for now is the time of God's favor, now is the day of salvation. We put no stumbling block in anyone's path, but as servants of God we commend ourselves through great endurance in troubles, hardships, and distresses, and we open wide our hearts to you, so do not be yoked together with unbelievers, for what fellowship can light have with darkness?
2 Corinthians 7: Since we have these promises, let us purify ourselves from everything that contaminates body and spirit, perfecting holiness out of reverence for God. Paul rejoices that his previous letter brought them to repentance—not that they were made sorry but that their sorrow led to repentance, for godly sorrow brings repentance that leads to salvation, and Titus's spirit was refreshed by them all.
2 Corinthians 8: Paul urges the Corinthians to excel in the grace of giving, following the example of the Macedonian churches who gave beyond their ability despite extreme poverty. He reminds them that Christ became poor so that through His poverty they might become rich, and he is sending Titus and others to complete their generous gift so it will be ready, for each of you should give what you have decided in your heart to give.
2 Corinthians 9: Whoever sows sparingly will reap sparingly, and whoever sows generously will reap generously, so each should give what they have decided in their heart, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver. God is able to bless you abundantly so you will abound in every good work, and thanks be to God for His indescribable gift!
2 Corinthians 10: Paul appeals by the meekness and gentleness of Christ, defending his boldness—though we live in the world, we do not wage war as the world does, for the weapons we fight with have divine power to demolish strongholds. We will not boast beyond proper limits but will confine our boasting to the sphere of service God assigned to us, and let the one who boasts boast in the Lord.
2 Corinthians 11: I am jealous for you with a godly jealousy, for I promised you to one husband, to Christ, but I fear that just as Eve was deceived, your minds may be led astray. Paul defends his apostleship against false apostles who masquerade as apostles of Christ, and he recounts his sufferings—imprisonments, floggings, stonings, shipwrecks, dangers from rivers and bandits, sleepless nights, hunger and thirst—and besides everything else, he faces daily the pressure of his concern for all the churches.
2 Corinthians 12: Paul was caught up to the third heaven and heard inexpressible things, but to keep him from becoming conceited, he was given a thorn in his flesh. Three times he pleaded with the Lord to take it away, but God said 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness,' so Paul boasts in his weaknesses that Christ's power may rest on him.
2 Corinthians 13: This is my third visit to you, and every matter must be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses, so examine yourselves to see whether you are in the faith. Paul prays they will not do anything wrong and that they will be fully restored, and he closes: May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.
Galatians 1: Paul expresses astonishment that the Galatians are deserting the gospel for a different gospel, declaring that even if an angel from heaven preaches another gospel, let them be under God's curse. He explains he received his gospel not from any man but by revelation from Jesus Christ, and God set him apart from birth to preach Christ among the Gentiles.
Galatians 2: Paul recounts confronting Peter in Antioch for withdrawing from eating with Gentiles, declaring that a person is not justified by works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ. He proclaims 'I have been crucified with Christ and I no longer live, but Christ lives in me.'
Galatians 3: Paul rebukes the foolish Galatians, asking whether they received the Spirit by works of the law or by believing what they heard. Just as Abraham believed God and it was credited to him as righteousness, those who have faith are children of Abraham, and Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law.
Galatians 4: When the set time had fully come, God sent His Son to redeem those under the law so we might receive adoption as sons. Paul uses the allegory of Sarah and Hagar to show that we are children of the free woman, not of slavery under the law.
Galatians 5: Christ has set us free, so stand firm and do not let yourselves be burdened again by a yoke of slavery through circumcision. The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control.
Galatians 6: Brothers and sisters, if someone is caught in sin, restore that person gently and carry each other's burdens, fulfilling the law of Christ. Do not be deceived—a man reaps what he sows, so let us not become weary in doing good.
Ephesians 1: Paul praises God who has blessed us in Christ with every spiritual blessing, choosing us before the foundation of the world to be holy and blameless. In Him we have redemption through His blood and were marked with the seal of the promised Holy Spirit.
Ephesians 2: You were dead in your transgressions, but God made us alive with Christ—it is by grace you have been saved through faith, not by works. He has made Jews and Gentiles one, destroying the dividing wall, so you are fellow citizens and members of God's household.
Ephesians 3: Paul explains the mystery made known to him—that through the gospel the Gentiles are heirs together with Israel and members of one body. He prays they would know the love of Christ and be filled to the measure of all the fullness of God.
Ephesians 4: Make every effort to keep the unity of the Spirit—there is one body, one Spirit, one Lord, one faith, one baptism, one God and Father of all. Put off your old self and put on the new self, created to be like God in true righteousness and holiness.
Ephesians 5: Walk in the way of love just as Christ loved us and gave Himself up as a fragrant offering, and be filled with the Spirit. Wives submit to your husbands as to the Lord, and husbands love your wives just as Christ loved the church.
Ephesians 6: Children, obey your parents in the Lord, and fathers, bring them up in the training and instruction of the Lord. Put on the full armor of God—belt of truth, breastplate of righteousness, gospel of peace, shield of faith, helmet of salvation, and sword of the Spirit.
Philippians 1: Paul gives thanks for the Philippians' partnership in the gospel, confident that He who began a good work will carry it on to completion. For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain, yet it is more necessary that I remain for your progress in the faith.
Philippians 2: Have the same mindset as Christ Jesus who made Himself nothing, taking the nature of a servant and becoming obedient to death on a cross, therefore God exalted Him to the highest place. Continue to work out your salvation with fear and trembling, for it is God who works in you.
Philippians 3: Watch out for those who mutilate the flesh, for we who serve God by His Spirit are the true circumcision. Paul counts his former achievements as loss compared to knowing Christ, pressing on toward the goal to win the prize.
Philippians 4: Rejoice in the Lord always—do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation present your requests to God with thanksgiving. I can do all things through Him who gives me strength, and my God will meet all your needs.
Colossians 1: Paul thanks God for the Colossians' faith and prays they would be filled with knowledge of His will. The Son is the image of the invisible God in whom all things were created, and God was pleased to reconcile all things through Christ's blood.
Colossians 2: Paul warns them not to be taken captive through philosophy and empty deception, for in Christ all the fullness of the Deity lives in bodily form. You have been given fullness in Him who is the head over every power and authority.
Colossians 3: Since you have been raised with Christ, set your hearts on things above where Christ is seated at God's right hand. As God's chosen people, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, patience, and above all, love.
Colossians 4: Masters, provide your slaves with what is right and fair, and devote yourselves to prayer, being wise toward outsiders. Paul sends greetings from his fellow workers including Tychicus, Onesimus, and Luke.
1 Thessalonians 1: Paul gives thanks for the Thessalonians' work of faith, labor of love, and endurance of hope in Jesus Christ. Your faith in God has become known everywhere so we do not need to say anything about it.
1 Thessalonians 2: You know our visit was not without results, for we had the courage to declare the gospel despite strong opposition. We were like a nursing mother caring for her little children and a father encouraging you to live lives worthy of God.
1 Thessalonians 3: When we could stand it no longer, we sent Timothy to strengthen and encourage you in your faith. Now Timothy has brought good news about your faith and love, and how can we thank God enough for the joy we have because of you?
1 Thessalonians 4: We urge you to live in order to please God, and God's will is your sanctification—that you should avoid sexual immorality. We do not want you to be uninformed about those who sleep in death, for at His coming the dead in Christ will rise first, then we who are alive will be caught up together with them to meet the Lord.
1 Thessalonians 5: The day of the Lord will come like a thief in the night, so let us not be like others who are asleep but be alert and sober. Rejoice always, pray continually, give thanks in all circumstances, and may your whole spirit, soul and body be kept blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
2 Thessalonians 1: Paul gives thanks for the Thessalonians' persevering faith and growing love despite persecutions and trials they are enduring. God will pay back trouble to those who trouble you and give relief when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven in blazing fire.
2 Thessalonians 2: Concerning the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, don't let anyone deceive you—that day will not come until the rebellion occurs and the man of lawlessness is revealed. Stand firm and hold fast to the teachings passed on to you, and may our Lord Jesus Christ encourage your hearts.
2 Thessalonians 3: Finally, pray for us that the message of the Lord may spread rapidly and that we may be delivered from wicked people. We hear that some among you are idle, so such people we command to settle down and earn the food they eat.
1 Timothy 1: Paul urges Timothy to remain in Ephesus and command certain people not to teach false doctrines or devote themselves to myths and endless genealogies. Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners—of whom I am the worst—and Timothy should fight the good fight, holding on to faith and a good conscience.
1 Timothy 2: I urge that requests, prayers, intercession and thanksgiving be made for all people, for kings and those in authority, that we may live peaceful and quiet lives. For there is one God and one mediator between God and mankind, the man Christ Jesus, who gave Himself as a ransom for all people.
1 Timothy 3: Whoever aspires to be an overseer desires a noble task, and an overseer must be above reproach, faithful to his wife, temperate, self-controlled, respectable, and able to teach. Deacons likewise must be worthy of respect, sincere, and must keep hold of the deep truths of the faith with a clear conscience.
1 Timothy 4: The Spirit clearly says that in later times some will abandon the faith and follow deceiving spirits and things taught by demons. Train yourself to be godly, and don't let anyone look down on you because you are young, but set an example in speech, conduct, love, faith and purity.
1 Timothy 5: Do not rebuke an older man harshly but exhort him as a father, and treat younger men as brothers, older women as mothers, and younger women as sisters. Give proper recognition to widows who are really in need, and elders who direct the affairs of the church well are worthy of double honor.
1 Timothy 6: Those who are under the yoke of slavery should consider their masters worthy of full respect. People who want to get rich fall into temptation, for the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil, but you, man of God, pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, endurance and gentleness.
2 Timothy 1: I am reminded of your sincere faith, which first lived in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice. God did not give us a spirit of timidity but a spirit of power, love and self-discipline, so do not be ashamed to testify about our Lord.
2 Timothy 2: You then, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus, and the things you have heard me say entrust to reliable people. Endure hardship like a good soldier of Christ Jesus, and if we died with Him, we will also live with Him.
2 Timothy 3: Mark this: There will be terrible times in the last days when people will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, and lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God. But as for you, continue in what you have learned, because all Scripture is God-breathed and useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness.
2 Timothy 4: In the presence of God and of Christ Jesus, I give you this charge: Preach the word, be prepared in season and out of season, correct, rebuke and encourage. I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith, and now there is in store for me the crown of righteousness.
Titus 1: Paul writes to Titus in Crete to appoint elders in every town—men who are blameless, faithful to their wives, whose children believe. An overseer must be blameless as one entrusted with God's work, hospitable, self-controlled, upright, holy and disciplined, holding firmly to the trustworthy message.
Titus 2: Teach what accords with sound doctrine—older men are to be temperate and self-controlled; older women reverent; younger women to love their husbands; and young men to be self-controlled. The grace of God has appeared bringing salvation, teaching us to say 'No' to ungodliness and live self-controlled, upright and godly lives as we wait for the blessed hope.
Titus 3: Remind the people to be subject to rulers and authorities, to be obedient and ready to do whatever is good. When the kindness and love of God our Savior appeared, He saved us through the washing of rebirth and renewal by the Holy Spirit, so that having been justified by His grace, we might become heirs.
Philemon 1: Paul appeals to Philemon on behalf of Onesimus, his slave who became a believer while with Paul, asking Philemon to welcome him back not as a slave but as a dear brother. Paul offers to repay anything Onesimus owes, confident that Philemon will do even more than he asks.
Hebrews 1: In the past God spoke through the prophets, but in these last days He has spoken through His Son, the radiance of God's glory and exact representation of His being. The Son is superior to angels—God never said to an angel 'You are my Son' or 'Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool.'
Hebrews 2: We must pay more careful attention to what we have heard, lest we drift away, for how shall we escape if we ignore so great a salvation? Since the children have flesh and blood, Jesus too shared in their humanity so that by His death He might break the power of him who holds the power of death.
Hebrews 3: Fix your thoughts on Jesus, our apostle and high priest, who was faithful to the one who appointed Him just as Moses was faithful in all God's house. Today, if you hear His voice, do not harden your hearts as you did in the rebellion during the time of testing in the wilderness.
Hebrews 4: Therefore, since the promise of entering His rest still stands, let us be careful that none of you be found to have fallen short. We have a great high priest who has ascended into heaven, Jesus the Son of God, who sympathizes with our weaknesses and was tempted in every way just as we are, yet without sin.
Hebrews 5: Every high priest is selected from among the people to represent them before God, offering gifts and sacrifices for sins. Christ did not take on Himself the glory of becoming a high priest but was called by God, and although He was a son, He learned obedience from what He suffered.
Hebrews 6: Let us move beyond the elementary teachings about Christ and be taken forward to maturity, not laying again the foundation of repentance and faith. It is impossible for those who have once been enlightened and shared in the Holy Spirit, if they fall away, to be brought back to repentance.
Hebrews 7: Melchizedek was without father or mother, without genealogy, without beginning of days or end of life, resembling the Son of God and remaining a priest forever. Jesus has become a high priest forever in the order of Melchizedek, able to save completely those who come to God through Him because He always lives to intercede for them.
Hebrews 8: We have such a high priest who sat down at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven, a minister in the true tabernacle set up by the Lord. The ministry Jesus has received is superior to the old one, and the covenant of which He is mediator is founded on better promises.
Hebrews 9: The first covenant had regulations for worship and an earthly sanctuary where priests entered regularly, but only the high priest entered the Most Holy Place once a year with blood. Christ entered the Most Holy Place once for all by His own blood, obtaining eternal redemption, and just as people are destined to die once and face judgment, so Christ was sacrificed once to take away the sins of many.
Hebrews 10: The law is only a shadow of the good things to come, not the realities themselves, so it can never make perfect those who draw near to worship. By God's will we have been made holy through the sacrifice of Christ's body once for all, so let us draw near with a sincere heart in full assurance of faith.
Hebrews 11: Faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see, and by it the ancients were commended. By faith Abel, Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Moses, and others obeyed God, and all these people were still living by faith when they died, not having received what was promised but seeing it from a distance.
Hebrews 12: Since we are surrounded by such a great cloud of witnesses, let us throw off everything that hinders and run with perseverance the race marked out for us, fixing our eyes on Jesus. Endure hardship as discipline, for God is treating you as His children, and no discipline seems pleasant at the time but later produces a harvest of righteousness and peace.
Hebrews 13: Keep on loving one another as brothers and sisters, show hospitality to strangers, honor marriage, and keep your lives free from the love of money. Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever, so through Jesus let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise.
James 1: Consider it pure joy when you face trials of many kinds, because the testing of your faith produces perseverance which must finish its work so you may be mature and complete. Do not merely listen to the word but do what it says, for anyone who listens but does not do is like someone who looks in a mirror and immediately forgets what they look like.
James 2: Believers in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ must not show favoritism, for if you show special attention to the rich but say to the poor 'Stand there,' have you not discriminated? Faith by itself, if not accompanied by action, is dead—show me your faith without deeds and I will show you my faith by my deeds.
James 3: Not many should become teachers, for we who teach will be judged more strictly, and we all stumble in many ways. The tongue is a small part of the body but makes great boasts—it is a fire, a restless evil full of deadly poison, and with it we bless the Lord and curse people made in God's image.
James 4: What causes fights and quarrels among you? Don't they come from your desires that battle within you—you desire but do not have, so you quarrel and fight. Submit yourselves to God, resist the devil and he will flee from you, draw near to God and He will draw near to you.
James 5: Now listen, you rich people, weep and wail because of the misery coming on you, for the wages you failed to pay the workers cry out against you. Be patient and stand firm because the Lord's coming is near, and the prayer of a righteous person is powerful and effective.
1 Peter 1: Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ who in His great mercy has given us new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ. You were redeemed not with perishable things like silver or gold but with the precious blood of Christ, a lamb without blemish or defect.
1 Peter 2: Rid yourselves of all malice, deceit, hypocrisy, envy, and slander, and like newborn babies, crave pure spiritual milk so you may grow up in your salvation. You are a chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, God's special possession, that you may declare the praises of Him who called you out of darkness into His wonderful light.
1 Peter 3: Wives, submit yourselves to your own husbands so that if any do not believe, they may be won over by your behavior, and husbands, be considerate and treat them with respect. Do not repay evil with evil or insult with insult, but with blessing, and always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope you have.
1 Peter 4: Since Christ suffered in His body, arm yourselves also with the same attitude, living the rest of your earthly life for God's will rather than evil human desires. Above all, love each other deeply because love covers a multitude of sins, and each of you should use whatever gift you have received to serve others.
1 Peter 5: To the elders: Be shepherds of God's flock under your care, watching over them not as lording it over those entrusted to you but being examples. Humble yourselves under God's mighty hand that He may lift you up in due time, casting all your anxiety on Him because He cares for you.
2 Peter 1: His divine power has given us everything we need for a godly life through our knowledge of Him who called us, and through these He has given us His very great and precious promises. Make every effort to add to your faith goodness, knowledge, self-control, perseverance, godliness, mutual affection and love.
2 Peter 2: False prophets appeared among the people, and there will be false teachers among you who will secretly introduce destructive heresies, even denying the sovereign Lord. If God did not spare angels when they sinned but cast them to hell, and if He condemned Sodom yet rescued righteous Lot, then the Lord knows how to rescue the godly from trials.
2 Peter 3: Scoffers will come saying 'Where is this coming He promised?' but the day of the Lord will come like a thief—the heavens will disappear with a roar and the earth will be laid bare. Since you are looking forward to a new heaven and a new earth where righteousness dwells, make every effort to be found spotless, blameless and at peace with Him.
1 John 1: That which was from the beginning, which we have heard and seen with our eyes and touched with our hands, we proclaim to you—the Word of life appeared. If we claim to be without sin, we deceive ourselves, but if we confess our sins, He is faithful and just and will forgive us and purify us from all unrighteousness.
1 John 2: My dear children, I write this to you so that you will not sin, but if anybody does sin, we have an advocate with the Father—Jesus Christ, the Righteous One. Do not love the world or anything in it, for the world and its desires pass away, but whoever does the will of God lives forever.
1 John 3: See what great love the Father has lavished on us, that we should be called children of God! And that is what we are. This is how we know what love is: Jesus Christ laid down His life for us, and we ought to lay down our lives for our brothers and sisters.
1 John 4: Dear friends, do not believe every spirit but test the spirits to see whether they are from God, because many false prophets have gone out into the world. God is love—whoever lives in love lives in God and God in them, and we love because He first loved us.
1 John 5: Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Christ is born of God, and everyone who loves the Father loves His child as well. This is love for God: to keep His commands, and His commands are not burdensome, for everyone born of God overcomes the world through faith.
2 John 1: The elder to the lady chosen by God and to her children: I rejoice to find some of your children walking in the truth, just as the Father commanded us. Many deceivers have gone out into the world who do not acknowledge Jesus Christ as coming in the flesh—such a person is the deceiver and the antichrist, so watch out that you do not lose what we have worked for.
3 John 1: The elder to my dear friend Gaius: I pray that you may enjoy good health and that all may go well with you, just as your soul is getting along well. You are faithful in what you are doing for the brothers and sisters, and I wrote to the church but Diotrephes, who loves to be first, will not welcome us.
Jude 1: Jude urges believers to contend for the faith that was once for all entrusted to God's holy people, for certain ungodly people have secretly slipped in among you who pervert the grace of God. Build yourselves up in your most holy faith and pray in the Holy Spirit, keep yourselves in God's love as you wait for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ to bring you to eternal life.
Revelation 1: John, exiled on Patmos, receives a revelation from Jesus Christ to show His servants what must soon take place, declaring 'I am the Alpha and the Omega who is and who was and who is to come, the Almighty.' John sees someone like a son of man among seven golden lampstands with eyes like blazing fire, saying 'Do not be afraid. I am the First and the Last. I am the Living One; I was dead, and now look, I am alive for ever and ever!'
Revelation 2: Jesus gives messages to four churches: to Ephesus—you have forsaken your first love, repent; to Smyrna—be faithful even to death and I will give you life as your crown; to Pergamum—you have people who hold to false teaching, repent; to Thyatira—you tolerate Jezebel who teaches sexual immorality. To the one who is victorious, I will give authority over the nations.
Revelation 3: Jesus continues His messages: to Sardis—you have a reputation of being alive but you are dead, wake up; to Philadelphia—I have placed before you an open door that no one can shut; to Laodicea—you are lukewarm, neither hot nor cold, so I am about to spit you out of my mouth. I stand at the door and knock, and those whom I love I rebuke and discipline, so be earnest and repent.
Revelation 4: John sees a door standing open in heaven and a voice says 'Come up here, and I will show you what must take place after this.' Around the throne are twenty-four elders dressed in white with golden crowns, and four living creatures covered with eyes saying day and night 'Holy, holy, holy is the Lord God Almighty, who was, and is, and is to come.'
Revelation 5: John sees a scroll with seven seals in the right hand of Him on the throne, and he weeps because no one is found worthy to open it until an elder says 'See, the Lion of the tribe of Judah has triumphed. He is able to open the scroll.' Then John sees a Lamb looking as if it had been slain, and when He takes the scroll, all sing 'You are worthy because you were slain, and with your blood you purchased for God persons from every tribe and language and people and nation.'
Revelation 6: The Lamb opens the first four seals and four horsemen appear: a white horse whose rider conquers; a fiery red horse whose rider takes peace from the earth; a black horse whose rider brings famine; and a pale horse whose rider is Death. When the sixth seal is opened, there is a great earthquake, the sun turns black, the moon becomes like blood, and people hide in caves crying 'Fall on us and hide us from the face of Him who sits on the throne!'
Revelation 7: John sees four angels holding back the winds, and another angel ascends with the seal of the living God to seal 144,000 from the twelve tribes of Israel on their foreheads. After this John sees a great multitude from every nation, tribe, people, and language standing before the throne in white robes crying out 'Salvation belongs to our God who sits on the throne, and to the Lamb!'
Revelation 8: When the Lamb opens the seventh seal, there is silence in heaven for about half an hour, then seven angels are given seven trumpets. As the first four trumpets sound, hail and fire are hurled down, a mountain on fire is thrown into the sea, a star falls making waters bitter, and a third of the sun and moon are struck.
Revelation 9: The fifth angel sounds his trumpet and a star falls from heaven opening the Abyss, releasing locusts with power like scorpions to torment people for five months who do not have the seal of God. The sixth angel sounds his trumpet and four angels are released to kill a third of mankind, yet the rest of mankind still did not repent of their murders, magic arts, sexual immorality, or thefts.
Revelation 10: John sees a mighty angel coming down from heaven holding a little scroll, and when the angel gave a loud shout, seven thunders spoke but John is told to seal up what they said. The angel declares there will be no more delay—in the days of the seventh trumpet, the mystery of God will be accomplished, and John is told to take the scroll and eat it.
Revelation 11: John is given a measuring rod to measure the temple of God, and two witnesses prophesy for 1,260 days, and when they finish, the beast kills them, but after three and a half days God's breath enters them and they stand on their feet. The seventh angel sounds his trumpet and loud voices in heaven say 'The kingdom of the world has become the kingdom of our Lord and of his Messiah, and he will reign for ever and ever.'
Revelation 12: A woman clothed with the sun gives birth to a son who will rule all nations, but an enormous red dragon tries to devour the child, who is snatched up to God's throne. War breaks out in heaven and Michael and his angels fight the dragon—the ancient serpent called the devil and Satan—who is hurled to the earth, and a loud voice declares 'Now have come the salvation and the power and the kingdom of our God.'
Revelation 13: John sees a beast coming out of the sea with ten horns and seven heads, and the dragon gives the beast his power, throne, and great authority, and the whole world follows the beast. Another beast comes out of the earth exercising all the authority of the first beast and forcing all people to receive a mark on their right hands or foreheads—the number of the beast is 666.
Revelation 14: John sees the Lamb standing on Mount Zion with 144,000 who have His name and His Father's name written on their foreheads, singing a new song before the throne. Three angels proclaim messages: fear God for the hour of His judgment has come; Babylon has fallen; and if anyone worships the beast and receives its mark, they will drink the wine of God's fury.
Revelation 15: John sees seven angels with the seven last plagues—last because with them God's wrath is completed. Those who had been victorious over the beast stand beside a sea of glass singing 'Great and marvelous are your deeds, Lord God Almighty. Just and true are your ways, King of the nations.'
Revelation 16: A loud voice from the temple tells the seven angels 'Go, pour out the seven bowls of God's wrath on the earth,' bringing painful sores, blood in seas and rivers, scorching sun, darkness over the beast's kingdom, and the Euphrates dries up. The seventh bowl brings the worst earthquake in history, destroying cities and islands.
Revelation 17: One of the seven angels shows John the judgment of the great prostitute sitting on many waters, drunk with the blood of God's holy people. She sits on a scarlet beast with seven heads and ten horns, and on her forehead is written MYSTERY: BABYLON THE GREAT, and the ten horns will hate the prostitute and bring her to ruin.
Revelation 18: Another angel cries out 'Fallen! Fallen is Babylon the Great!' and another voice calls 'Come out of her, my people, so that you will not share in her sins.' In one hour she has been brought to ruin, and merchants weep because no one buys their cargoes of gold, silver, precious stones, pearls, fine linen, and every kind of luxury.
Revelation 19: A great multitude in heaven shouts 'Hallelujah! Salvation and glory and power belong to our God!' and the wedding of the Lamb has come. John sees heaven standing open and a white horse whose rider is called Faithful and True with a name written on Him: KING OF KINGS AND LORD OF LORDS, and the beast and the kings of the earth are captured and thrown into the fiery lake.
Revelation 20: An angel seizes the dragon, that ancient serpent who is the devil and Satan, and binds him for a thousand years in the Abyss, and John sees thrones on which were seated those given authority to judge. When Satan is released, he deceives the nations but fire comes down from heaven and devours them, and the devil is thrown into the lake of burning sulfur, and the dead are judged according to what they have done.
Revelation 21: John sees a new heaven and a new earth, and the Holy City, the new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, prepared as a bride beautifully dressed for her husband. A loud voice declares 'Look! God's dwelling place is now among the people, and He will dwell with them. He will wipe every tear from their eyes. There will be no more death or mourning or crying or pain, for the old order of things has passed away.'
Revelation 22: The angel shows John the river of the water of life flowing from the throne of God and of the Lamb, and on each side of the river stands the tree of life bearing twelve crops of fruit, and no longer will there be any curse. Jesus declares 'Look, I am coming soon! Blessed is the one who keeps the words of the prophecy written in this scroll,' and the Spirit and the bride say 'Come!' and whoever is thirsty, let them come and take the free gift of the water of life.
